sentence:
Let G be a finite group and let X→ S be a family of stable curves of genus g with n marked disjoint sections s_1,…, s_n.  Let μ=(r_1,…, r_n) be a n-tuple of natural numbers that divide #(G), and denote k_i=#(G)/r_i for i=1,…, n. An admissible G-cover of X consists of a finite morphism f X'→ X from a family of stable curves X'→ S that is Galois and unramified away from the sections of X, an action of G on X', and disjoint sections s'_ij of X' over S for i=1,…,n and j=1,…,k_i, 

subject to the following conditions: 


  * The map f:X'→ X is a principal G-bundle away from the nodes and sections of X.

  * The preimage of the set of nodes in X is precisely the set of nodes of X'.

  * The preimage of a section s_i is precisely given by the sections s'_i1,…, s'_ik_i.

  * Let p be a node in X and p' a node of X' above p. Then étale-locally p' is given by x'y'=t for t∈_S and p is étale-locally given by xy=t^r for some integer r≥ 1 with x'=x^r and y'=y^r, and the stabilizer of G at p' is cyclic of order r and operates via 

    (x',y')⟼ (ζ x',ζ^-1 y')

for an r-th root of unity ζ∈μ_r. 

  * Étale-locally near the sections s_i and s'_ij respectively, the morphism f is given by _S[t_i]→_S[t_ij'] with (t_ij')^r_i=t_i, and the stabilizer of G along s_ij is cyclic or order r_i and operates via t'_ij↦ζ t, for an r_i-th root of unity ζ∈μ_r_i.

sentence:
Let π∈_n and let x,y be a pair of rooks that is a descent,
  i.e. y_i=x_i-1 and x_j<y_j.
  Then, x,y is a light reduction pair if
  we have the situation in Figure <ref>(a), i.e.
  
  
  * there is no rook a with a_i<y_i and a_j>y_j, and
  
  * there is no rook a with a_i>x_i and x_j<a_j<y_j.
  
  The pair x,y is called a heavy reduction pair if we have the 
  situation
  in Figure <ref>(b), i.e.
  
  
  * there is no rook a with a_i>x_i and a_j<x_j,
  
  * there is no rook a with a_i<y_i and a_j>y_j, and
  
  * there is no pair of rooks a,b such that
    a_i<y_i and b_i>x_i and x_j<a_j<b_j<y_j (or, equivalently,
there is some x_j≤ j<y_j such that the regions
[1,y_i-1]×[x_j+1,j] and [x_i+1,n]×[j+1,y_j-1] are both
empty).

sentence: A local modification rule is a pair (A,T), where A is a finite set, and T: 2^A ⊎ [2]2→{0,1} is a map from graphs on A ∪ [2] to {0,1}, where [2] := {1,2}, which is symmetric with respect to interchange of the 1 and 2 labels.  Given any vertex set V, we define a modification map T^(V): 2^A ⊎ V2→ 2^V2 by declaring an edge (v_1,v_2) in V to lie in T^(V)(G) for some G ∈ 2^A ⊎ V2 if and only if T( {0,1}_2^(𝕀_A ⊕ϕ)(G) ) = 1, where 𝕀_A ⊕ϕ: A ⊎ [2] → A ⊎{v_1,v_2} is the map which is the identity on A and maps 1,2 to v_1,v_2 respectively.

sentence:
A vertex set is any set which is at most countable.  If V and W are vertex sets, we define a morphism from W to V to be an injective map ϕ: W → V, and use (W,V) to denote the space of such morphisms.  We use 𝕀_V ∈(V,V) to denote the identity map from V to itself, and if W ⊂ V, we use ι_W ⊂ V∈(W,V) to denote the inclusion map.  If N is a non-negative integer, we use [N] := { 1,…,N} to denote the vertex set of integers from 1 to N.  If v_1,…,v_N are distinct vertices of V, we use (v_1,…,v_N) ∈([N],V) to denote the morphism that sends i to v_i for all i ∈ [N] (in particular, we canonically embed ([N],V) in V^N, and the unique element of ([0],V) is denoted ()).  If V is a set, we use |V| to denote the cardinality of V, and for any k ≥ 0 we let

    Vk := { e ⊂ V: |e| = k }≡([k],V)/([k],[k])

denote the k-element subsets of V.  If V, W are vertex sets, we use V ⊎ W := (V ×{0}) ∪ (W ×{1}) to denote the disjoint union of V and W.  We often abuse notation and view V and W as subsets of V ⊎ W.  If ϕ_1 ∈(W_1,V_1) and ϕ_2 ∈(W_2,V_2), we use ϕ_1 ⊕ϕ_2 ∈(W_1 ⊎ W_2, V_1 ⊎ V_2) to denote the direct sum of ϕ_1 and ϕ_2.

sentence: A finite palette is a sequence K = (K_j)_j=0^∞ of finite non-empty sets, all but finitely many of which are singleton sets.  We refer to the singleton components as points and denote them by .  We define the order of K to be the greatest integer k for which K_k is not a point (or -1 if all components are points).  We shall often abbreviate K as (K_0,…,K_k) (thus discarding the trivial palettes K_j = for j > k).  For any k ≥ 0, we define the monochromatic palette {0,1}_k of order k to be the palette whose k^þ component is {0,1} and all other components are points.  If j ∈, we let K_≤ j (resp. K_<j, K_≥ j, K_>j, K_=j) be the palette whose i^þ component is K_i when i ≤ j (resp. i < j, i ≥ j, i>j, i=j), and is  otherwise, thus for instance K = K_≥ 0 = K_>-1.

sentence:
If V is a vertex set, we define a K-coloured (directed) hypergraph to be a tuple G = (G_j)_j=0^∞, where each G_j: ([j],V) → K_j is a function.  (Note that G_j will be trivial when K_j is a point, and so only finitely many of the G_j are of any interest.  We will often abuse notation slightly by omitting the trivial components G_j of a hypergraph.)  We let

    K^(V)≡∏_j=0^∞ K_j^([j],V)

denote the collection of all K-coloured hypergraphs on V.  We say that the hypergraph is undirected if we have the symmetry property G_j( ϕ∘σ ) = G_j(ϕ) for all j ≥ 0, all σ∈([j],[j]), and all ϕ∈([j],V).  If ϕ∈(W,V) is a morphism between vertex sets, we define the pullback map K^(ϕ): K^(V)→ K^(W) by defining K^(ϕ)(G)_j(ψ) := G_j(ϕ∘ψ) for all G = (G_j)_j=0^∞∈ K^(V), j ≥ 0, and ψ∈([j],W). If W is a subset of V, we write G⇂_W for K^(ι_W ⊂ V)(G), and refer to G⇂_W as the restriction of G to W.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A contravariant functor Z is an assignment of a sub-Cantor space Z^(V) to every vertex set V, together with a probability kernel Z^(ϕ): Z^(V)→ Z^(W) for every morphism[Recall that in the category of vertex sets (as opposed to that of sub-Cantor spaces), the morphisms are just the (deterministic) injective maps between vertex sets.] ϕ∈(W,V) between vertex sets, such that Z^(𝕀_V): Z^(V)→ Z^(V) is the identity probability kernel on Z^(V) for every vertex sets V, and such that Z^(ϕ∘ψ) = Z^(ψ)∘ Z^(ϕ) for any morphisms ϕ∈(W,V) and ψ∈(V,U) between vertex sets.  We say that the contravariant functor is deterministically continuous (resp. weakly continuous ) if all the probability kernels Z^(ϕ) are deterministically continuous (resp. weakly continuous).  If z ∈ Z^(V) and W ⊂ V, we write z⇂_W ∈ Z^(W) for Z^(ι_W ⊂ V)(z), and refer to z⇂_W as the restriction of z to W. Similarly, if μ∈(Z^(V)) and W ⊂ V, we write μ⇂_W ∈(Z^(W)) for the projected measure Z^ι_W ⊂ V∘μ.

If Z is a contravariant functor and S is a vertex set, we define the shift Z^⊎ S to be the contravariant functor given by requiring that

    (Z^⊎ S)^(V) := Z^(V ⊎ S)

for all vertex sets V and

    (Z^⊎ S)^(ϕ) := Z^(ϕ⊕𝕀_S)

for all morphisms ϕ.  One easily verifies that Z^⊎ S is a contravariant functor, which is deterministically continuous (resp. weakly continuous) if Z is.

sentence:
A natural transformation N: Z → Y between two contravariant functors Z, Y is an assignment of a probability kernel N^(V): Z^(V)⇝ Y^(V) for every vertex set V, such that the diagram

    Z^(V)             @>N^(V)>>   Y^(V)
    
    @VVZ^(ϕ)V                   @VVY^(ϕ)V            
    
    Z^(W)             @>N^(W)>>   Y^(W)

commutes for every morphism ϕ∈(W,V) between vertex sets (the horizontal arrows here being probability kernels rather than continuous maps).  We say that the natural transformation is deterministically continuous (resp. weakly continuous ) if all the probability kernels N^(V) are deterministically continuous (resp. weakly continuous).

An exchangeable Z-recipe on a contravariant functor Z is a natural transformation μ: → Z from the trivial functor to Z, or equivalently an assignment of a probability measure μ^(V)∈(Z^(V)) to every vertex set V, such that one has the exchangeability property

    Z^(ϕ)∘μ^(V) = μ^(W)

for all morphisms ϕ∈(W,V) between two vertex sets.  If S is a vertex set, we define the exchangeable Z^⊎ S-recipe μ^⊎ S: → Z^⊎ S by the formula (μ^⊎ S)^(V) := μ^(V ⊎ S).

We arbitrarily select a default point z_* ∈ Z_k.  For any V, we define z_*^(V)∈ Z_k^(V) by setting z_*^(V)(ϕ) := z_*
for all ϕ∈([k],V).

sentence:
[Testability for graph properties]<cit.>  A graph property  is said to be locally testable with one-sided error , or testable for short, if for every > 0 there exists N ≥ 1 and a real number δ > 0 with the following property: whenever G = (V,E) is a graph with N ≤ |V| < ∞ which locally almost obeys  in the sense that

    1/|VN| |{ W ∈VN: G ⇂_W ∈^(W)}| ≥ 1-δ

(thus most N-element induced subgraphs of G obey ), then there exists G' = (V,E') obeying  which is close to G in the sense that 1/V2 |E Δ E'| ≤.

sentence: [Local modification rule]  A local modification rule is a pair (A,T), where A is a finite set, and T: 2^A ⊎ [2]2→{0,1} is a map from graphs on A ∪ [2] to {0,1}, where [2] := {1,2}, which is symmetric with respect to interchange of the 1 and 2 labels.  Given any vertex set V, we define a modification map T^(V): 2^A ⊎ V2→ 2^V2 by declaring an edge (v_1,v_2) in V to lie in T^(V)(G) for some G ∈ 2^A ⊎ V2 if and only if T( {0,1}_2^(𝕀_A ⊕ϕ)(G) ) = 1, where 𝕀_A ⊕ϕ: A ⊎ [2] → A ⊎{v_1,v_2} is the map which is the identity on A and maps 1,2 to v_1,v_2 respectively.

sentence:
[Weak local repairability]  Let 𝒫 be a graph property.  We say that 𝒫 is weakly locally repairable if for every > 0 there exists a finite set A, an integer N ≥ |A|+2, and a δ > 0 with the following property: if G = (V,E) is a graph with N ≤ |V| < ∞ which almost obeys 𝒫 in the sense of (<ref>), then there exists an embedding of A in V (thus identifying V with A ⊎ V' for some |V'| = |V| - |A|) and a local modification rule (A,T) such that G' = (V',E') := T^(V')(G) obeys 𝒫, and G' is close to G in the sense that 

    |E' Δ (E⇂_V')| ≤ |V'2|

where E⇂_V' := E ∩V'2.

sentence:
[Vertex sets]  A vertex set is any set which is at most countable.  If V and W are vertex sets, we define a morphism from W to V to be an injective map ϕ: W → V, and use (W,V) to denote the space of such morphisms.  We use 𝕀_V ∈(V,V) to denote the identity map from V to itself, and if W ⊂ V, we use ι_W ⊂ V∈(W,V) to denote the inclusion map.  If N is a non-negative integer, we use [N] := { 1,…,N} to denote the vertex set of integers from 1 to N.  If v_1,…,v_N are distinct vertices of V, we use (v_1,…,v_N) ∈([N],V) to denote the morphism that sends i to v_i for all i ∈ [N] (in particular, we canonically embed ([N],V) in V^N, and the unique element of ([0],V) is denoted ()).  If V is a set, we use |V| to denote the cardinality of V, and for any k ≥ 0 we let

    Vk := { e ⊂ V: |e| = k }≡([k],V)/([k],[k])

denote the k-element subsets of V.  If V, W are vertex sets, we use V ⊎ W := (V ×{0}) ∪ (W ×{1}) to denote the disjoint union of V and W.  We often abuse notation and view V and W as subsets of V ⊎ W.  If ϕ_1 ∈(W_1,V_1) and ϕ_2 ∈(W_2,V_2), we use ϕ_1 ⊕ϕ_2 ∈(W_1 ⊎ W_2, V_1 ⊎ V_2) to denote the direct sum of ϕ_1 and ϕ_2.

We shall often abbreviate K as (K_0,…,K_k) (thus discarding the trivial palettes K_j = for j > k).  For any k ≥ 0, we define the monochromatic palette {0,1}_k of order k to be the palette whose k^þ component is {0,1} and all other components are points.  If j ∈, we let K_≤ j (resp. K_<j, K_≥ j, K_>j, K_=j) be the palette whose i^þ component is K_i when i ≤ j (resp. i < j, i ≥ j, i>j, i=j), and is  otherwise, thus for instance K = K_≥ 0 = K_>-1.

sentence:
[Hypergraphs]  If V is a vertex set, we define a K-coloured (directed) hypergraph to be a tuple G = (G_j)_j=0^∞, where each G_j: ([j],V) → K_j is a function.  (Note that G_j will be trivial when K_j is a point, and so only finitely many of the G_j are of any interest.  We will often abuse notation slightly by omitting the trivial components G_j of a hypergraph.)  We let

    K^(V)≡∏_j=0^∞ K_j^([j],V)

denote the collection of all K-coloured hypergraphs on V.  We say that the hypergraph is undirected if we have the symmetry property G_j( ϕ∘σ ) = G_j(ϕ) for all j ≥ 0, all σ∈([j],[j]), and all ϕ∈([j],V).  If ϕ∈(W,V) is a morphism between vertex sets, we define the pullback map K^(ϕ): K^(V)→ K^(W) by defining K^(ϕ)(G)_j(ψ) := G_j(ϕ∘ψ) for all G = (G_j)_j=0^∞∈ K^(V), j ≥ 0, and ψ∈([j],W). If W is a subset of V, we write G⇂_W for K^(ι_W ⊂ V)(G), and refer to G⇂_W as the restriction of G to W.

sentence:
[Hereditary hypergraph properties]  Let K = (K_j)_j=0^∞ be a finite palette.  A hereditary K-property is an assignment : V ↦^(V) of a collection ^(V)⊂ K^(V) of K-coloured hypergraphs on V for every[Technically, the class of finite vertex sets is not itself a set, and so  is a class function rather than a function.  If one wishes to work with actual functions, one restricting attention to vertex sets which are (for instance) subsets of the integers.  As this issue does not make any actual impact on our arguments, we shall henceforth ignore it.]  finite vertex set V, such that

    K^(ϕ)( ^(V) ) ⊂^(W)

for every morphism ϕ∈(W,V) between finite vertex sets.  In particular, the K-property  is invariant under hypergraph isomorphism and preserved under hypergraph restriction[In category-theoretic language, one can view  (like K) as a contravariant functor, in which ^(ϕ): ^(V)→^(W) is the restriction of the pullback map K^(ϕ) to ^(V) for any injection ϕ: W → V; see Example <ref>.].  We say that the K-property  is undirected if ^(V) consists entirely of undirected hypergraphs for each vertex set V.  We extend  to countably infinite vertex sets V by declaring

    ^(V) := { G ∈ K^(V): G⇂_W ∈^(W) for all finite  W ⊂ V }.

We say that a hypergraph G ∈ K^(V) obeys  if G ∈^(V).

sentence:
[Testability]<cit.>  Let K be a finite palette of some order k ≥ 0, and let  be a hereditary K-property.  We say that  is testable with one-sided error if, for every > 0, there exists an integer N ≥ 1 and a real number δ > 0 with the following property: if G ∈ K^(V) is a K-coloured hypergraph with N ≤ |V| < ∞ which
locally almost obeys  in the sense that

    1/|VN| |{ W ∈VN: G⇂_W ∈^(W)}| ≥ 1-δ,

then there exists G' ∈^(V) which is close to G in the sense that

    1/|Vk| |{ W ∈Vk: G⇂_W ≠ G'⇂_W }| ≤.

sentence:
[Continuous hypergraphs]  Let K be a finite palette. A K-coloured continuous hypergraph is a quadruplet G = (V,,ν,(G_j)_j=0^∞), where (V,,ν) is a probability space, and G_j: V^j → K_j is a measurable map for each j ≥ 0. If W is an vertex set, we define the sampling map G^(W): V^W → K^(W) by the formula

    G^(W)( v )_j(ϕ) = G_j(v ∘ϕ)

for all j ≥ 0, all ϕ∈([j],W), and all v ∈ V^W, where we view v as a function from W to V (and identify V^j with V^[j]).  If  is a K-property, we say that G obeys  if G^(W)(v) ∈^(W) for all vertex sets W and all v ∈ V^W.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Local modification rule, concrete definition] Let K = (K_j)_j=0^k be a finite palette.  A local modification rule is a pair T = (A, T), where A is a finite vertex set, and T is a collection of maps T_j: K^(A ⊎ [j])→ K_=j^([j]) for 0 ≤ j ≤ k which obey the ([j],[j])-equivariance condition

    K_=j^(ϕ)∘ T_j = T_j ∘ K^(𝕀_A ⊎ϕ)

for all ϕ∈([j],[j]).  Given such a rule, and given a vertex set V, we define the modification map T^(V): K^(A ⊎ V)→ K^(V) by the formula

    T^(V)(G)_j(ϕ) := T_j(K^(𝕀_A ⊎ϕ)(G))(ϕ)

for every vertex set V, all 0 ≤ j ≤ k, all G ∈ K^(A ⊎ V), and all ϕ∈([j],V); the components T^(V)(G)_j for j>k are of course trivial.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Local modification rule, categorical definition]  Let K be a finite palette.  A local modification rule is a pair T = (A, T), where A is a finite vertex set, and T is an assignment of a map T^(V): K^(A ⊎ V)→ K^(V) for every vertex set V (where A ⊎ V denotes the disjoint union of A and V), such that the diagram

    K^(A ⊎ V)                @>T^(V)>>   K^(V)
    
    @VVK^(𝕀_A ⊕ϕ)V                             @VVK^(ϕ)V            
    
    K^(A ⊎ W)                @>T^(W)>>   K^(W)

commutes for any morphism ϕ∈(W,V) between two vertex sets W,V.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Entailment and modification] Let (A,T) be a local modofication rule.  We say that this rule entails a K-property  if T^(V)( K^(A ⊎ V) ) ⊂^(V) for any vertex set V.


  * If G = (V,,ν,(G_j)_j=0^∞) is a continuous K-coloured hypergraph, and v = (v_a)_ a ∈ A∈ V^A is a collection of vertices in a, we define the modification T_v(G) = (V, , ν, (G'_j)_j=0^∞) of G to be the continuous K-coloured hypergraph given by the requirement that

    T_v(G)^(W)( w ) = T^(W)( G^(A ⊎ W)( v, w ) )

for all vertex sets W and all w ∈ V^W; one can verify that this requirement uniquely defines a continuous K-coloured hypergraph T_v(G).  Note that if T entails , then T_v(G) obeys  for every continuous K-coloured hypergraph G on a vertex set V, and any v ∈ V^A.

  * If G = (G_j)_j=0^∞ is a K-coloured hypergraph on a vertex set V, and ϕ∈(A,V), then we define the modification T_ϕ(G) of G to be the K-coloured hypergraph G' = (G'_j)_j=0^∞ on V \ϕ(A) defined by the formula

    T_ϕ(G) = T^(V \ϕ(A))( K^(ϕ⊎𝕀_V \ϕ(A))(G) ),

where ϕ⊎𝕀_V \ϕ(A): A ⊎ (V \ϕ(A)) → V is the bijection formed by the direct sum of ϕ: A →ϕ(A) and the identity map 𝕀_V \ϕ(A): V \ϕ(A) → V \ϕ(A).  Again, note that if T entails , then T_ϕ(G) obeys  for every K-coloured hypergraph on a vertex set V, and any ϕ∈(A,V).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Local repairability]  Let K be a finite palette of some order k, and let  be a hereditary K-property.


  * We say that  is strongly locally repairable if for every > 0 there exists a finite set A, an N > 0, and a real number δ > 0 with the following property: Whenever G = (V,,ν,(G_j)_j=0^k) is a continuous K-coloured hypergraph which approximately locally obeys  in the sense that[We use (E) to denote the indicator of an event E, thus (E)=1 when E is true and (E)=0 otherwise.]

    ∫_V^[N](G^([N])(v) ∈^([N])) dν^[N](v) ≥ 1-δ,

where ν^[N] is the N-fold product measure of ν on V^[N], then there exists a local modification rule T = (A,T) that entails , which does not significantly modify G in the sense that

    ∫_V^A∫_V^[k]( T_v(G)^([k])(w) ≠G^([k])(w) ) dν^A(v) dν^[k](w)  ≤.


  * We say that  is weakly locally repairable if for every > 0 there exists a finite set A, an integer N ≥ |A|+k, and a real number δ > 0 with the following property: whenever G is a K-coloured hypergraph on a vertex set V with N ≤ |V| < ∞ which approximately obeys  in the sense of (<ref>), then there exists a local modification rule T = (A,T) and ϕ∈(A,V) such that T_ϕ(G) obeys , and which is close to G in the sense that

    1/|V \ϕ(A)k||{ W ∈V \ϕ(A)k : T_ϕ(G)⇂_W ≠ G⇂_W }|  ≤.

sentence:
[Monotonicity]  An ordered finite palette is a finite palette K = (K_j)_j=0^∞, together with a partial ordering <_j on each component K_j which is a meet-semilattice , in the sense that any two elements c_j, c'_j in K_j have a unique meet[We say that z = x ∧ y is the meet of two elements x,y of a partially ordered set if z ≤ x,y, and if z ≥ z' for any z' ≤ x,y.] c_j ∧ c'_j; note that this is automatically a commutative and associative operation.  

Now let K be an ordered finite palette and  a hereditary K-property.


  * We say that  is monotone if if given any vertex set V and any K-coloured hypergraphs G ∈^(V), any hypergraph G' ∈ K^(V) with the property that G'_j(ϕ) ≤ G_j(ϕ) for all j ≥ 0 and ϕ∈([j],V), will obey .  (Informally: “deleting”  edges (or lowering the colour of edges) will preserve the property .)

  * We say that  is weakly monotone if given any vertex set V and any K-coloured hypergraphs G,G' ∈^(V), the hypergraph G ∧ G' ∈ K^(V) defined by (G ∧ G')_j(ϕ) := G_j(ϕ) ∧ G'_j(ϕ) for all j ≥ 0 and ϕ∈([j],V), also obeys .  (Informally, the “intersection” (or color-meet) of two hypergraphs obeying , continues to obey .)

sentence: [Partiteness]  Let K be a palette of order k ≥ 1.  If G ∈ K^(V) is a K-coloured hypergraph, 0 ≤ j ≤ k, and ϕ∈([j],V), we say that ϕ is a partite edge of G if the map G_1: V → K_1 is injective on ϕ([j]).  If G, G' ∈ K^(V), we say that G, G' are partite equivalent if G_1 = G'_1 and if G_j(ϕ) = G'_j(ϕ) for every 0 ≤ j ≤ k and every partite edge ϕ∈([j],V) of G (and thus of G').  We say that a hereditary K-property  is partite if it is preserved under partite equivalence, thus if G ∈^(V) and G' is partite equivalent to G, then G' ∈^(V).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Contravariant functor]  A contravariant functor Z is an assignment of a sub-Cantor space Z^(V) to every vertex set V, together with a probability kernel Z^(ϕ): Z^(V)→ Z^(W) for every morphism[Recall that in the category of vertex sets (as opposed to that of sub-Cantor spaces), the morphisms are just the (deterministic) injective maps between vertex sets.] ϕ∈(W,V) between vertex sets, such that Z^(𝕀_V): Z^(V)→ Z^(V) is the identity probability kernel on Z^(V) for every vertex sets V, and such that Z^(ϕ∘ψ) = Z^(ψ)∘ Z^(ϕ) for any morphisms ϕ∈(W,V) and ψ∈(V,U) between vertex sets.  We say that the contravariant functor is deterministically continuous (resp. weakly continuous ) if all the probability kernels Z^(ϕ) are deterministically continuous (resp. weakly continuous).  If z ∈ Z^(V) and W ⊂ V, we write z⇂_W ∈ Z^(W) for Z^(ι_W ⊂ V)(z), and refer to z⇂_W as the restriction of z to W. Similarly, if μ∈(Z^(V)) and W ⊂ V, we write μ⇂_W ∈(Z^(W)) for the projected measure Z^ι_W ⊂ V∘μ.

If Z is a contravariant functor and S is a vertex set, we define the shift Z^⊎ S to be the contravariant functor given by requiring that

    (Z^⊎ S)^(V) := Z^(V ⊎ S)

for all vertex sets V and

    (Z^⊎ S)^(ϕ) := Z^(ϕ⊕𝕀_S)

for all morphisms ϕ.  One easily verifies that Z^⊎ S is a contravariant functor, which is deterministically continuous (resp. weakly continuous) if Z is.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Sub-Cantor palettes]  A sub-Cantor palette is a tuple Z = (Z_j)_j=0^∞ of sub-Cantor spaces, all but finitely many of which are trivial.  We define the order of Z to be the largest k for which Z_k is non-trivial, or -1 if all components Z_j are trivial.  We identify Z with a deterministically continuous contravariant functor by defining

    Z^(V) := ∏_j=0^∞ Z_j^([j],V)

for all vertex sets V, and defining Z^(ϕ): Z^(V)→ Z^(W) for all morphisms ϕ∈(W,V) by the formula

    Z^(ϕ)( ( ( z_j(ψ) )_ψ∈([j],V) )_j=0^∞ ) = ( ( z_j(ϕ∘ψ) )_ψ∈([j],W) )_j=0^∞

for all ( ( z_j(ψ) )_ψ∈([j],V) )_j=0^∞∈ Z^(V).  One easily verifies that Z is indeed a deterministically continuous contravariant functor.

If j is an integer, we write Z_≤ j (resp. Z_<j, Z_≥ j, Z_>j, Z_=j) for the sub-Cantor palette whose i^þ component is Z_i when i ≤ j (resp. i<j, i≥ j, i>j, i=j) and a point otherwise.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Natural transformation]  A natural transformation N: Z → Y between two contravariant functors Z, Y is an assignment of a probability kernel N^(V): Z^(V)⇝ Y^(V) for every vertex set V, such that the diagram

    Z^(V)             @>N^(V)>>   Y^(V)
    
    @VVZ^(ϕ)V                   @VVY^(ϕ)V            
    
    Z^(W)             @>N^(W)>>   Y^(W)

commutes for every morphism ϕ∈(W,V) between vertex sets (the horizontal arrows here being probability kernels rather than continuous maps).  We say that the natural transformation is deterministically continuous (resp. weakly continuous ) if all the probability kernels N^(V) are deterministically continuous (resp. weakly continuous).

An exchangeable Z-recipe on a contravariant functor Z is a natural transformation μ: → Z from the trivial functor to Z, or equivalently an assignment of a probability measure μ^(V)∈(Z^(V)) to every vertex set V, such that one has the exchangeability property

    Z^(ϕ)∘μ^(V) = μ^(W)

for all morphisms ϕ∈(W,V) between two vertex sets.  If S is a vertex set, we define the exchangeable Z^⊎ S-recipe μ^⊎ S: → Z^⊎ S by the formula (μ^⊎ S)^(V) := μ^(V ⊎ S).
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Colouring as a natural transformation]  Let Z = (Z_j)_j=0^∞ be a sub-Cantor palette.  A colouring α: Z → A of Z is a tuple α = (α_j)_j=0^∞ of continuous[Informally, this means that the colour assigned to any point in Z depends only on “finitely many coordinates” of that point.] maps α_j: Z_j → A_j, where A = (A_j)_j=0^∞ is a finite palette.  Each individual map α_j can be interpreted as a deterministically continuous natural transformation α_j: Z_j → A_j defined by the formula

    α_j^(V)( (z(ϕ))_ϕ∈([j],V) ) := ( α_j(z(ϕ)))_ϕ∈([j],V)

and then the entire colouring can be viewed as a deterministically continuous natural transformation α: Z → A by

    α^(V)( (z_j)_j=0^∞ ) := ( α_j^(V)(z_j) )_j=0^∞.

One easily verifies that α_j and α are indeed deterministically continuous natural transformations.  We say that a colouring α: Z → A refines or is finer than another κ: Z → K if we have κ = σ∘α for some colouring σ: A → K.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: [Direct sum of natural transformations] If Y_1 and Y_2 are contravariant functors, we define the Cartesian product Y_1 × Y_2 to be the contravariant functor defined by (Y_1 × Y_2)^(V) :=Y_1^(V)× Y_2^(V) for all vertex sets V, and (Y_1 × Y_2)^(ϕ)(y_1,y_2) := (Y_1^(ϕ)(y_1), Y_2^(ϕ)(y_2)) for all morphisms ϕ∈(W,V) and points y_1 ∈ Y_1^(V), y_2 ∈ Y_2^(V); one easily verifies that Y_1 × Y_2 is indeed a contravariant functor.  If N_1: Z_1 → Y_1 and N_2: Z_2 → Y_2 are natural transformations, we define the direct sum N_1 ⊕ N_2: Z_1 × Z_2 → Y_1 × Y_2 to be the natural transformation defined by (N_1 ⊕ N_2)^(V)(z_1,z_2) = (N_1^(V)(z_1), N_2^(V)(z_2)) for all vertex sets V and points z_1 ∈ Z_1^(V) and z_2 ∈ Z_2^(V); one easily verifies that N_1 ⊕ N_2 is indeed a natural transformation.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: [Vague convergence of recipes]  Let Z be a sub-Cantor palette, let μ_n: → Z be a sequence of exchangeable Z-recipes, and let μ: → Z be another exchangeable Z-recipe.  We say that μ_n converges vaguely to μ if μ_n^(V) converges vaguely to μ^(V) for every vertex set V (see Appendix <ref> for a definition of vague convergence of measures).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Independence]  Let X be a sub-Cantor space with a probability measure μ∈(X), and let π_α: X → Y_α, α∈ A be a collection of measurable maps to other sub-Cantor spaces Y_α.  We say that the maps π_α are jointly independent relative to μ if we have

    ∫_X (∏_α∈ A' f_α∘π_α) dμ = ∏_α∈ A'∫_X f_α∘π_α dμ

for all finite subsets A' of A and all bounded measurable functions f_α: Y_α→.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: [j-independence]  Let N: Z → Y be a natural transformation, and let j ≥ 0.  We say that N is j-independent if for every vertex set V and every z ∈ Z^(V), the restriction maps π_W: Y^(V)→ Y^(W) for W ∈Vj are jointly independent relative to the measure N^(V)(z) ∈(Y^(V)).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Regular exchangeable recipes]  Let Z be a sub-Cantor palette of some order k ≥ 0, and let μ: → Z be an exchangeable Z-recipe.  We say that μ is regular if there exists a factorisation

    μ = P_k ∘…∘ P_0

where for each 0 ≤ j ≤ k, P_j: Z_<j→ Z_≤ j is a j-independent natural transformation which partially inverts the projection natural transformation π_j: Z_≤ j→ Z_<j in the sense that π_j ∘ P_j = 𝕀_Z_<j.  (Here we identify Z with Z_≤ k in the obvious manner.)

sentence: [Entailment]  Let K be a finite palette, let  be a hereditary K-property, and let N: Z → K be a natural transformation from some contravariant functor Z.  We say that N almost entails  if we have N^(V)(z)(^(V)) = 1 for all vertex sets V and all z ∈ Z^(V).  We say that N entails  if N is deterministically continuous and almost entails .

sentence:
[Infinitary repairability and testability] Let K be a finite palette of some order k ≥ 0, and let  be a hereditary K-property.  We say that  is infinitarily testable with one-sided error (resp. infinitarily strongly locally repairable ) if given any sub-Cantor palette Z of order k, any colouring κ: Z → K, any regular exchangeable Z-recipe μ: → Z such that κ∘μ almost entails , and every ε > 0, there exists a weakly continuous (resp. deterministically continuous) natural transformation T: Z → K that almost entails (resp. entails)  and is close to κ in the sense that

    ∫_Z^([k]) T^([k])(z)( K^([k])\{κ^([k])(z)} ) dμ^([k])(z) < ε.

sentence:
[Invariant space, stabiliser, indistinguishability]  Let Y be a sub-Cantor palette, and V, W be vertex sets.


  * If G ≤(V,V) is a group, we define the G-invariant space (Y^(V))^G := { y ∈ Y^(V): Y^(ϕ)(y) = y  for all ϕ∈ G}; this is a compact subspace of Y^(V).

  * If y ∈ Y^(V), we define the stabiliser (y) := {ϕ∈(V,V): Y^(ϕ)(y) = y}; this is a subgroup of (V,V).

  * We say that two elements y ∈ Y^(V), y' ∈ Y^(W) are indistinguishable if there exists an invertible ϕ∈(V,W) such that Y^(ϕ)(y) = y' (in particular, this requires V and W to have equal cardinality), and distinguishable otherwise.

for all ϕ∈([k],V).

sentence: [Quadruples]  If V is a vertex set, G ≤(V,V), a_k ∈ A_=k^(V), and z_<k∈ Z_<k^(V), we say that (V,G,a_k,z_<k) is good if Q^(V)(z_<k)(C_V,G,a_k) > 0, and bad otherwise.  We define the probability measure ρ_V,G,a_k,z_<k∈( (Z_=k^(V))^G ) to equal the conditioned measure (Q^(V)(z_<k)|C_V,G,a_k) (as defined in Appendix <ref>) if (V,G,a_k,z_<k) is good, and δ_z_*^(V)(ϕ) otherwise.

sentence:
[Probability kernels]
Let X,Y be sub-Cantor spaces.  A probability kernel from Y to X is a measurable function P: Y →(X) from Y to (X). We will use the notation P:Y ⇝ X to denote the fact that P is a probability kerne from Y to X.  If y ∈ Y and f: X → is measurable, we use ∫_X f(x) P(y, dx) to denote the integral of f against the measure P(y) ∈(X).  We call a probability kernel P: Y ⇝ X trivial if X is a point.

plain_text_term: probability kernel from Y to X;trivial

sentence:
[Composition of kernels] If P: Y ⇝ X and Q:Z
⇝ Y are probability kernels between sub-Cantor spaces, we define composition
P∘ Q: Z⇝ X by the formula
by

    P∘ Q(z)(E) := ∫_YP(y)(E) Q(z,d y)

for all z ∈ Z and all measurable E ⊂ X.

sentence: [Absolute continuity]  If μ, ν∈(X) are two probability measures on a sub-Cantor space, we say that μ is absolutely continuous with respect to ν , and write μ≪ν, if for every measurable E ⊂ X we have μ(E)=0 whenever ν(E)=0.  If P, P': Y ⇝ X are probability kernels, we say that P' is absolutely continuous with respect to P , and write P' ≪ P, if we have P'(y) ≪ P(y) for all y ∈ Y.

sentence:
A formula φ(x;y_0,…,y_n-1) has the n-independence property , or _n (with respect to a theory T), if in some model there is a sequence (a_0,i,…,a_n-1,i)_i∈ω
such that for every s⊆ω^n there is b_s such
that 

    ϕ(b_s;a_0,i_0,…,a_n-1,i_n-1)⇔(i_0,…,i_n-1)∈ s

Here x,y_0, …, y_n-1 are possibly tuples of variables.
Otherwise we say that φ(x,y_0,…,y_n-1) is n-dependent, or 
_n.
A theory is n-dependent , or _n, if it implies that every formula is
n-dependent.

sentence:
[Vapnik and Chervonenkis]A subset A⊆ X is said to be shattered by  if ∩ A =(A). The VC-dimension of  is defined as 

    ()=sup{|A|:A⊆ X },
 and the shatter function of  is defined as 
    π_(m):=max{|∩ A|: A⊆ X, |A|=m}.
 Observe that 0≤π_(m)≤ 2^m, and π_(m)=2^m if and only if m ≤().

sentence:
Let T be a theory in the language L, and let  be a monster
model of T.


  * Let I be a structure in the language L_0.
We say that a̅=(a_i)_i∈ I
with a_i∈ is an I-indiscernible if for
all n∈ω and all i_0,…,i_n and j_0,…,j_n
from I we have:

    _L_0(i_0, …, i_n)=_L_0(j_0,…,j_n)
    ⇒_L(a_i_0, …, a_i_n)=_L(a_j_0, …, a_j_n)
    .

An I-indiscernible (a_i)_i∈ I is also called an L_0-indiscernible to clarify the structure on I. 
(So, for L_1⊆ L_0, (a_i)_i∈ I is said to be L_1-indiscernible if it is (I|L_1)-indiscernible.)

  * For L_0-structures I and J, we say that (b_i)_i∈ J
is based on (a_i)_i∈ I if for any finite
set Δ of L-formulas,  and for any finite tuple (j_0,…,j_n)
from J there is a tuple (i_0,…,i_n) from
I such that:




  * _L_0(j_0,…,j_n)=_L_0(i_0,…,i_n) and

  * _Δ(b_j_0,…,b_j_n)=_Δ(a_i_0,…,a_i_n).


  * Let I be a structure in the language L_0. We say that I has the modeling property if given any a̅=(a_i)_i∈ I
there exists an L_0-indiscernible b̅=(b_i)_i∈ I
based on a̅.

sentence:
(Nakamura)
A subset Γ of monomials in [x,y,z] is called a
G-set if


  * it contains the constant monomial 1,

  * if vw ∈Γ then v ∈Γ and w ∈Γ ,

  * the restriction of the function  to Γ is a bijection.

sentence:
(Nakamura)
A monomial x^m y^n (resp. x^m z^n) for m,n≥ 0 is called a
y-valley (resp. z-valley ) for Γ, if

    x^m y^n,x^m+1 y^n,x^m y^n+1∈Γ     x^m+1 y^n+1∉Γ


    (resp.  x^m z^n,x^m+1 z^n,x^m z^n+1∈Γ  but  x^m+1
    z^n+1∉Γ).
 We call a y-valley or z-valley a valley
for brevity.

sentence:
Let Γ be a  with 0 or 1 valley and let τ be the
2-dimensional face of σ(Γ). The G-igsaw
transformation of Γ in the direction of τ is called
upper (resp. right, left) transformation if u=α (resp.
u=β,u=γ.), where the monomial u is as in
Lemma (<ref>). The upper, left and right
transformations of Γ will be denoted by , and
, respectively.

By slight abuse of notation, the G-igsaw transformation of 
Γ with 2 valleys is called left (resp. upper left,
right, left) transformation if the corresponding monomial u is
equal to β (resp. γ,δ_y,δ_z). The right,
left, upper right and upper left G-igsaw transformations of
Γ will be denoted by ,,,, respectively.





We say that a  Γ is spanned by monomials
u_1,…,u_n if Γ consists of all monomials dividing
u_1,…,u_n. If  Γ is spanned by monomials
u_1,…,u_n we write

    Γ= (u_1,…,u_n).

sentence:
Let Γ be a  with two valleys, spanned by x^i y^j_y, x^i z^k_z,
x^i_yy^j, x^i_zz^k. The set

    Θ(Γ)={^m(^n(Γ)) |  m+n≤min{j,k,j-j_y,k-k_z}}

will be called triangle of transformations of Γ.

sentence:
A  Γ is called primitive if it has a y-valley
equal to x^i_y and a z-valley equal to x^i_z for some
nonnegative i_y,i_z.

in (<ref>). Denote by ρ_n the common
ray of the cones (Γ_n) and σ(Γ_n).

Let Γ be any . A ray of σ^∨(Γ) will be
called upper,(upper) left or right ray if it dual to the wall
of σ(Γ) corresponding to the upper,(upper) left or right
transformation, respectively.

sentence:
Let G be a graph and 𝐅 a field.


  * A function f:V(G) →𝐅 is said to be a weighting of G. If the sum of all weights is constant for all maximal independents sets of G, then the weighting is a well-covered weighting of G. 

  * The 𝐅-vector space consisting of all well-covered weightings of G is called the well-covered space of G (relative to 𝐅). 

  * The dimension of this vector space is called the well-covered dimension of G, denoted wcdim(G, 𝐅).

sentence: Given a configuration, 𝒞, we define the Levi graph of 𝒞, denoted Levi_𝒞, as the bipartite graph with vertices given by the points and lines in 𝒞. The edges of Levi_𝒞 connect a point-vertex P with a line-vertex ℓ if and only if the point P is incident with the line ℓ in 𝒞. No other edges exist in Levi_𝒞.

sentence:
Let M be an oriented matroid on a linearly ordered set E.

Following <cit.>, we denote



    O(M)     =   { min(C)|C positive circuit of M }, 
    
    O^*(M)     =   { min(C)|C positive cocircuit of M }.


The sets O(M) and O^*(M) are respectively known as the sets of active and dual-active elements of M.
The parameters | O(M) | and | O^*(M) | are respectively known as the (orientation) activity and dual (orientation) activity  of M.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let M N be an oriented matroid perspective on a linearly ordered set E
with




    O(M)     =   {g_1, …, g_}_<, 
    
    O^*(N)     =   {h_1, …, h_}_<.


We define G_=∅ and, for  0≤ k≤-1, we define

    G_k = ⋃_ C  positive circuit of  M
    min(C) ≥ g_k+1C.

We define H_=E and, for  0≤ k≤-1, we define

    H_k = E  ⋃_ C  positive cocircuit of  N
    min(C) ≥ h_k+1C.




Observe that G_0 is the union of positive circuits of M (i.e. the maximal positive vector of M), E G_0 is the union of positive cocircuits of M (i.e. the maximal positive covector of M), H_0 is the union of positive circuits of N (i.e. the maximal positive vector of N), and E H_0 is the union of positive cocircuits of N (i.e. the maximal positive covector of N).

Hence, by definition of an oriented matroid perspective, we have

    G_0 ⊆ H_0.


Observe that we can have G_0= H_0, e.g. when M=N, and that we can also have ∅=G_0⊂ H_0=E, when M is acyclic and N totally cyclic, as for the reorientations mentioned above counted by t(M,N;0,0,1).



We call active filtration of M N the sequence of nested  subsets

    ∅=G_ ⊂ … ⊂  G_1 ⊂  G_0 ⊆  H_0 ⊂   H_1 ⊂ … ⊂  H_ = E.


And we call active partition of M N the partition of E given by

    E =  (G_-1 G_) ⊎ … ⊎ (G_0 G_1) ⊎ (H_0 G_0) ⊎ (H_1 H_0) ⊎ … ⊎ (H_ H_-1).


The parts contained in G_0 are called the cyclic parts , 
the parts contained in E H_0 are called the acyclic parts , 
and the part H_0 G_0 (possibly empty) is called the hybrid part .
We assume that the active filtration and active partition are always given along with the sets G_0 and H_0 (hence one can deduce the active filtration from the active partition and vice versa).

sentence:
Let M N be an oriented matroid perspective on a linearly ordered set E.

We define the activity class of M N as the set of 
its reorientations -_AM -_AN 
where 
A is any union of 
cyclic or acyclic parts of its active partition. 







Observe that we forbid reorienting the hybrid part
[This is done in order to distinguish reorientations from their complementaries when the hybrid part is non-empty. This yields tighter classes, closer to Tutte polynomial properties, and meaningful notably in the proof of Theorem <ref>.]
.


By Proposition <ref> and 
extending this definition to all reorientations of  M N,
we define activity classes of reorientations of M N , that partition the set of reorientations of M N, and can be seen as classes of the equivalence relation defined by reorienting parts of the active partition.

sentence:
Let  be an oriented matroid on a linearly ordered set E and A⊆ E.
The reorientation -_AM of M is called active-fixed if no active element of -_AM is reoriented w.r.t. M, that is if Θ̅_(A)=O(-_A)∩ A=∅.
It is called dual-active-fixed if no dual-active element of -_AM is reoriented w.r.t. M, that is if Θ̅^*_(A)=O^*(-_A)∩ A=∅.

For an oriented matroid perspective M N on a linearly ordered set E and A⊆ E, by extension of the terminology,
the reorientation -_AM -_AN will be called active-fixed if -_AM is active-fixed (w.r.t. M)
and dual-active-fixed if -_AN is dual active fixed (w.r.t. N).

sentence:
A power ideal is an ideal in the polynomial ring 
[V] generated by a collection of powers of homogeneous linear 
forms such that these linear forms span V; i.e. , an ideal of the form 
< h_i^r_i: i ∈ I> where I is some indexing set, the h_is are linear forms which span V, and the r_is are non-negative integers.

sentence:
The inverse system of a homogeneous ideal I ∈[V] is its orthogonal complement with respect to this pairing, which is easily seen to be

    I^⊥ := {g()∈[V^*] | f(∂/∂)· g() = 0 .
    
     for any  f()∈ I}.

The inverse system of the power ideal I(ρ) is called the power inverse system C(ρ) = I(ρ)^⊥.

sentence: Given a polynomial f ∈[V^*], let the directional degree function of f be ρ_f:  V →, defined by letting ρ_f(h) be the degree of the restriction of f to a generic line parallel to h. For a set of polynomials S⊂[V^*] with finite dimensional linear span, define the degree-span ≪ S as the unique minimal space C(ρ) such that C(ρ) ⊇ S.

sentence:
The Tutte polynomial of a matroid M with ground set E and rank function r is defined by 

    T_M(x,y) = ∑_A ⊆ E (x-1)^r(M)-r(A)(y-1)^|A|-r(A).

sentence:
A function f:→ R from the class of finite matroids to a commutative ring R is said to be a generalized Tutte-Grothendieck invariant if there exist a,b,L,C ∈ R, with a and b invertible, such that the following properties hold.


  * If M and N are isomorphic matroids then f(M) = f(N).

  * If e is neither a loop nor a coloop of M, then f(M) = af(M\ e) + bf(M/e).

  * If e is a loop of M then f(M) = Lf(M\ e).

  * If e is a coloop of M then f(M) = Cf(M/e).

  * f(∅) = 1.

A function f:→ R is said to be a weak generalized Tutte-Grothendieck invariant if it satisfies conditions 1 and 2 above.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: generalized Tutte-Grothendieck invariant;weak generalized Tutte-Grothendieck invariant

sentence: Let P be a prime 3-edge-connected alternating tangle diagram. Then there exists a constant c > 0 so that all but exponentially few prime alternating knot types K have a minimal alternating diagram which contains at least cn instances of P. Furthermore, every minimal diagram for such an alternating knot type contains at least cn copies of P or its reflections.

Given two k-uniform hypergraphs on the vertex set [n] E_1 and E_2,

(i) E_1 dominates E_2 if the matrix C_E_1,E_2(X), whose rows and columns correspond
to sets in E_2 and E_1 respectively,
has rank |E_2|.

(ii) E_1 and E_2 are weakly isomorphic if each dominates the other.

( Kotzig's theorem ) All the Euler systems of a 4-regular multigraph
can be obtained from any one by applying finite sequences of κ-transformations.

sentence:
A square matrix S=(s_ij) with entries in GF(2) is symmetric if
s_ij=s_ji for all i≠ j. S is zero-diagonal if s_ii=0
for all i.

sentence:
The interlacement graph of a 4-regular graph F with respect to
an Euler system C is the simple graph ℐ(F,C) with
V(ℐ(F,C))=V(F) and E(ℐ(F,C))={vw


|

v and w are interlaced with respect to C}. The interlacement
matrix of F with respect to C is the adjacency matrix of this graph; when
no confusion can arise, we use ℐ(C) to denote both the graph and
the matrix.

sentence:
Let P be a circuit partition of the 4-regular multigraph F,
and let C be an Euler system of F. For each circuit γ∈ P, let the
relative core vector of γ with respect to C be the vector
ρ(γ,C)∈ GF(2)^V(F) whose nonzero entries correspond to the
vertices of F at which P involves either the χ or the ψ
transition, and γ is singly incident. (A circuit γ is
singly incident at v if γ includes precisely two of the four
half-edges at v.)

sentence:
Let P be a d-dimensional polyhedron and let F be a facet of P. A wedge on P over F is a (d+1)-dimensional polyhedron P'=H^≤∩ (P × L), where P × L denotes the product of P with L=[0,∞) and H^≤⊂^d+1 is a closed halfspace 
with P×{0}⊂ H^≤ that is defined by a hyperplane H that intersects the interior of P× L and satisfies

sentence:

sentence:
A prismatoid is a polytope Q with two parallel facets Q^+ and Q^-, that we call the bases , containing all the vertices. We call a prismatoid simplicial if all faces except perhaps Q^+ and Q^- are simplices. Observe that the faces of a prismatoid of dimension d, excluding the two bases, form a simplicial complex of dimension d-1 and homeomorphic to the product of 𝕊^d-2 with a segment. We call this complex the prismatoid complex of Q.

The width of a prismatoid is the distance from one base to the other, measured in the adjacency graph.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A ((d-1)-dimensional) topological prismatoid  is a (d-1)-dimensional pure simplicial complex homeomorphic to 𝕊_d-2× [0,1] (that is, it is homeomorphic to a cylinder), and such that every face with all its vertices in the same boundary component is a boundary face. Put differently, the two boundary components, each homeomorphic to 𝕊_d-2, are induced subcomplexes.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A  flip in a topological prismatoid  is a triple (f,l,v) of pairwise disjoint
subsets of  V(𝒞) such that f is a face, l is a minimal nonface, _(f)=∂(l)*v, v is either the empty face  or a vertex, and one of the following two things happens:

  
  * |f|+|l|=d+1 and v=∅, in which case l is required to intersect both bases of . (Observe that in this case _(f)=∂(l)*v=∂(l)).
  
  * |f|+|l|=d and v is a vertex, in which case f and l are required to be contained in the base opposite to v.

In both cases, the result of the flip is the prismatoid

    𝒞' = ∖_(f) ∪ (l * ∂(f) * v).

flips with v=∅ are called interior flips and flips where v is a vertex are called  boundary flips . The support of the flip is f∪ l ∪ v.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let  be a topological prismatoid with bases B^+ and B^-.
The incidence pattern of   is the bipartite directed graph having a node for each vertex of  with bipartition given by the bases and with the following arcs: for each v∈ B^+ and w∈ B^- we have an arc v→ w (resp., w→ v) if there is a facet F in  containing vw and incident to B^+ (resp., incident to B^-). 

The reduced incidence pattern is the subgraph induced by vertices that are not sources.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(Szemerédi, Trotter) Let 𝒫 be a finite set of points in ^2 and 𝔏 a finite set of lines in ^2. Then, if I(𝒫,𝔏) denotes the number of incidences between 𝒫 and 𝔏, it holds that

    I(𝒫,𝔏)≲ |𝒫|^2/3|𝔏|^2/3+|𝔏|+|𝒫|.

In particular, for any k ≥ 2, if 𝒫^k denotes the set of points in 𝒫 each lying in at least k and fewer than 2k lines of 𝔏, then

    |𝒫^k|≲|𝔏|^2/k^3+|𝔏|/k.
word_labels: B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: (Bézout)  Let γ be an irreducible real algebraic curve in ^n, of degree at most b. Let p∈[x_1,…,x_n] be a non-zero polynomial such that γ does not lie in the zero set of p in ^n. Then, γ intersects the zero set of p ≲_n,b p times.
word_labels: B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let 𝔏_1, … , 𝔏_n be finite collections of lines in 𝔽^n. We say that a point x ∈𝔽^n is a multijoint formed by the n collections of lines if, for each i=1,…, n, there exists a line l_i ∈𝔏_i passing though x, so that the directions of l_1, …, l_n span 𝔽^n. We denote by J(𝔏_1,…,𝔏_n) the set of multijoints formed by 𝔏_1,…,𝔏_n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that a point x ∈𝔽^n is a generic joint formed by a finite collection 𝔏 of lines in 𝔽^n if, whenever n lines in 𝔏 pass through x, they form a joint there. For all k ≥ n, we denote by J^k(𝔏) the set of generic joints formed by a finite collection 𝔏 of lines in 𝔽^n, each of which lies in at least k and fewer than 2k lines of 𝔏.

sentence:
Let Γ be a finite collection of sets in ℱ_n. A point x in ^n is a joint formed by Γ if there exist v_1,…,v_n ∈ T_x^Γ such that {v_1,…,v_n} spans ^n.

A point x ∈^n is a generic joint formed by Γ if any n vectors in T_x^Γ span ^n.

For eack k ≥ n, we denote by J^k(Γ) the set of generic joints x formed by Γ, such that |T_x^Γ|∈ [k,2k).

sentence:
Let Γ_1, ..., Γ_n be finite collections of sets in ℱ_n. A point x in ^n is a multijoint formed by these collections if, for all i=1,…,n, x belongs to some γ_i ∈Γ_i, with the property that there exists at least one vector v_i in T_x^{γ_i}, such that {v_1,...,v_n} spans ^n.

We denote by J(Γ_1,...,Γ_n) the set of multijoints formed by Γ_1, ..., Γ_n.

sentence:
Suppose X is a simplicial complex, the star St(σ) of a
     simplex σ in X is the subcomplex consisting of all the simplices of
     X that contain σ. The link lk(σ) of
     σ is the subcomplex consisting of all the simplices σ' of
     X with σ'∩σ = ∅ and σ' * σ being a simplex in X.
     A simplicial complex is called an n-dimensional
     closed combinatorial manifold if the link
   of each vertex of the complex is an (n - 1)-dimensional PL sphere.

sentence:
Let M^n be a combinatorial n-manifold and σ∈
        M^n a (n-i)-simplex (0≤ i ≤ n) such that its link
        in M^n is the boundary ∂τ of an
        i-simplex τ that is not a face of M^n. Then the
        operation
        
    T^n,i_σ,τ (M^n) := (M^n \ (σ * ∂τ)) ∪ (∂σ
            * τ)

         is called a n-dimensional bistellar i-move (or Pachner move).
         Bistellar i-moves with i≥ [n/2] is also
         called reverse bistellar (n-i)-move ..2cm

sentence:
Let (𝒩_1, w_1) and (𝒩_2, w_2) be balanced fans and suppose that 𝒩_1 refines 𝒩_2. 


  * We call 𝒩_2 a strict balanced coarsening of 𝒩_1 if w_1-w_2^↑≥ 0 with strict inequality for at least one n-1 cone. In this case we write 𝒩_2≻_b 𝒩_1.

  * We call (𝒩_2, w_2) a minimal balanced coarsening if there does not exist another strict balanced coarsening (𝒩', w') of 𝒩_1 such that w_1, w_2≠ w' up to multiplication by a constant and 𝒩_2≻_b 𝒩'≻_b 𝒩_1.

sentence:

    w_g^↑(σ)   :=0    if there does not exist σ'∈(g)_n-1 s.t σ⊂σ'
    
    
    w_g^↑(σ)   :=w(σ')    if there is a σ'∈(g)_n-1 s.t σ⊂σ'

for all σ∈(f)_n-1.

sentence:
[Minimal and Maximal Summands]
Let P be a lattice polytope and R a Minkowski summand. We call R a (Minkowski) minimal summand if it is indecomposable. We call R' a (Minkowski) maximal summand if P=R'+R and R is a minimal summand.

sentence: A lattice polytope in ^n+1 such that each edge is parallel to some vector e_i-e_j for i≠ j is called a Generalized Permutahedron .

sentence:
The unweighted fan 
    :=  ⋀_I⊂ [n+1]
    |I|=2𝒩(_I)/· (1, …, 1) ⊂^n
 is called the type A_n universal fan .

sentence: Let I⊂ [n+1] and π∈Π_[n+1]. We say that π restricts to Π_I, if the ordered partition π|_I obtained by deleting the coordinates which contain elements that are not in I, is an element of Π_I.

sentence: [Φ-Polytope] A polytope P⊂^n whose edges are parallel to roots in Φ will be called a Coxeter Polytope or a Φ-Polytope .

sentence:
Let T ⊂𝒯_d be a non-empty balanced subregion. Then we define the perfect matching sign
    of a lozenge tiling τ of T as τ := π, where π∈_#(T) is the perfect
    matching determined by τ.

sentence:
Let T ⊂𝒯_d be a non-empty balanced subregion as above, and let τ be a lozenge tiling of T.
    Then we define the lattice path sign of τ as τ := λ, where λ∈_m is
    the permutation such that, for each i, the lattice path determined by τ that starts at A_i ends at E_λ (i).

sentence: Two blocks of a partition of the set [m]:={1,…,m} cross each other if one block contains {a,c} and the other block contains {b,d} where a<b<c<d. A partition of [m] is called a non-crossing partition if no two blocks cross each other.

sentence:
Let us say that a Schröder tree is left directed is the rightmost subtree of each internal node is a leaf.
Let LDST denote the set of such trees.
Then,

    h = ∑_t∈ LDSTS^t.

sentence:
An ideal I is differentially perfect if for all s and r, one has 
    (I^{r})^(s)=I^{r+s-1}+∑_i=1^s-1(I^{r})^(i)(I^{r})^(s-i).

sentence:
Let δ be a monomial and P an ideal. We define the function 
    O_P(δ)=max{k: δ∈ P^k}.

If monomial δ_1=x_i_1⋯ x_i_s is the maximum of the c-chains which divide δ then the c-chain i=i_1,…,i_s is called the c-socle of δ, denoted by Soc_c(δ). We set supp(δ)={i:  x_i|δ}. By the maximality of δ_1, we have supp(δ)⊆ F_Soc_c(δ)={i_1,i_1+1,…,i_1+c,i_2,i_2+1,…,i_2+c,…,i_s,i_s+1,…,i_s+c}.

Let i=i_1,…,i_h and j=j_1,…,j_k with h>k. We define 
    r_i(j)=|{i_1,…,i_h}∩ F_j|.

sentence:
Let a=a_1,…,a_s be a c-chain. We define L(a) to be the union of closed intervals [a_i-c,a_i] for all i=2,…,s.

Let a=a_1,…,a_s and b=b_1,…,b_r be two c-chains with x_a>_τ x_b. The pair (a,b) is called quasi-sorted if  a_i≤ b_i for all i=1,…,r and either b_i≤ a_i+1 for all i=1,…,r or b_i≤ a_i+1   for all i=1,…,k-1 and b_k>a_k+1 and b_k,…,b_r∈ L(a). If b_i≤ a_i+1 for all i=1,…,r then (a,b) is called sorted .

More generally, let a^(1),…,a^(k) be c-chains with a^(i)=a^(i)_1,…,a^(i)_n_i such that x_a^(i)>_τx_a^(i+1). The set (a^(1),…,a^(k)) is called sorted if a^(t)_i≤ a^(s)_i for all t≤ s and a^(t)_i≤ a^(t')_i+1 for all t'<t. The set (a^(1),…,a^(k)) is called quasi-sorted if it is either sorted or a^(t)_i≤ a^(s)_i for all t≤ s  and if a^(t)_i> a^(t')_i+1 for some t'<t then a^(t)_i,a^(t)_i+1,…,a^(t)_n_i∈ L(a^(t')). We call the table A=(a^(i)_j) quasi-sorted form for short.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let X be a set and , called the atlas of X,  be a collection of injective charts f:↪ X.
For each f in , we call the images f()   apartments and define Weyl chambers, Weyl  simplices, hyperplanes, half-apartments, etc. of X to be images of such in  under any f in . The pair (X,) is a (generalized) affine building (or Λ-building) if the following conditions are satisfied


  (A1) The atlas is invariant under pre-composition with elements of  .

  (A2) Given two charts f,g∈ with f()∩ g()≠∅. Then f^-1(g()) is a closed convex subset of  and there exists w∈ with f|_f^-1(g()) = (g∘ w )|_f^-1(g()).

  (A3) For any pair of points  in X there is an apartment containing both.

Given a Λ-metric d_ on the model space,  axioms (A1)–(A3) imply the existence of a Λ-valued distance function on X, that is a function d:X× X↦Λ satisfying all conditions of the definition of a Λ-metric but the triangle inequality.  The distance between points x,y in X is the distance between their pre-images under a chart f of an apartment containing both.


  (A4) Given two  Weyl chambers  in X there exist sub-Weyl chambers of both which are contained in a common apartment. 

  (A5) For any apartment A and all x∈ A there exists a retraction r_A,x:X→ A such that r_A,x does not increase distances and r^-1_A,x(x)={x}.

  (A6) Let f, g and h be charts such that the associated apartments pairwise intersect in half-apartments. Then f()∩ g()∩ h()≠∅. 

By (A5) the distance function d on X is well defined and satisfies the triangle inequality.

sentence:
vertex retraction
Let μ be a germ of a Weyl chamber and y a point in X, then, by (ALA),  there exists a chart g∈ such that y and μ are contained in g(). 
By axiom (A2) there exists w∈ such that g|_g^-1(f())=(f∘ w)|_g^-1(f()).
Hence we can define

    r_A,μ(y) = (f∘ w∘ g^-1 )(y).

The map r_A,μ is called retraction onto A centered at μ .

sentence: Given a graph G=(V,E) and a weight function w on V, we say that G is (r,w)-connected if the removal of a set of vertices having sum of their weights at most r-1 does not disconnect G.

sentence:
Given a word w=w_1… w_k∈ and a set
  ={[o_1,c_1],…,[o_k,c_k]} with 1≤ o_i<c_i≤ m for
  every i∈[k] and o_1<o_2<…<o_k, we say that the pair
  P=(w,) is a valid pair if


  * w_o_i>w_c_i for every i∈[k];

  * c_1<c_2<…<c_k.

An A-parking function is a function f A→[m] for
which

    ∀_j∈[m] , |f^-1([j])|≥ j .

We denote by  the set of A-parking functions.  Of course, for
f A→[m], f∈ if and only if f∘ι_A is a
parking function, where ι_A[m]→ A is such that
ι_A(i)=a_i.  A particular case occurs when

    ∀_j∈[m] , f(a_j)≤ j .

In this case, we say that f is A-central . We denote by
 the set of A-central parking functions.  We call
contraction of w to the new function w A→[m]
such that

    w(a):=w^-1(a)-|{b∈ A| b>a ,  w^-1(b)<w^-1(a) }| .

Note that indeed w∈, since
w(a)=|w([w^-1(a)])∩[a]|.

sentence:
Let again A=:{a_1,…,a_m} with a_1<…<a_m and
  f:A→[m]. For every i∈[m], define the set
  A_i:={a_1,…,a_i}, and define recursively the bijection
  w^i A_i →[i] as follows.
 
 
  * w^1:a_1↦ 1 (necessarily);
 
  * for 1<j≤ i≤ m,
   
   
  * if j<i, w^i(a_j)=
       w^i-1(a_j),    if w^i-1(a_j)<f(a_i)

       1+w^i-1(a_j),   if w^i-1(a_j)≥ f(a_i)
   
  * w^i(a_i)=f(a_i);
   
 
 Finally, let ψ:[m]→ A be the inverse of w^m:A→[m].  We
 call S(f):=ψ (viewed as the word ψ(1)…ψ(m)) the s-parking of f .

sentence:
An ℓ-partition is an ℓ-regular partition which


  * Has no non-horizontal ℓ-rim hooks.

  * After removing any number of horizontal ℓ-rim hooks, the remaining diagram has no non-horizontal ℓ-rim hooks.

sentence:
For a positive integer n,
a colorful n-periodic sequence
is a function f:/n→_3 defined on the set of integers modulo n, such that  f(i) f(i+1) for all i∈/n. 
The set of colorful n-periodic sequences is denoted by 𝒜_n.

The degree vector or degree statistics of a graph G on n vertices is the column vector

    𝐝_ G:= (d_0, d_1, …, d_n-1 )^T

where d_i is the number of vertices of degree i in G.

[Linear quotients]
A monomial ideal I⊂[x_1,… ,x_n] is said to have linear quotients if there is an ordering m_1,… ,m_q on the minimal monomial generators of I such that for every i=2,… ,q the ideal (m_1,… ,m_i-1):m_i is generated by a subset of {x_1,… ,x_n}.

sentence:
Let (P,Q,R) be a weak projective triple in ^d, seen as a canonical subspace of ^d+1. Let H denote the wedge hyperplane in ^d spanned by points of R with H∩ P=∅. Let v denote any point not in ^d, and let H denote any hyperplane in ^d+1 such that H∩^d=H and H separates v from P. Consider, for every vertex p of P, the point p^ v={ v,  p}∩H. Denote by P^ v the pyramid

    P^ v:=(  v∪⋃_ p∈_0(P)p^ v).

 The PP configuration (P^v,Q ∪ R) in ^d+1 is a subdirect cone of (P,Q,R).

sentence: Let  be a sequence of real numbers.  We construct the panorama sequence () of  in the following manner.  Suppose the maximum value of  occurs in positions i_1, i_2, …, i_j.  Begin () with the sequence of views (v_i_1, v_i_2, …, v_i_j).  Now continue this process with the next highest value in , concatenating the corresponding view values onto the right end of ().  Repeat this process until the view of every element of  has been added to ().

sentence: A restricted growth function (RGF) is a sequence  of non-negative integers such that each j>0 that appears in  is preceded by an appearance of j-1. Equivalently, for all j>0 that appear in , the first appearance of j is preceded by an appearance of every i satisfying 0 ≤ i < j.

sentence: An SE-pair of a matrix M ∈ is a pair of non-zero entries m_ij and m_i'j' such that i < i', j<j' and i' ≤ j.  We say that M is SE-free if it contains no SE-pair.

sentence:
* The (tropical) permanent of a matrix A∈^ is
defined by:
  
  
    (A) = ⋁_σ∈𝔖_n    A_1σ(1) +
     ⋯ +  A_nσ(n),


where 𝔖_n is the set of all the permutations on {1,…,
  n}.
 
  * A matrix A ∈^ is called (tropically) singular
if A=(-∞)∈^1× 1 or if there exist at least two different permutations that reach
the maximum in (A), that is,

    (A)  =  ∑_i A_iσ(i) = ∑_i A_iτ(i) ,

for some  σ≠τ in 𝔖_n.
Otherwise A is called (tropically) non-singular .

If A is non-singular, we denote by τ_A the unique permutation that
reaches the maximum in (<ref>).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:

    (λ⊙ ) ∨
    (μ⊙ ) = ( (λ,… , λ) + ) ∨(
    (μ, …, μ) + )  ∈  X  .

 
  * The tropically convex set generated by a finite family  of vectors
of ^n, that is the set

    { ∈^n |∃ (_ s)_ s∈, _ s∈,    =
    ⋁_ s∈ ( _ s⊙ s )  } ,

is called the (tropical) convex hull of .

For A ∈^n × n, if λ∈ and ∈^n
∖{(-∞)} are such that:

    A⊙=λ⊙ u  ,

then λ is called a (tropical) eigenvalue and u is
a (tropical) eigenvector associated to λ.
The set of such eigenvectors is the (tropical) eigenspace associated to λ.

sentence:
Given posets P_1,…,P_k, the Boolean Ramsey number
 R(P_1,…,P_k) is the minimum integer n such that
for any k-coloring on ℬ_n, it always contains a monochromatic P_i of color i for some i.
Moreover, if P_i=P for all 1≤ i≤ k, then we use R_k(P) to denote R(P_1,…,P_k).

sentence:
Given two collections of posets 𝒫={P_1,…,P_r} and 𝒬={Q_1,…,Q_s},
the Boolean rainbow Ramsey number RR(𝒫,𝒬) is the minimum integer n such that
for any coloring c on _n, it always contains some monochromatic P_i
or some rainbow Q_j.
If 𝒫={P} (resp. 𝒬={Q}), then we will simply use P (resp. Q) instead of {P} (resp. {Q}).

sentence:
A fringe subtree of a rooted tree is a subtree that consists of a vertex and all its descendants.
  An additive tree parameter is a functional F satisfying a recursion of the form
  
    F() = ∑_j=1^k F(^j) + f(),

  where  is some rooted tree, ^1, ^2, …, ^k are the branches of the root
  of , i.e., the fringe subtrees rooted at the children of the root of , and f is
  a so-called toll function .

sentence: Let T∈_k(λ).  The promotion (T) of T  is given by the following construction.  If T has no 1's then let (T) be the result of decrementing all the values of T by 1.  Otherwise, do the following.  First, delete all the boxes in T that contain a 1 and rectify the resulting skew tableau.  Next, decrement all the values by 1 and then place a k in all the empty boxes resulting from sliding (so that (T) has the same shape as T).

We define the evacuation (T) of T to be ϵ_k(T).

sentence:
[inverse, undirected, complement, oriented, transitive] 




  * The inverse of an edge (a,b) is the edge (a,b)^-1=(b,a).
The inverse of a graph G=(V,E) is the graph G^-1=(V,E^-1), where E^-1={(a,b)^-1| (a,b)∈ E}.

  * We say that a graph G=(V,E) is undirected iff E=E^-1.
The undirected closure of a graph G=(V,E) is the graph 𝒰(G)=(V,E^U), where E^U=E∪ E^-1.

  * The complement of G=(V,E) is the graph G=(V,V V∖ E^U), where V V={(a,b)| a,b∈ V, a≠ b}.

  * A graph G=(V,E) is oriented iff E∩ E^-1=∅.
A graph G'=(V,E') is an orientation of G=(V,E) iff E' is a maximal oriented subset of E.

  * A graph G=(V,E) is transitive iff for all edges (a,b),(b,c)∈ E with a≠ c we also have (a,c)∈ E.
The transitive closure of a graph G=(V,E) is G=(V,E), where E is the minimal transitive superset of E.

sentence:
In the game of m-Modular Nim , each position consists of a set of heaps of tokens, like in Nim. However, we have two types of moves:



  * Remove a positive number of tokens from a single heap.

  * Remove km tokens total where k is a positive integer.

sentence: Let the heap-sum of a position A be the total number of tokens. We denote it as |A|.

sentence:
If A = (a_1, a_2, a_3, …, a_k) and B = (b_1, b_2, b_3, …, b_k) are positions in m-Modular Nim such that a_i ≥ b_i for all integers 1 ≤ i ≤ k, we say that A dominates B. Position A strictly dominates B if A dominates B and A is not equal to B, that is, there exists i such that a_i > b_i. We denote domination as A ≽ B and strict domination as A ≻ B. 

Moreover if all members of set 𝒮 dominate all members of set 𝒯, we say that 𝒮 dominates 𝒯 or 𝒮≽𝒯. Similarly, if all members of 𝒮 strictly dominate all members of 𝒯, we say that 𝒮 strictly dominates 𝒯 or 𝒮≻𝒯.

of the unbarred entries that appear in T

    ⋯ read(T|_S_d)

is lattice.

sentence:
A set of points (p_1, p_2, …, p_n) in ℤ^2 is called a
staircase if the following two conditions are satisfied:


  * for each i with 1 ≤ i ≤ n-1 one of the points
p_i and p_i+1 is an element of F_1 \ F_2 and the
other is an element of F_2 \ F_1;

  * either for all i the points p_2i and p_2i+1 are in
the same column and the points p_2i+1 and p_2i+2 are in
the same row, or for all i the points p_2i and p_2i+1
are in the same row and the points p_2i+1 and p_2i+2 are
in the same column.

sentence:
Let T be a tetrahedron with vertices p_1, p_2, p_3, and p_4. Consider the points q_i= 1/2 (p_1+p_2+p_3+p_4) - p_i, i∈ [4], and let

    C(T)=(p_i,q_i: i∈[4]).
 
C(T) is a parallelepiped with facets (p_i, p_j, q_k, q_l) for all choices of {i,j,k,l}=[4]. We call it the parallelepiped circumscribed to T.

For each i ∈ [4], let T_i=(q_i, p_j, p_k, p_l), with {i,j,k,l}=[4]; we call these T_i the corner tetrahedra of C(T). Together with T they triangulate C(T).

sentence:
Let L be a finite lattice, and let Θ be an equivalence relation on L.
We say that Θ is a lattice congruence if it satisfies both of the following conditions for each x,y, and z in L.

    if x≡ y Θ then x z≡ y zΘ



    if x≡ y Θ then x z≡ y zΘ

We say that Θ is a meet (join) semilattice congruence if Θ satisfies <ref> (<ref>).

sentence:
The fundamental polytope of a metric space (X,ρ) is the convex polytope
 R_X,ρ obtained as the convex hull of all vectors e_x,y, where (x,y)
 run through all pairs of distinct points of X.
 The combinatorial type of R_X,ρ, i.e., the isomorphism class of the
 corresponding poset of faces,
 is called the combinatorial structure of the finite metric space (X,ρ).
 Two finite metric spaces with the same combinatorial structures called similar metric spaces .

sentence:
Two orbits Ω_1 and Ω_2 of a permutation group G≤(V)
  are linked if there is a group isomorphism σ G(Ω_1)→
  G(Ω_2) with
  G(Ω_1∪Ω_2)=[](ϕ,σ(ϕ))ϕ∈
    G(Ω_1). (This happens if and only if both
  G(Ω_1) and G(Ω_2) are isomorphic to G(Ω_1∪Ω_2).)

sentence:
A template for a k-colouring of K_n is a function 

    t:  E(K_n)→	2^[k]∖{∅},

 associating to each edge e of K_n a non-empty list of colours t(e)⊆ [k]; we refer to t(e) as the palette available at e.  We write (2^[k]∖{∅})^K_n for the family of all k-colouring templates of K_n.


Given a template t∈(2^[k]∖{∅})^K_n, we say that a k-colouring c∈[k]^K_n realises t if c(e)∈ t(e) for every edge e∈ E(K_n).  We write ⟨ t ⟩ for the collection of realisations of t and c∈⟨ t⟩  as a shorthand for `c is a realisation of t'.

sentence:
Let 𝒫 be an order-hereditary property of k-colourings of K_n. A family 𝒮 of k-colouring templates is said to be a stability family for 𝒫 if the following holds:

for all ε>0, there exist δ>0 and m, n_0∈ such that for all n≥ n_0, every 
t∈ (2^[k]∖{∅})^K_n with
	
		
  * (almost extremality) (t)≥ (π(𝒫)-δ)n2, and
		
  * (almost locally  in 𝒫) at most δnm pairs (ϕ, c) with ϕ∈K_nK_m, c∉𝒫_m  and c∈⟨ t_|_ϕ⟩ 
	
	must lie within edit distance at most εn2 of some template s∈𝒮.

If 𝒫 has a stability family, then it is said to be stable .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let m, n∈ with m≤ n. An order-preserving map from [m] to [n] is a function ϕ:  [m]→ [n] such that ϕ(i)≤ϕ(j) whenever i≤ j. Given e∈ [m]^(r), we write ϕ(e) for the set ϕ(e)={ϕ(v):  v∈ e}.



Given r-graphs G_1 on [m] and G_2 on [n], we say that G_2 contains G_1 as an ordered subgraph if there is an order-preserving isomorphism from G_1 to an m-vertex subgraph H of G_2. We further say that G_2 contains G_1 as an induced orderered subgraph if the m-vertex subgraph H in question is an induced subgraph of G_2.


An r-graph property 𝒫 is said to be order-hereditary if for every G∈𝒫_n and every order-preserving injection ϕ:  [m]→ [n], the graph G_|ϕ=([m], {e:  ϕ(e)∈ E(G)}) is a member of 𝒫_m.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For each r∈ and v∈{0,1}^r, let  ℋ(r,v) be the collection of all graphs G such that V(G) may be partitioned into r disjoint sets A_1, …, A_r such that for each i, G[A_i] is an empty graph if v_i=0 and a complete graph if v_i=1. The colouring number χ_c(𝒫) of a hereditary property is defined to be

    χ_c(𝒫):=sup{r∈  :  ℋ(r,v)⊆𝒫 for some v∈{0,1}^r}.
