sentence:
A directed graph
(or
digraph ) is a tuple G = (V, , t, h) where V and
 are sets—the vertex and 
directed edge sets—and t
→ V is the tail map and h → V is the head map . A directed edge e is called 
self-loop
if t(e) = h(e), that is, if its tail is its head.
Note that our definition also allows for multiple edges , that is
directed edges with identical tails and heads.  Unless
specifically mentioned, we will only consider directed graphs which have
finitely many vertices and directed edges.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An undirected graph (or simply a graph) is a
tuple G = (V, , t, h, ι) where (V, , t, h) is a
directed graph and where ι→, called
the opposite map
or involution of the graph,
is an involution on the set of directed edges
(that is, ι^2=𝕀_ is the identity) satisfying t ι
= h. The directed graph G = (V, , t, h) is called the
underlying directed graph of the graph G. If e is an edge,
we often write e^-1 for ι(e) and call it the opposite edge . 
A
self-loop e is called a half-loop
if ι(e) = e, and otherwise is called a
whole-loop.

The opposite map induces an equivalence relation on the directed edges of
the graph, with e∈ equivalent to ι e;
we call the quotient set, E, the 
undirected edge of the 
graph G (or simply its edge). 
Given an edge of a
graph, an orientation
of that edge is the choice of a representative
directed edge in the equivalence relation (given by the opposite map).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a directed graph.
The adjacency matrix , A_G, of G
is the 
square matrix indexed on the vertices, V_G, whose (v_1, v_2)
entry is the number of directed edges whose tail is the vertex v_1 and
whose 
head is the vertex v_2. 
The indegree (respectively outdegree) of a vertex, v,
of G is the number
of edges whose head (respectively tail) is v.

The adjacency matrix of an undirected graph, G, is
simply the adjacency matrix of its underlying directed graph. 
For an undirected graph, the indegree of any vertex equals its outdegree,
and is just called its degree.
The degree matrix of G is the diagonal matrix, 
D_G, indexed on V_G
whose (v,v) entry is the degree of v.
We say that G is d-regular if D_G is d times the identity
matrix, i.e., if each vertex of G has degree d.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a graph.  We define the 
directed line graph or 
oriented line graph of G,
denoted 
(G), to be the
directed graph L=(G) = (V_L, _L, t_L, h_L) given as follows:
its vertex set, V_L, is the set _G of directed edges of
G; its set of directed edges is defined by 
    _L = { (e_1,e_2) ∈_G ×_G | h_G(e_1) =
    t_G(e_2)  and ι_G(e_1) ≠ e_2 }
 that is,
_L corresponds to the
non-backtracking walks of length two in G. 
The tail and head maps are simply
defined to be the projections in each component, that is by t_L(e_1,e_2)
= e_1 and h_L(e_1,e_2) =e_2.

The Hashimoto matrix 
of G is the adjacency matrix of its 
directed line graph, denoted
H_G, which is, therefore, a square matrix indexed
on _G.
We use the symbol μ_1(G) to denote the Perron-Frobenius eigenvalue
of H_G, and use μ_2(G),…,μ_m(G), where m=|_G|,
to denote the remaining eigenvalues, in no particular order (all
concepts we discuss about the μ_i for i≥ 2 will not depend
on their order).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A 
morphism of directed graphs , 
φ
G→ H is a pair φ=(φ_V, φ_E) for which
φ_V  V_G → V_H is a map of vertices and φ_E _G →_H is a map of directed edges
satisfying h_H(φ_E(e)) = φ_V(h_G(e)) and t_H(φ_E(e)) = φ_V(t_G(e)) for all e ∈_G. 
We refer to the values of φ_V^-1 as vertex fibres of φ,
and similarly for edge fibres.
We often more simply write
φ instead of φ_V or φ_E.

sentence:
A morphism of directed graphs ν H → G
is a covering map if it is a
local isomorphism, that is
for any vertex w ∈ V_H, the edge morphism ν_E induces a
bijection (respectively, injection)
between t_H^-1(w) and t_G^-1(ν(w)) and a
bijection (respectively, injection)
between h_H^-1(w) and h_G^-1(ν(w)).
We call G the
base graph and H a covering graph of G .

If ν H → G is a covering map and G is connected,
then the degree of ν, denoted [H G], is the number
of preimages of a vertex or edge in G under ν (which does not
depend on the vertex or edge). If G is not connected, we insist that
the number of preimages of ν of a vertex or edge is the same,
i.e., the degree is independent of the connected component, and we will
write this number as [H G].
In addition, we often refer to H, without ν mentioned explicitly,
as a covering graph of G.

A morphism of graphs is a covering map 
if the morphism of the
underlying
directed graphs is a covering map.

sentence:
We say that a path satisfies the odd (k,i)-conditions if
it starts at height k-i and its height is always less than k.
We say that a path satisfies the even (k,i)-conditions if
it satisfies the odd (k,i)-conditions and for each peak of
coordinates (x,k-1), we have x-u+v ≡ i-1  2 where
u is the number of a-peaks to the left of the peak and v is
the number of b-peaks to the left of the peak.

For the k-conjugation of an overpartition pair, we first
interchange these two regions G_1 and G_2 of λ '_1 and
λ '_2 to get two new partitions λ”_1 and
λ”_2.  Next, we conjugate these to get λ”'_1
and λ”'_2. Finally, we use the Joichi-Stanton algorithm
to assemble λ”'_1 and μ_1 into the top row and

if it is obtained by taking a self-k-conjugate overpartition

≤ j ≤ k-1.

sentence:
(generalized indiscernible set) Fix an L'-structure  and an L-structure  for some languages L and L'.  Let a_i be same-length tuples of parameters from M indexed by the underlying set I of .



  * We say that (a_i : i ∈ I) is an -indexed indiscernible (set in ) if for all n ≥ 1, for all sequences i_1,…,i_n, j_1,…,j_n from I,




 qftp^L'(i_1, …, i_n; ) = qftp^L'(j_1, …, j_n; ) ⇒




 tp^L(a_i_1, …, a_i_n; ) = tp^L(a_j_1, …, a_j_n; )




We omit  where it is clear from context.


  * In the case that the L'-structure  is clear from context, we say that the -indexed indiscernible (a_i : i ∈ I) is L'-generalized indiscernible .


  * Given a sublanguage L^∗⊆ L', we say the L'-generalized indiscernible set (a_i : i ∈ I) is L^∗-generalized indiscernible if it is an | L^∗-indexed indiscernible. 


  * A generalized indiscernible (set) is an I-indexed set (a_i : i ∈ I) for some set I that is an -indexed indiscernible for some choice of structure  on I.


We will always assume that generalized indiscernible sets are nontrivial , i.e. that whenever i ≠ j, a_i ≠ a_j.

  * By 

    C → (B)^A_k

we mean that for all k-colorings f of C  A, there is a B' ⊆ C, where B' is L'-isomorphic to B and the restricted map, f B'  A, is constant.


  * If, for a particular coloring f:  C  A→ k we have a B' ⊆ C such that f B'  A is constant, we say that B' is homogeneous for this coloring (homogeneous for f) .

sentence:

sentence:
Let T(G,a,r) be the convex hull of the characteristic vectors of all edge sets F⊆ E(K^r_n) that contain no clique of size a.  Let 𝒬^i_H be the set of all r-uniform hypercliques of size i, Q^i, in some r-uniform hypergraph H. Then


    T(G,a,r)=({x∈{0,1}^nr| ∑_e∈ E(Q^a) x_e ≤ar-1   ∀ Q^a∈𝒬^a_G}).

We call T(G,a,r) the Turán polytope of G . We denote max{∑_e∈ E(G) x_e| x∈ T(G,a,r)} by ex(G,a,r). We let T(n,a,r):=T(K^r_n,a,r) and ex(n,a,r):=ex(K^r_n,a,r). Furthermore, we let
                                                                                                                                             [         Q(G,a,r)={x∈ℝ^nr| ∑_e∈E(Q^i) x_e ≤ex(i,a,r)     ∀Q^i∈𝒬^i_G, ∀a≤i ≤n-1                          ;                                            0≤x_e ≤1                   ∀e∈E(G)                         } ]

be the clique-relaxation of the Turán polytope of G . Again we let Q(n,a,r):=Q(K^r_n,a,r). We call ∑_e∈ E(Q^i) x_e ≤ ex(i,a,r) clique inequalities, x_e ≥ 0 non-negativity inequalities, and x_e ≤ 1 edge inequalities.

plain_text_term: Turán polytope of G;clique-relaxation of the Turán polytope of G

sentence: A hyperwheel ^rW_l^a is a r-uniform hypergraph on l vertices with one vertex in the center, say l, and vertices [l-1] placed in a cycle in increasing order around it. The r-edges present are such that every a-1 consecutive vertices form an a-clique with vertex l. We only consider wheels for which n≥ 2a-1, since otherwise we'd have a complete hypergraph. For example, Figure <ref> represents ^3W_8^4. We call edges that contain the middle vertex, say l, spoke edges and those who don't, cycle edges . Suppose 1 ≤ j_1 < … < j_r-1≤ l-1, then we say that the cycle edge (i, i+j_1  l, …, i+ j_r-1 l) spans j_r-1 vertices, and the spoke edge (i, i+j_1  l, …, i+j_r-2 l, l) spans j_r-2 vertices if j_r-1 and j_r-2 are as small as possible.  A spoke edge spans between r-1 and a-1 vertices of the cycle and a cycle edge, between r and a-1 vertices. Note that a r-edge spanning β vertices of the cycle is contained in a-1-(β-1)=a-β of the hypercliques. We label the hyperclique spanning vertices i, i+1, …, i+a-2, l  (l-1) as hyperclique i . Note that hypercliques containing any edge e are consecutive modulo a-1 in that labeling. The hyperwheel ^rW_l^a contains (l-1)·a-1r-1 r-edges.

sentence: A hyperweb ^rW_l^a-1 is a r-uniform hypergraph on l vertices placed in a cycle in increasing order, say 1 through l. The r-edges present are such that every a consecutive vertices form an a-clique, i.e., for any given vertex, any edge starting with it and spanning at most the next a-1 vertices will be present. We only consider hyperwebs for which l≥ 2a, so that we do not have a complete hypergraph. A hyperweb is thus for us a hyperwheel with the central vertex removed. For example, Figure <ref> represents the edges present in ^3W_7^3.

sentence:
Given a finite set A of cardinality k, a multiset S is a collection of elements of A where each element of A can appear zero or more times, and where the order of the elements and appearances does not matter.
The number of occurrences of an element a ∈ A in S is called its multiplicity . The sum of all a multiset's elements' multiplicities is its cardinality . The dimension of the multiset S is the number of distinct elements that it contains one or more times.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A sub-multiset S' of a multiset S is a multiset whose elements are all also elements of S. The elements' multiplicities in S' must be less than or equal to their corresponding multiplicities in S.

sentence:
A k-resolution of n is an element of the set
	
    { (x_1 , x_2 , … , x_k)  | x_1 + x_2 + … + x_k = n, z x_i≥ 0  } .

	The cardinality of this set is denoted
	
    R_k^n = { (x_1 , x_2 , … , x_k)  | x_1 + x_2 + … + x_k = n, z x_i≥ 0  } .

	The cardinality of the set of k-resolutions with lower constraints specified by a sequence (a_1,a_2,…,a_k) is
	
    R_ (a_1,a_2, … , a_k )^↓^n  = { (x_1 , x_2 , … , x_k)  | x_1 + x_2 + … + x_k = n, 0 ≥ x_i≥ a_i  } ,

	while the cardinality of the set of k-resolutions with upper constraints specified by such a sequence is
	
    R_ (a_1,a_2, … , a_k)^↑^n = { (x_1 , x_2 , … , x_k)  | x_1 + x_2 + … + x_k = n, x_i≤ a_i  } .

of pairwise disjoint ℓ-sets in V∖ X for some ℓ. Then the number of
stars in G between X and F is

    (X,F):=| { (x,F) x∈ X, F∈F, 
          F⊂ N_G(x) } |.

sentence:
Let f,f' X→ Y be injective functions. We say that f' is obtained
  from f by a switching if there are
  u,v∈ X with f'(u)=f(v) and f'(v)=f(u) and f(w)=f'(w) for all
  w∉{u,v}. The switching distance (f,f')
  of f and f' is at most s if the mapping f' can be obtained from f
  by a sequence of at most s switchings.

sentence:
[Bad and good vertex sets]

Let G, ℓ, T, p, , d, X, Y, and Z
be as above. We define the following family of ℓ-sets in Y with small
joint neighbourhood in Z:

    ℓd(Y,Z) := {B∈Yℓ 
        |_Z(B)|<(d-)^ℓp^ℓ|Z| } .

If (Y,Z) has p-density d_G,p(Y,Z)≥ d-, then all
ℓ-sets T∈Yℓ that are not in 
ℓd(Y,Z) are called p-good in
(Y,Z).

Let further

    ℓd(X,Y,Z)

be the family of ℓ-sets B ∈Xℓ that contain an
ℓ'-set B'⊂ B with ℓ'>0 such that either
|_Y(B')|<(d-)^ℓ'p^ℓ'|Y| or (_Y(B'),Z) is not
(,d,p)-dense in G.

sentence:
[corrupted sets]
  For Δ∈ and a set V let
  B⊂VΔ be a collection of Δ-sets in V
  and let x be a positive real. We say that all B∈B are
  x-corrupted by B.
  Recursively, for i∈[Δ-1] an i-set
  B∈Vi in V is called x-corrupted by B if it
  is contained in more than x of the (i+1)-sets that are
  x-corrupted by B.

  Observe that, if a vertex v∈ V is not x-corrupted by B, then
  it is also not x'-corrupted by B for any x'>x.

sentence:
Define the map C  [0, 1] → [0, 1] by


    C(x) =  x+1    0 = k ≤ x ≤ 2k-1 = 0 + k - 1
    
    x     x = 0 + k = 2k  or  x = 0 + k +1 = 2k+1
    
    x-1    0 + k + 2 = 2k+2 ≤ x ≤ 3k +1= 1.


We refer to this map C as the coordinate-centring function .

Given functions of digital images f_i  X_i → Y_i for i = 1, …, n, we define the product function


    f_1 ×⋯× f_n  X_1 ×⋯×  X_n → Y_1 ×⋯× Y_n


as (f_1 ×⋯× f_n) (x_1, …, x_n) = (f_1(x_1), …, f_n(x_n) ).

sentence:
Let f, g X → Y be (continuous) maps of digital images.
We say that f and g are homotopic , and write f ≈ g,  if, for some N≥ 1, there is a continuous map


    H  X × I_N → Y,


with H(x, 0) = f(x) and H(x, N) = g(x).  Then H is a homotopy from f to g.

sentence:
A transducer is said to be finally connected if there exists a state
which can be reached from any other state. The final component of such a
transducer is defined to be the transducer induced by the set of
states which can be reached from any other state. A finally connected
transducer is said to be finally aperiodic if the underlying graph of the final
component is aperiodic (i.e., the gcd of the lengths of all walks starting and ending at a given vertex is 1).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The Hamming weight of a finite sequence (n_0,…,n_L) is the number of nonzero elements of the sequence.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A transducer is independent if the random vector 
converges in distribution to a random vector with two independent
components, i.e., the sum of the input (X_n) and the sum of the output
(X_n) are asymptotically independent random variables.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The output sum of a transducer is called
quasi-­deter­min­is­tic if there is a constant k∈ such that 

    (X_n)=kn+(1)

holds for all n and all inputs.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For ∈𝒜_I, let a transition matrix M_(y) of the final component be the N× N-matrix whose entry
(s,t) is y^δ if there is a transition from state s to state t
in the final component
with input  and output δ, and 0 otherwise. 

Similarly, let M_' be the transition matrix of the whole transducer. The ordering
of the states is considered to be fixed in such a way that the initial state
1 is the first state and M_' has the
block structure

    [  *  *;  0 M_ ]

where * are matrices with arbitrary entries. If the transducer is strongly
connected, the matrices * are not present (they have 0 rows).

sentence:
We define the following types of directed graphs as subgraphs
  of the final component of the transducer.


  * A rooted tree is a weakly connected digraph with one vertex which has out-degree
0, while all other vertices have out-degree 1. The vertex with out-degree 0
is called the root of the tree.


  * A functional digraph is a digraph whose vertices have out-degree
1. Each component of a
functional digraph consists of a directed cycle and some trees rooted at
vertices of the cycle. For a functional digraph D, let 𝒞_D be the
set of all cycles of D.

sentence:
A subring  𝒜 of  ℤ G is called an S-ring over G if there exists a partition 𝒮=𝒮(𝒜) of G such that:

 (1) {e}∈𝒮,

 (2) X∈𝒮 ⇒ X^-1∈𝒮,

 (3) 𝒜=Span_ℤ{X: X∈𝒮}.

sentence: An S-ring 𝒜 over  G is called schurian if 𝒜=𝒜(Γ, G) for some Γ with G_right≤Γ≤ Sym(G).

sentence: A finite group G is called a Schur group if every S-ring over G is schurian.

sentence: Cayley schemes  𝒞=(G,ℛ) and 𝒞^'=(G^',ℛ^') are called isomorphic if there exists a bijection f:G→ G^' such that  ℛ^'=ℛ^f, where ℛ^f={R^f: R∈ℛ} and R^f={(a^f, b^f): (a, b)∈ R}.

sentence: Two S-rings 𝒜  over G and 𝒜^' over G^' are called isomorphic if there exists an isomorphism of the corresponding Cayley schemes 𝒞(𝒜) and 𝒞^'(𝒜^') taking  the identity element of G  to the identity element of G^'. It is called the isomorphism from 𝒜 to 𝒜^'.

sentence: Let γ be an n-dimensional faithful complex representation of a finite group G, and let M be defined as above.  The extended McKay-Cartan matrix is C̃:=nI-M and the McKay-Cartan matrix C is the submatrix of C̃ obtained by removing the row and column corresponding to the trivial character χ_0.

Given a faithful complex representation γ of a finite group G with McKay-Cartan and extended McKay-Cartan matrices C and C̃, we define its critical group in either of the following equivalent ways:

    K(γ)   := (C^t)=K(C) 
    ⊕ K(γ)    := (C̃^t)

sentence:
A matroid M=(E,) is called strong lattice path matroid , if
its ground set has the property 
E = 1,2,…,| E | and if
there are lattice paths p,q∈E,N^| E |
with p≼ q,
such that M = M[p,q],
where M[p,q] denotes the transversal matroid  presented by
the family
_[p,q]=(A_i)_i=1^_M(E)⊆ E
with

    A_i = j∈ E | ∃ (r_j)_j=1^| E |∈P[p,q] 
     r_j = N| k∈ E| k≤ j, r_k=N| = i ,

i.e. each A_i consists of those j∈ E, such that there is a 
lattice path r between p and q such that the j-th step of r is towards the North for the i-th time in total.
Furthermore,
a matroid M=(E,) is called lattice path matroid , 
if there is a bijection ϕ E1,2,…,| E | 
such that ϕ[M] = (ϕ[E],ϕ[X] |  X∈) is a strong lattice path matroid.

sentence:

matroid. We say that 𝒪 is generalized series-parallel ,
if every non-trivial minor ' of 𝒪 with a simple underlying matroid M(') has a {0,±1}-valued
coflow which has exactly one or two nonzero-entries.

sentence: A signed graph G = (V,E,σ) is a simple graph on vertices V = {v_1, v_2, …, v_n}, with edges E, such that each vertex is given a sign by σ: V →{+,-}.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The three combinatorial reduction rules on signed graphs are as follows.


  * gpr_v, the graph positive rule applies if and only if σ(v)=+. It removes v from the graph, all edges among two vertices in N_G(v) are complemented, and the signs of all vertices in N_G(v) are inverted.

  * gdr_v_1,v_2, the graph double rule applies if and only if σ(v_1)=σ(v_2)=- and (v_1,v_2) ∈ E. It removes v_1 and v_2 from the graph, and complements all edges (x,y) such that one of x or y lies in N_G(v_1) and the other in N_G(v_2), but such that not both v_1 and v_2 lie in N_G(v_1) ∩ N_G(v_2). Signs are unaffected.

  * gnr_v, the graph negative rule applies if and only if σ(v)=- and v is isolated (has no neighbors). It removes v, and does not affect the rest of the graph.

A combinatorial reduction strategy is a sequence (γ_1, γ_2, …, γ_n) of one or more combinatorial reduction rules. A combinatorial reduction strategy is called applicable if for i =1,2,…,n, the rule γ_i applies to γ_i-1∘…∘γ_2 ∘γ_1 (G). The domain of a reduction strategy is the set of vertices removed by the strategy. A reduction strategy is called successful if it is applicable and its domain is all of V. The composition γ_n ∘…∘γ_2 ∘γ_1 of the rules of a combinatorial reduction strategy is called a combinatorial reduction .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A vector subspace 𝒲 of 𝒱 is ℰ-reducible if 𝒲 + 𝒲^⊥ℰ = 𝒱, i.e. if 𝒲 and its ℰ-annihilator span 𝒱. A subset W of vertices in the graph G is reducible in G if ⟨ W ⟩ is ℰ-reducible.

    Γ_W(G)= 𝒢(V \ W, ℰ^⟨ W ⟩).

sentence: If G is a graph, and W ⊂ V is a subset of the vertices of G, then the rank of W in G , rank_G(W), is the rank of the bilinear form  restricted to ⟨ W ⟩. The nullity of W is |W| - rank_G(W). The set W is called singular if it has positive nullity, and non-singular otherwise.

sentence: The reducibility poset (G) of a graph G is the collection of reducible subsets of vertices S ⊂ V. The reducibility poset at level n , _n(G), is the collection of reducible subsets S ⊂ V with nullity n in G. The subsets _n(G) ⊂(G) will be called the levels of the reducibility poset. The first level _0(G) will be called the pivotal poset of G.

sentence: A pair (_0, V), where V is a finite set and _0 is a collection of subsets of V, is called realizable if there exists a graph G on vertices V with pivotal poset _0.

sentence: A nonempty subset W of vertices is minimally reducible if it is reducible, and none of its nonempty subsets are reducible. A minimal graph reduction is a reduction Γ_W such that W is minimally reducible.

sentence: Two pairs of matrices (A_1,B_1),(A_2,B_2) are row-equivalent if there exists an invertible matrix M such that (MA_1, MB_1) = (A_2,B_2). Denote by [A,B] the equivalence class of pairs of matrices row-equivalent to (A,B). These equivalence classes are called pair-classes of matrices. A pair-class [A,B] is called proper if A is nonsingular.

    [A, B] ∗ X = [ P_2Q_1R_2S_1, -P_1Q_2-R_1
    S_2]

sentence:
Let 𝒟_1 (resp. 𝒟_2) be the set of horizontal (resp. vertical) edges of a maximal Dyck path 𝒟=𝒟^a_1× a_2. We label 𝒟 with the corner-first index in the following sense:




  * edges in 𝒟_1 are indexed as u_1,…,u_a_1 such that u_i is the horizontal edge of the i-th corner for i∈ [1,c] and u_c+i is the i-th of the remaining horizontal ones for i∈ [1, a_1-c],

  * edges in 𝒟_2 are indexed as v_1,…, v_a_2 such that v_i is the vertical edge of the i-th corner for i∈ [1,c] and v_c+i is the i-th  of the remaining vertical ones for i∈ [1, a_2-c].

(Here we count corners from bottom left to top right, count vertical edges from bottom to top, and count horizontal edges from left to right.)
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let  S_1⊆𝒟_1, S_2 ⊆𝒟_2, s∈ℤ_≥0. We say that S_1 and S_2 are s-compatible if for every 1≤ r≤ s, either u_r∉ S_1 or v_r∉ S_2. In other words, neither of the first s corners are in the subpath S_1∪ S_2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let a=(a_1,…,a_n)∈ℤ_≥0^n  be a d-vector.
For each pair i→ j in Q, let 𝒟^(i,j) be a maximal Dyck path 𝒟^a_i× a_j. We label  𝒟^(i,j) with the corner-first index (described in Definition <ref>), whose horizontal edges are denoted u_1^(i,j),…,u_a_i^(i,j) and vertical edges are denoted by v_1^(i,j),…,v_a_j^(i,j).
We say that the collection

    {S_ℓ^(i,j)⊆𝒟^(i,j)_ℓ |   i→ j
     is an arrow,  ℓ∈{1,2}}
 is a globally compatible collection (abbreviated GCC) if and only if for any k→ i→ j in Q:


  * if j→ k is also an arrow in Q, then S^(i,j)_1 and S^(i,j)_2 are σ_ijk-compatible,
and

    v^(k,i)_r∈ S^(k,i)_2⟺ u^(i,j)_a_i+1-r∉S^(i,j)_1,  for all r∈[1,a_i];



  * otherwise,   
    v^(k,i)_r∈ S^(k,i)_2⟺ u^(i,j)_r∉S^(i,j)_1, for all r∈[1,a_i].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A configuration is a triple (C, X, ) where C is a plane graph, X ⊆ V(C), and : V(C) →{ 0, 1, 2, ∞} is an external degree function.
A graph G contains the configuration (C,X, ) if C appears as an induced subgraph C' of G, and for each vertex v ∈ V(C), there are at most (v) edges in G from the copy of v to vertices not in C'.
For a triple (C,X,), define the list-size function f : V(C) →ℕ as 
    f(v) =  4 - (v)     v ∈ X
     1     v ∉ X.

A configuration (C,X,) is reducible if C is (f,2)-choosable.

sentence:
A poset P on [n] is a Baxter poset if and only if it satisfies the following conditions:


  * P is bounded.

  * If x∈ P, then
x is covered by at most two elements and covers at most two elements. 

  * P contains no 2-14-3, no 3-14-2, no 2-41-3, and no 3-41-2 chains.

  * If [x,y] is an interval of P such that the open interval (x,y) is disconnected, then
 |x-y|=1. 

  * There exists a planar embedding of P such that for every interval [x,y] of P with (x,y) disconnected, if w,z ∈ (x,y)  and w is left of z, then w<x<z in numerical order.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Lam <cit.>] 
The (affine) Stanley symmetric function of π∈_n is 

    _π = ∑_π = π^1 π^2 ⋯ x_1^ℓ(π^1) x_2^ℓ(π^2)⋯∈[[x_1,x_2,…]]

where the sum is over all factorizations π = π^1 π^2 ⋯ 
of π
into countably many (possibly empty) cyclically decreasing factors
π^i ∈_n such that ℓ(π) = ℓ(π^1) + ℓ(π^2) + ….

sentence:
[Rains and Vazirani <cit.>]
A scaled W-set is a pair (X,) with X a W-set and : X → a function such that |(sx)-(x)|≤1 for all s∈ S. An element x∈ X is W-minimal if (sx)≥(x) for all s∈ S.

sentence:
[Rains and Vazirani <cit.>]
A quasiparabolic W-set is a scaled W-set (X,) satisfying the following two properties:

    
  ∙ (QP1) For all r∈ R(W), x∈ X, if (rx)=(x), then rx = x.
    
  ∙ (QP2) For all r∈ R(W), x∈ X, s∈ S, if (rx) > (x) and (srx) < (sx), then rx = sx.

sentence:
[Rains and Vazirani <cit.>]
Let (X,) be a quasiparabolic W-set with W-minimal element x_0. Suppose x∈ Wx_0⊂ X is in the W-orbit of x_0 and has height (x)=k+(x_0). Then we call s_1s_2⋯ s_kx_0 a reduced expression for x if x=s_1s_2⋯ s_kx_0, s_i∈ S. By abuse of notation, we also call wx_0 reduced where w =s_1s_2⋯ s_k is the corresponding reduced expression.

sentence:
[Rains and Vazirani <cit.>]
Let (X, ) be a quasiparabolic W-set. The Bruhat order on X is the transitive closure of the relation that for x∈ X, r∈ R(W), x≤ rx if (x)≤(rx).

sentence:
An S-labeled graph Γ=(V,ω,τ) if a W-graph if the free -module generated by V can be given an -module structure with

    H_sx=vx   s∉τ(x)
    
    -v^-1x+∑_y∈ V;s∉τ(y)ω(x,y)y   s∈τ(x)     for s∈ S and x∈ V.

sentence: For every σ∈ S_m and 1 ≤ s ≤ m-1, we define the overlap set of σ of size s as the set of permutations τ∈ S_2m-s such that (τ_1⋯τ_m) = (τ_m-s+1⋯τ_2m-s) = σ, denoted by _s(σ).  We similarly define (σ) := ⋃_s_s(σ) as the overlap set of σ .

sentence:
We  denote by ∼ the equivalence relation on  F(V) generated by  elementary commutations

    w_1abw_2 ∼ w_1ba w_2,

where w_1,w_2∈ F(V) and a,b∈ V are disconnected letters, i.e., they satisfy a b and b  a.

sentence: Let a_i∈ V, i=1,…, n, so that w=a_1 a_2 … a_n∈ F(V). Then a_j is an initial letter of w, if a_j commutes with a_i for each i<j.

sentence:
A square matrix in which each row (after the first) has the elements of the previous
row shifted cyclically one place right is called a circulant matrix. So, a circulant matrix has the form




    𝐌= circ(m_0, m_1,… , m_n-1) =
    [
        [   m_0   m_1     … m_n-1; m_n-1   m_0     … m_n-2;     ⋮     ⋮     ⋱     ⋮;   m_1   m_2     …   m_0;       ]],
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The number τ_2(n) of the spanning trees for the generalized Petersen graph
GP(n,2) is equal to (-1)^n 1/20 n (α^2 - 29
β^2), where the integers α and β are given by the
equality: T_n(1 + √(29)/4) - 1 =α +
β√(29)/4.

Moreover, τ_2(n) = n a(n)^2, where the integer sequence a(n) satisfies the following recursive
relation

    a(n+4)    = a(n+3) + 3 a(n+2) - a(n+1) - a(n),
    
    a(0)    = 0, a(1) = 1, a(2) = 1, a(3)=5.

Note a(n) is A192422 sequence in the On - Line Encyclopaedia of Integer Sequences.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The strong alliance polynomial defined in <cit.> denoted by  a is:
	
    a(G;x) = ∑_S ⊆ V(G)    [S  is not empty ][   G[S]  is connected ]
       [ S  is strong defensive alliance ]x^f_x(S)

sentence:
The Catalan simplicial set ℂ has its n-simplices
  given by Dyck words of length 2n+2; these are strings
  comprised of (n+1) U's and (n+1) D's such that the ith U
  precedes the ith D for each 1 ⩽ i ⩽ n+1.
  
  
  
  
  
  The face maps d_i ℂ_n →ℂ_n-1 act on a
  word W by deleting the ith U and ith D; the degeneracy maps
  s_i ℂ_n-1→ℂ_n act on a word W by
  repeating the ith U and ith D.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let  be a monoidal category. The monoidal nerve of  is the
   simplicial set N_⊗() defined as follows:


  * There is a unique 0-simplex, denoted ⋆.

  * A 1-simplex is an object A ∈; its two faces are
  necessarily ⋆.

  * A 2-simplex is a morphism A_12⊗ A_01→ A_02
  in ; its three faces are A_12,
  A_02 and A_01.

  * A 3-simplex is a commuting diagram
A_01
A_12
A_23
A_02
A_03
A_13
A_123
A_023
A_013
A_012
  
    
 in ; its four faces are A_123, A_023,
A_013 and A_012.

  * Higher-dimensional simplices are determined by 3-coskeletality.

The degeneracy of the unique 0-simplex is the unit object I ∈; the two degeneracies s_0(A), s_1(A) of a 1-simplex are the
respective coherence constraints ρ^-1_A  A ⊗ I →
A and λ_A  I ⊗ A → A; the three degeneracies of
a 2-simplex are simply the assertions that certain diagrams commute,
which is so by the axioms for a monoidal category. Higher degeneracies
are determined by coskeletality.

sentence:
A skew-monoidal category is a  
 category  equipped with a unit element I ∈, a tensor
product ⊗×→, and natural families
of (not neccesarily invertible) constraint maps 

    α_ABC (A ⊗ B) ⊗ C → A ⊗ (B ⊗
      C)
    λ_A I ⊗ A → A   and  ρ_A  A → A
      ⊗ I

subject to the commutativity of the
following diagrams—wherein tensor is denoted by juxtaposition—for
all A,B,C,D ∈:


    ((AB)C)D(AB)(CD)A(B(CD))(A(BC))DA((BC)D) (5.1)ααα 1α1 α[0.1cm]
       [@!C@C-6pt]
      (AI)B [r]^α    A(IB) [d]^1λ@[dl]| (5.2)   
    
     AB [u]^ρ1[r]_id    AB


    [@!C@C-22pt]    I(AB) [dr]^λ@[d]|(0.6) (5.3)   
    
    (IA)B [ur]^α[rr]_λ1       AB
      [@!C@C-20pt]    (AB)I [dr]^α@[d]|(0.6) (5.4)   
    
    AB [ur]^ρ[rr]_1ρ       A(BI)
      [@!C@C-3pt@R+4pt]    II [dr]^λ@[d]|(0.6) (5.5)   
    
    I [ur]^ρ[rr]_id       I .

sentence:
The lax nerve N_ℓ(Cat) of the monoidal bicategory
  Cat is the simplicial set defined as follows:


  * There is a unique 0-simplex, denoted ⋆.

  * A 1-simplex is a (small) category _01; its two faces are
  both ⋆.

  * A 2-simplex is a functor A_012_12×_01→_02.

  * A 3-simplex is a natural transformation
  
    _01_12_23_02_03_13A_123A_023A_013A_012A_0123
 with 1-cell components

    (A_0123)_a_23, a_12, a_01 A_013(A_123(a_23,a_12),a_01) →
    A_023(a_23,A_012(a_12,a_01)) .


  * A 4-simplex is a quintuple of appropriately-formed natural transformations
(A_1234, A_0234, A_0134, A_0124, A_0123) making the
pentagon

    [@C-9.6em@R-1.5em]                        
        A_024(A_234(a_34, a_23), A_012(a_12, a_01))
        [dddr]^A_0234
    
    
        A_014(A_124(A_234(a_34, a_23), a_12), a_01)
        [uurr]^A_0124[dd]_A_014(A_1234, 1)
              
        A_034(a_34, A_023(a_23, A_012(a_12, a_01))) 
        
     
        A_014(A_134(a_34, A_123(a_23, a_12)), a_01) [ddrr]_A_0134
    
          A_034(a_34, A_013(A_123(a_23, a_12), a_01))
        [uuur]_A_034(1, A_0123)

commute in _04 for all (a_01, a_12, a_23, a_34) ∈_01×_12×_23×_34.

  * Higher-dimensional simplices are determined by 4-coskeletality, and
face and degeneracy maps are defined as before.

The pseudo nerve N_p(Cat)
is defined identically except that the natural transformations
occurring in dimensions 3 and 4 are required to be invertible.

sentence:
Let K⊆ L be a field extension in which every algebraic element of L is separable 
 over K. Let A, B⊂ L be non-zero finite-dimensional K-subspaces of L and H be the stabilizer of 
 ⟨ AB⟩. Then
 
    _K⟨ AB⟩≥_KA+_KB-_KH.

(Here H is a subfield of L containing K and we have H⟨ AB⟩=⟨ AB⟩.)

Let E be a vector space over the field K and let ℰ = {E_1, E_2,…, E_n} be a collection of vector 
subspaces of E. A free transversal for ℰ is a free family of vectors {x_1,… , x_n} in 
E satisfying x_i ∈ E_i for all i=1,… , n. The following result of Rado [8] gives necessary and sufficient 
conditions for the existence of a free transversal for ℰ, very similar to those of Hall's marriage theorem. 
The interested readers are also referred to <cit.>.

sentence:
Let (,) be an edge colored hypergraph. The chromatic polynomial of (,) is a polynomial in the variable t defined by 
    χ (, ,t)=# (proper vertex colorings of  (,)  with  t  colors).

sentence: By an edge coloring of a hypergraph =([ℓ ],E) we mean a function :E→Λ for some finite set Λ. We say that a pair (,) is a edge colored hypergraph when  is a hypergraph and  is a edge coloring of
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For any edge e={i_1,i_2…,i_s}∈ E let 
    ν(e)={v∈ V| v_i_1=v_i_2=⋯ =v_i_s}.
 Then for each λ∈Λ let 
    X_λ = ⋂_e∈^-1(λ)ν (e).
 The edge colored hypergraphic arrangement associated to (,) is 
    _(,)={ X_λ} _λ∈Λ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: For any hypergraph =([ℓ],E) we say that a set of edges {e_1,…,e_k}⊆ E is connected if for all i,j∈⋃_s=1^ke_s there exists a sequence of edges {e_i_1,…,e_i_t}⊆{e_1,…,e_k} such that i∈ e_i_1, j∈ e_i_t and for all 1≤ s≤ t-1, e_i_s∩ e_i_s+1≠∅. Given a hypergraph  we call the maximal connected sets of edges connected components.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let E and E' be two sets of edges of a hypergraph  with connected components { K_1,… , K_s} and { K_1',… , K_t'} respectively. Let { V_1,… ,V_s} and { V_1',… ,V_t'} be the vertex sets of the connected components { K_1,… , K_s} and { K_1',… , K_t'}. We say that E is a refinement of E' and write E⋐ E' if for each 1≤ i≤ s there exists a 1≤ j≤ t such that V_i ⊆ V_j'.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let (,) be an edge colored hypergraph with edge colors Λ and let Γ_1,Γ_2⊆Λ. We say that Γ_1 covers Γ_2 if Γ_1⋑Γ_2 and there does not exist a set of colors Ψ that satisfies Ψ≢Γ_i for i=1,2 and Γ_1⋑Ψ⋑Γ_2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that a vertex coloring c of (,) is proper if for every λ∈Λ there exists a connected component K∈^-1(λ ) and some i,j∈ K with c(i)≠ c(j).

sentence:
Let (,) be an edge colored hypergraph with edge colors Λ. Let λ_1,λ_2,λ_3∈Λ. We call (λ_1,λ_2,λ_3) a Massey color system if the pairs λ_1,  λ_2 and {λ_1,λ_2}, λ_3 are multiplicative and there exists λ_4,λ_5∈Λ such that 

    {λ_1,λ_2}   ⋑λ_4    {λ_2,λ_4}   ⋑̸λ_1    {λ_1,λ_4}   ⋑̸λ_2   		
    {λ_2,λ_3}   ⋑λ_5    {λ_3,λ_5}   ⋑̸λ_2    {λ_2,λ_5}   ⋑̸λ_3.
 We call _4 and _5 embedded colors for the triple _1, _2,_3.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
Let P be an ordered set. A pair (a,b) of elements of V is very good if the following two conditions hold simultaneously in P or in its dual.


  * D(a)= D(b); and

  * U(a)∖ U(b) and U(b)∖ U(a) are chains (possibly empty).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let W=w_1...w_2n be a double occurrence word in the
letters v_1,...,v_n. The interlacement graph ℐ(W) is
the simple graph with vertex-set V={v_1,...,v_n}, in which v_i and
v_j are adjacent if and only if they are interlaced in W, i.e.,
they appear in W in the order v_iv_jv_iv_j or v_jv_i
v_jv_i. A circle graph is a simple graph that can be realized as
the interlacement graph of some double occurrence word.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
<cit.> Let G be a simple graph. For each pair of
distinct vertices v and w of G, let β(v,w) and β(w,v) be
distinct variables. Then the Naji equations for G are the following.

(a) For each edge vw of G, β(v,w)+β(w,v)=1.

(b) If v,w,x are three distinct vertices of G such that vw∈ E(G) and
vx,wx∉ E(G), then β(x,v)+β(x,w)=0.

(c) If v,w,x are three distinct vertices of G such that vw,vx∈ E(G)
and wx∉ E(G), then β(v,w)+β(v,x)+β(w,x)+β(x,w)=1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a simple graph. A split (X, Y) of G is given by a
partition V(G)=X∪ Y with | X|, |
Y|≥2 and subsets X^'⊆ X and Y^'⊆ Y such that the set of edges of G connecting X to Y is
{xy| x∈ X^' and y∈ Y^'}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If v is a vertex of a simple graph G then the local complement
G^v is the graph obtained from G by reversing the adjacency status of
every pair of neighbors of v. A graph that can be obtained from G through
some sequence of local complementations is locally equivalent to G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let π be a permutation of {1,...,n}. Then the corresponding
permutation graph has vertices 1,...,n, with an edge ij whenever
i<j and π(i)>π(j).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let L be a Latin cube that is isomorphic to a Boolean Latin cube.


A row block of L is a set of n rows R_i,k such that for every pair 
of rows R_i_1,k_1={(i_1,j,k_1): j ∈ [n]} and 
R_i_2,k_2 = {(i_2,j,k_2): j ∈ [n]} in this set, B(i_1,x,k_1)=B(i_2,x,k_2) for every x ∈{1,…,n}. It is obvious that there are n row blocks in total.
Column blocks and  file blocks are defined similarly.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
If L is a Latin cube that is isomorphic to a 
Boolean Latin cube, a transversal-set 𝔱 of L 
is a set of n cells that satisfy the following



	
  * no two cells in 𝔱 are in the same row/column/file;
	
	 
  * no two cells in 𝔱 contain the same symbol;
	
	
  * for any two cells in 𝔱, there is a unique 3-cube
	that contain these cells.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A symbol-row block of a Latin cube L that is isomorphic to a Boolean
Latin cube is a set 𝔰  of n^2 cells 
satisfying that

	
	
  * all cells of 𝔰 that are in the same row layer
	contain the same symbol, and
	
	
  * for every cell of 𝔰, there are n-1 other cells that have
	the same column and file coordinate.
	 


Symbol-column blocks and symbol-file blocks are defined similarly.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence: A symbol block of a Latin cube L is a set of n^2 cells such that all these cells contain the same symbol.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let x_1,x_2,… be formal variables which commute with each other
and with u_1,…,u_N.
Define the noncommutative Cauchy product Ω(𝐱,
𝐮)∈[[x_1,x_2,…]] by

    Ω(𝐱, 𝐮)
    = H(x_1) H(x_2) ⋯
    =∏_j=1^∞∏_i=1^N(1-x_ju_i)^-1
    =∏_j=1^∞∑_ℓ = 0^∞ x_j^ℓ h_ℓ(𝐮)

(cf. (<ref>)); here the notation ∏ always means that the factors are
multiplied left-to-right.
Now, for γ∈^*, we define the formal
power series F_γ(𝐱)∈ℤ[[x_1,x_2,…]] by

    F_γ(𝐱)=⟨Ω(𝐱, 𝐮) ,γ⟩,

where  ⟨· ,·⟩ is the extension of the pairing between  and ^* to
the bilinear pairing between [[x_1,x_2,…]] and ^* in which ⟨ f  𝐮_w,v⟩ = f  δ_vw for
any  f ∈[[x_1,x_2,…]].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[ Noncommutative Schur functions ]

Let λ=(λ_1,λ_2,…) be an integer partition.
Let λ' be the conjugate partition,
and let  t=λ_1 be the  number of parts of λ'.
The noncommutative Schur function
𝔍_λ(𝐮) ∈ is given by the following
noncommutative version of the classical Kostka-Naegelsbach determinantal formula  s_λ = (e_λ'_i+j-i) :

    𝔍_λ(𝐮) = ∑_π∈_t(π)   e_λ'_1+π(1)-1(𝐮) 
    e_λ'_2+π(2)-2(𝐮) ⋯
    e_λ'_t+π(t)-t(𝐮).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The switchboard ideal  is the ideal in  generated by the elements

   u_b^2 u_a + u_a u_b u_a - u_b u_a u_b - u_b u_a^2         (b-a=1), 


   u_b^2 u_a - u_b u_a u_b        (b - a ≥2), 

   u_b u_a^2 - u_a u_b u_a         (b - a ≥2), 

   u_b u_c u_a + u_a u_c u_b - u_b u_a u_c - u_c u_a u_b             (a < b
  < c).

sentence:
[ Switchboards ]

Let w=w_1⋯w_n and w'=w_1'⋯w_n'
be two words of the same length n in the
alphabet {1,…,N}.
We say that w and w'  are related by a switch in
position i if

w_j=w_j' for j∉{i-1,i,i+1},
while the unordered pair 
{w_i-1w_iw_i+1,
w'_i-1w'_iw'_i+1}
fits one of the following patterns (cf. Figure <ref>):


  * {bac, bca} or  {acb, cab}, with a < b < c
  (a Knuth switch );

  * {bac, acb} or  {bca, cab}, with a < b < c
  (a rotation switch );

  * {bab, bba} or {aba, baa}, with a < b
  (a Knuth switch );

  * {bab, aba} or {bba, baa}, with b = a+1
  (a braid/idempotent switch ).




A switchboard
is an edge-labeled graph Γ on a vertex set of words of fixed length n
in the alphabet {1,…,N}
with edge labels from the set  {2,3,…,n-1} such that
each i-edge (i.e., an edge labeled i) corresponds to a switch in position i,
and each vertex in Γ 
which has exactly one descent in positions i-1 and i
belongs to exactly one i-edge.

sentence:
A  graph is a switchboard

whose words have no repeated letters.

sentence:
Let q be a formal parameter.
Let  β be a  k-tuple of skew shapes 
in which the shifted contents of all cells lie in {1,…,N}.
The new variant combinatorial LLT polynomial indexed by
β is defined by

    𝒢_β(𝐱;q) =
    ∑_v∈k(β)q^k(v)Q_(v)(𝐱).

(We note that no generality is lost by the restriction on the shifted
contents of  β
because 𝒢_β(𝐱;q) is unchanged by
translating all the β^(i) horizontally by the same constant.)

sentence:
Let _q = (q) _ where (q) is the field of
rational functions in one variable q.

Lam's ideal k is the ideal in _q generated by the elements

   u_a^2         for all a, 

   u_a+ku_au_a+k         for all a,  

   u_au_a+ku_a        for all a,  

   u_au_b - u_bu_a            for b-a > k,  

   u_au_b - q^-1 u_bu_a            for 0<b-a<k. 



We denote k=k∩
(viewing  as the -subalgebra of _q generated by 1 and the u_i).
In what follows, we mostly work with k rather
than k.
Even though it is the latter that is contained in ,
we feel that the former is a more natural and important concept.

sentence:
The Assaf ideal  k is the ideal in  generated by
all monomials 𝐮_w∈k
(cf. Lemma <ref>)
together with the elements listed in (<ref>)–(<ref>).

sentence:
An Assaf switchboard of level k
is a switchboard in which every vertex is a nonzero
k-word, and every i-edge with endpoints
w and w' corresponds to a switch where
{w_i-1w_iw_i+1, w'_i-1w'_iw'_i+1}
fits one of the patterns

    {bac, bca} or  {acb, cab}, with c-a > k
        and a<b<c;
       {bac, acb} or  {bca, cab}, with c-a ≤
        k and a < b < c.

sentence:
LLT switchboards are the special
Assaf switchboards Γ_k(β,t) described in
Proposition <ref>.
This terminology is justified by Corollary <ref> below.

sentence:
An Assaf symmetric function of level k
is the symmetric function F_Γ(𝐱) associated to an 
Assaf switchboard Γ of level k.

sentence:
A switchboard Γ is called rotation-free
if it has no rotation switches.
That is, every switch in Γ is Knuth, braid, or idempotent,
see Definition <ref> and Figure <ref>.
That is, any i-edge
{w,w'} in Γ corresponds to a switch
where {w_i-1w_iw_i+1, w'_i-1w'_iw'_i+1} fits one of the patterns


  * {bac, bca} or  {acb, cab} for a<b<c, or

  * {bab, bba} or {aba, baa} for a < b, or

  * {bab, aba} or {bba, baa} for b = a+1.

sentence:
The plactic ideal ⊂ is 
generated by the “Knuth elements”

   u_au_cu_b - u_cu_au_b            for a≤ b<c; 

   u_bu_au_c - u_bu_cu_a        for a<b≤ c.



It is easy to see that ⊃.

sentence:
A switchboard is called plactic if all its switches are Knuth.
A connected plactic switchboard has the words in a Knuth (= plactic) equivalence class as its vertices,
and Knuth switches as its edges.
For a semistandard Young tableau T, we denote by Γ_T the switchboard
whose vertex set consists of words with insertion tableau T.

sentence:
Let us partition the set of 3-element subsets of {1,…,N} into three categories,
by declaring each triple S⊂{1,…,N} to be
either a Knuth triple , or a rotation triple , or an undecided triple .
Similarly, declare each subset  {a, a+1}⊂{1,…,N} to be a Knuth pair , a braid/idempotent pair , or an undecided pair .
Let I_M be a monomial ideal in .
The  semimatched ideal I associated to this data is the ideal generated by I_M,
the switchboard ideal  (whose generators are
(<ref>)–(<ref>)),

and the elements listed below:

   u_a u_c u_b - u_c u_a u_b            if a < b < c is a Knuth triple,  

   u_b u_a u_c - u_b u_c u_a          if a < b < c is a Knuth triple, 

   u_a u_c u_b - u_b u_a u_c          if a < b < c is a rotation triple,  

   u_c u_a u_b - u_b u_c u_a          if a < b < c is a rotation triple, 

   u_a u_b u_a - u_b u_a u_a          if  b-a=1 and {a, b} is a Knuth pair, 

   u_b u_a u_b - u_b u_b u_a          if  b-a=1 and {a, b} is a Knuth pair, 

   u_a u_b u_a - u_b u_a u_b          if  b-a=1 and {a, b} is a braid/idempotent pair, 

   u_b u_a u_a - u_b u_b u_a          if  b-a=1 and {a, b} is a braid/idempotent pair.

sentence:
A  triples ideal is a semimatched ideal
in which there are no undecided triples, all pairs  {a, a+1} are Knuth pairs, and I_M={0}.
Hence the data defining a triples ideal is a map  from the set of triples in {1,…,N}
to the 2-element set {Knuth, rotation}.
A triples switchboard is an I-switchboard associated to a triples ideal I.
A triples  graph is a triples switchboard

whose words have no repeated letters;
these were studied in
<cit.>,
see <cit.>.

sentence:
For 
α=(α_1,…,α_l)∈_≥ 0^l
and 
𝐧=(n_1,…,n_l) ∈{0,1,…, N}^l,
we define the noncommutative column-flagged Schur function
J_α(𝐧)=J_α(𝐧)(𝐮) by

    J_α(𝐧)
    =∑_π∈_l(π)   e_α_1+π(1)-1(𝐮_[n_1])
     e_α_2+π(2)-2(𝐮_[n_2])⋯
    e_α_l+π(l)-l(𝐮_[n_l]).

These specialize to the noncommutative Schur functions 𝔍_λ(𝐮)

via
𝔍_λ(𝐮) = J_λ'(N,…,N).

sentence:
Let α=(α_1,…,α_l)∈_≥ 0^l
be a composition satisfying α_j+1≤α_j+1 for all j.
We denote by α' the
diagram whose  jth column contains the cells in rows 1,…,α_j.
Formally, α'={(i,j)|j∈ [l], i∈ [α_j]}⊂_≥ 1×_≥ 1.




Now, for 𝐧=(n_1,…,n_l)∈_≥ 0^l,

let (α')^𝐧 denote the set of
fillings [3]
T: _≥ 1×_≥ 1→ [N] of the diagram α' such that


  * the entries weakly increase across the rows and strictly increase down the columns;

  * the entries in column  j lie in [n_j];

  * if α_j < α_j+1, then T(α_j+1,j+1) > n_j.


The diagonal reading word of T ∈(α')^𝐧, denoted (T),
is obtained by concatenating the diagonals of T
(reading each diagonal in the southeast  direction), starting with the
southwesternmost diagonal of α'.

For example,

    (  1   1   2   2 
    2   2     3
           7 ) = 21271322.

sentence:
The augmented noncommutative column-flagged Schur function
labeled by a weak composition α=(α_1,…,α_l)∈_≥
  0^l,
an l-tuple 𝐧=(n_1,…,n_l) ∈{0,1,…, N}^l,


and words
w^1, …, w^l-1∈^*
is defined by

    J_α(n_1w^1n_2w^2⋯w^l-1n_l)  
       =∑_π∈_l(π)  e_α_1+π(1)-1(𝐮_[n_1])  𝐮_w^1 
    e_α_2+π(2)-2(𝐮_[n_2]) 𝐮_w^2⋯𝐮_w^l-1  e_α_l+π(l)-l(𝐮_[n_l]).

We omit  w^j from the notation in (<ref>) if the word w^j is empty.

sentence:
Let uv be an edge in D.  We call uv a connecting edge if
  for some i = 1,2,


  u∈ X_i and either v∈ X_i or v∈ Y_i; or


u∈ Y_i and either v∈ Y_3-i or v∈ X_3-i.

sentence: A gapset is a finite set G ⊂_+ satisfying the following property: for all z ∈ G, if z=x+y with x,y ∈_+, then x ∈ G or y ∈ G.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G ⊂_+ be a gapset. The multiplicity of G is the smallest integer m ≥ 1 such that m ∉ G, the Frobenius number of G is  f = max G if G ≠∅ and f=-1  otherwise, the conductor of G is c=f+1, the genus of G is g=(G) and the depth of G is q=⌈ c/m ⌉.

sentence: Let G be a gapset. The canonical partition of G is the partition G = G_0 ⊔ G_1 ⊔…⊔ G_q-1 given by (<ref>).

sentence:
Let m ∈_+. An m-extension is a finite set A ⊂_+ containing [1,m-1] and admitting a partition

    A = A_0 ⊔ A_1 ⊔…⊔ A_t

for some t ≥ 0, where A_0=[1,m-1] and A_i+1⊆ m+A_i for all i ≥ 0.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let m ∈_+. An m-filtration is a finite sequence F=(F_0,F_1,…,F_t) of nonincreasing subsets of _+ such that

    F_0=[1,m-1] ⊇ F_1 ⊇…⊇ F_t.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G ⊂_+ be a gapset of multiplicity m. The gapset filtration associated to G is the m-filtration F=φ(G).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: Let F be a gapset filtration. Its multiplicity , genus and depth are defined as those of its corresponding gapset G=τ(F).

sentence:
A projective variety X⊂^k_ of codimension n is a
non-singular complete intersection
if it is the intersection of n non-singular
hypersurfaces
in ℙ^k_
that meet transversally at each point of the
intersection.

sentence:
Let V=(Q,^k) be a real algebraic set,
1≤ j ≤ k, and
ℓ∈Gr(k,k-j).  We say the linear space ℓ is
j-good with respect to V if either:

  * j∉ d([0,k]), or

  * d(i)=j,
and

    A_ℓ:={x∈reg  V^(i)|(_x V^(i)∩ℓ) =0}

is a non-empty dense Zariski open subset of reg  V^(i).

sentence:
The mixed volume (P_1,…,P_n) is the coefficient of the monomial _1 ⋯_n in the polynomial (<ref>).
More explicitly, we have

    (P_1,…,P_n)     :=    1/n!∑_j = 1^n (-1)^n - j∑_1 ≤ i_1 < ⋯ < i_j ≤ n(P_i_1+⋯ +P_i_j).

sentence:
Let :={f_1,… f_n}⊆[𝐳^± 1] be a generic collection of Laurent polynomials.
 
  
  (a) ⋂_j = 1^n ∂((f_j)) is called the set of vertices of (), denoted by V().
  
  (b) For a connected component K of () we call V(K):= K ∩ V() the set of vertices of K.

sentence:
Let :={f_1,… f_n}⊆[𝐳^± 1] be a generic collection of Laurent polynomials. Let K be a connected component of  (). Let 0≤ k≤ n-1.
  
   
  (a) A non-empty and connected subset F⊊ K is called a k-face of K, if there exist unique  E_α(1)(f_j_1),…,E_α(n-k)(f_j_n-k) such that  𝐱∈⋂_s = 1^n-k∂E_α(s)(f_j_s) for all 𝐱∈ F.
   
  (b) An (n-1)-dimensional face of K is called a facet of K.

sentence:
We call a non-empty, full dimensional cone ⋂_j = 1^n _G_j(f_j) in the common refinement (f_1,…,f_n) mixed if for all 1 ≤ i ≤ n it holds that

    _G_i(f_i)∩⋂_j ∈ [n] ∖{i}_G_j(f_j)    ≠   _G_i(f_i)
  
and

    _G_i(f_i)∩⋂_j ∈ [n] ∖{i}_G_j(f_j)    ≠   ⋂_j ∈ [n] ∖{i}_G_j(f_j).

sentence:
Let I⊆ S be a homogeneous ideal and let R=S/I be of Krull dimension d. 
	Let Θ={θ_1,…,θ_d}⊆ S_1. Then:
	
		
  (i) Θ is a linear system of parameters ( l.s.o.p. for short) for R if (R/(θ_1,…,θ_i)R)=(R)-i, for all 1≤ i≤ d.
		
  (ii) Θ is a regular sequence for R if θ_i is not a zero divisor of (R/(θ_1,…,θ_i-1)R), for all 1≤ i≤ d.

sentence: A graded ring R is Cohen-Macaulay if every l.s.o.p. is a regular sequence for R.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A (d-1)-dimensional simplicial complex Δ is balanced if there is a partition of its vertex set V(Δ)=_i=1^d V_i such that | F∩ V_i|≤ 1, for every i=1,…,d.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let n=kd for some integer k≥2. A stacked cross-polytopal (d-1)-sphere on n vertices is a simplicial complex obtained via the connected sum of k-1 copies of 𝒞_d. 
	We denote by 𝒮𝒯^×(n,d) the set of all stacked cross-polytopal (d-1)-spheres on n vertices.

sentence:
Let L_w ⊆ S^E and L_z ⊆ S^E be tropical linear spaces.
	Then the stable sum of L_w and L_z is 
	
    L_w  L_z = A_+L_w ⊕ L_z,

sentence:
(cf. <cit.>)
	Let S be a totally ordered idempotent semifield,
	and let f ∈ (S^E)^ be a linear form.
	The tropical hyperplane defined by f
	is the submodule 
	
    {v = ∑_i=1^n v_ie_i ∈ S^E: f(v) = f(∑_i ≠ j v_ie_i)  for all  j }.

sentence:
Let S be a totally ordered idempotent semifield.
	A tropical Plücker vector of rank d on ground set E
	is a nonzero vector w ∈ S^Ed satisfying the tropical Plücker relations:
	for any J ∈Ed+1 and K ∈Ed-1,
	
    ∑_i ∈ J - K w_J-iw_K+i = ∑_i ∈ J-K, i ≠ j w_J-iw_K+i

	for all j ∈ J-K.

sentence:
Let S be a totally ordered idempotent semifield,
	and let w ∈ S^Ed be a tropical Plücker vector.
	Then the tropical linear space associated to w
	is the intersection of the tropical hyperplanes defined by 
	
    ∑_i ∈ J w_J-ix_i

	over all J ∈Ed+1.
	The tropical linear space associated to w is denoted L_w.

sentence:
An extension of a tropical linear space L_w ⊆ S^E
is a tropical linear space L_z ⊆ S^E∪ P for P disjoint from E such that π_E(L_z) = L_w.
An elementary extension of L_w ⊆ S^E is an extension L_z ⊆ S^E ∪ P such that |P| = 1.

sentence:
Let S be a totally ordered idempotent semifield.
	A linear extension of a tropical linear space L_w ⊆ S^E
	is an elementary extension L_z ⊆ S^E + p of L_w
	such that for some φ∈ (S^E)^, z is of the form
	
    z= (w ∧ e_p) ·⋆_E+p(φ + x_p) = ⋆_E+p(⋆_E w ∧ (φ + x_p)).

	Such an L_z will be denoted L_wφp.

sentence:
Let S be a totally ordered idempotent semifield, and w ∈⋀^d S^E be a tropical Plücker vector.
	Let A = {a_ij}∈ S^F × E be a matrix with columns indexed by E and rows indexed by F = {f_1,…, f_m}.
	Let {x_1,…, x_n} denote the dual basis to S^E and {y_1,…, y_m} denote the dual basis to S^F.
	Let ρ_j = ∑_i ∈ E a_j ix_i ∈ (S^E)^ be the form associated with the jth row of A.
	The tropical graph of A on L_w is the tropical linear space in S^E ⊔ F with tropical Plücker vector
	
    g(w,A) = (w ∧ f_F) ·⋆(ρ_1 + y_1) ·⋆(ρ_2 + y_2) ·…·⋆(ρ_m + y_m) ∈⋀^d S^E ⊔ F,

	where f_F = f_1∧ f_2 ∧⋯∧ f_m.

sentence:
Let S be a totally ordered idempotent semifield, A ∈ S^F × E be a matrix, and w ∈⋀^d S^E be 
	a tropical Plücker vector.
	The tropical image of L_w under A, denoted AL_w, is the projection 
	
    π_F(L_g(w,a))

	of the tropical graph of A on L_w onto the codomain of A.

sentence:
Suppose ℒ is a language that contains some binary function symbol and 𝒜 is an orderly ℒ-algebra.
Then 𝒜 is weakly Ramsey if and only if for every X⊆‖𝒜‖, there exists a reduction ℬ of 𝒜
pre-homogeneous for X , in the sense that for every t_1,t_2∈(ℒ) such that the same variables appear in both orderly terms, ℬ(t_1)∈ X  if and only if ℬ(t_2)∈ X.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose that ℒ is a language. An orderly term of ℒ is a term of ℒ such that the indices  of the variables appearing in
it from left to right is strictly increasing. The set of orderly terms of ℒ is denoted by (ℒ).
If t,t'∈(ℒ), then t < t' means that the index of the last variable in t is less than the index of the first variable in t'.
An infinite  sequence t⃗ of orderly terms of ℒ is admissible iff  it is increasing with respect to <. The set of
admissible sequences of ℒ is denoted by
(ℒ).

sentence:

We say that b⃗ is a reduction of a⃗ (with respect to ℱ), denoted b⃗≤_ℱa⃗, iff there
exists  t⃗∈(ℒ_ℱ) such that b⃗(i)=(t⃗(i))^𝔄[a⃗] for all i ∈ω.

sentence:
Suppose (A, ℱ) is an algebra.
We say that (A, ℱ) is Ramsey iff
for every a⃗∈^ωA and X ⊆ A, there exists b⃗≤_ℱa⃗ such that _ℱ(b⃗) is
either contained in or disjoint from X.

sentence:
A preorder with approximations is a pair
ℜ=(R, ≤) such that R is a nonempty set of infinite sequences and ≤ is a reflexive and transitive relation on R. For n ∈ω and a⃗∈ R, define

    [n,a⃗]={ b⃗∈ R|b⃗≤a⃗ and ⟨b⃗(0), …, b⃗(n-1)⟩= ⟨a⃗(0), …, a⃗(n-1)⟩ }.

The natural topology on ℜ is the topology generated by the sets [n,a⃗].
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose ℜ= (R, ≤) is a preorder with approximations. Assume X is a subset of R. We say that X is Ramsey iff for every n
∈ω and a⃗∈ R, there exists b⃗∈ [n,a⃗] such that [n,b⃗] is either contained in or disjoint from X. Assuming
the Axiom of Choice, ℜ is a Ramsey space iff  every subset of ℜ (endowed with the natural topology) having the
property of Baire is Ramsey.

sentence:
Suppose ℒ is a language and suppose 𝒜 and  ℬ are orderly ℒ-algebras.
We say that ℬ is a reduction of 𝒜 iff there exists t⃗∈(ℒ) such that
for every  s∈(ℒ),

    ℬ(s)=𝒜(s[t⃗]) .

We say that ℬ is a reduction of 𝒜 witnessed by t⃗.

sentence:
Suppose ℒ is a language and 𝒜 is an orderly ℒ-algebra. We say that 𝒜 is weakly Ramsey iff for
every X⊆‖𝒜‖, there exists a reduction ℬ of 𝒜 homogeneous for X in the sense that ‖ℬ‖ is either contained in or disjoint from X. We say that 𝒜 is Ramsey iff for every reduction ℬ of
𝒜 and X⊆‖𝒜‖, there exists a reduction 𝒞 of ℬ homogeneous for X.

sentence: A set system  shatters a given set S ⊆[n] if 2^S = {F ∩ S  :   F ∈ℱ}. The family of subsets of [n] shattered by ℱ is denoted by Sh(ℱ).

shatters exactly |ℱ| sets, i.e. |ℱ|=|Sh(ℱ)|.

sentence:
Let F→ be a function on the set  of Young diagrams.
Suppose that for each ℓ≥ 1 the equality

    F(P'× Q')=_ℓ(γ;P ; Q)

— with the usual substitution (<ref>) for the variable γ — 
holds true for all choices of P, Q and A≠ 0 for which the multirectangular diagram P'× Q' is well-defined.
Then we say that  is the (anisotropic) Stanley polynomial for F.
For a given function F, the corresponding Stanley polynomial, if exists, is unique
(in order to show this, one can adapt the corresponding part of the proof of <cit.>).
The set of functions F with the above property forms an algebra which will be denoted by .

    f_1_∘→,      f_2_∙→

    ( f_1(w), f_2(b) ) is one of the boxes of λ

sentence:
Let Γ be a directed graph on n vertices and let η and ξ be positive real numbers. An (η, ξ)-weighted fractional matching w in Γ is an assignment of a weight w_uv≥ 0 to each edge uv of Γ such that for every vertex u ∈ V(Γ) we have 

    ∑_v ∈ N^+_Γ(u)η w_uv + ∑_v ∈ N^-_Γ(u)ξ w_vu≤ 1.

The total weight of w is defined to be W := ∑_uv∈ E(Γ) (η + ξ)w_uv. By (<ref>) we have W ≤ n; we say that w is perfect if W = n. Note that in this case we have equality in (<ref>) for every vertex.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let n be a non-negative integer and A={a_1,…,a_k} be a multi-set with k not necessarily distinct members. We denote by D(n,A) the number of ways to partition n as the form a_1x_1+…+a_kx_k, where x_i's are positive integers and x_i⩽ x_i+1 whenever a_i=a_i+1. The number of ways to partition n as the form a_1x_1+…+a_kx_k, where x_i's are non-negative integers and x_i⩽ x_i+1 whenever a_i=a_i+1, is also denoted by D_0(n,A). The numbers D(n,A) and D_0(n,A) are called the natural partition number and the arithmetic partition number of n with respect to A, respectively.

sentence:
Let n be a non-negative integer and A={a_1,…,a_k} be a multi-set with k
not necessarily distinct members, where a_1⩽…⩽ a_k. We denote by Δ(n,A) the number of ways to partition n as
the form a_1x_1+…+a_kx_k, where x_i's are distinct positive integers and
x_i< x_i+1 whenever a_i=a_i+1. The number of ways to
partition n as the form a_1x_1+…+a_kx_k, where x_i's are distinct
non-negative integers and x_i< x_i+1 whenever a_i=a_i+1, is also denoted by
Δ_0(n,A). The numbers Δ(n,A) and Δ_0(n,A) are called the natural distinct partition number and the arithmetic distinct partition number of n with respect to A.

sentence: Let X be a set and 𝒰 be a collection of subsets of X such that   covers X. Then the nerve N(𝒰) of the cover  is the simplicial complex that has vertex set   and where the vertices U_0,… ,U_k∈𝒰 form a simplex if and only if U_0∩…∩ U_k≠∅.

Let G be a group and   a family of subgroups of G.

sentence: A topological space is d-spherical if it is homotopy equivalent to a wedge of d-spheres; as a convention, we consider a singleton to be homotopy equivalent to a (trivial) wedge of n-spheres for all n.

sentence:
The opposition complex   is the simplicial complex whose simplices are of the form (σ,σ') with σ,σ'∈Δ, σσ'
and where the face relation is given by

    (τ,τ')≤ (σ,σ'):⇔τ≤σ and τ'≤σ'.

sentence:
A subgroup A of F_n is called a free factor , if there is a subgroup B≤ F_n such that F_n can be written as a free product F_n=A∗ B.

The free factor complex   is the simplicial complex whose vertices are proper free factors of F_n and where the vertices H_0,… ,H_k form a simplex if and only if they form a flag H_0≤ H_1≤…≤ H_k.

sentence:
Fix a basis b_1,…,b_n of F_n. This gives rise to a “standard-flag”

    C≪ b_1 <≪ b_1,b_2 <… < ≪ b_1,…,b_n-1

of free factors in F_.
Now analogously to the situation in buildings, we define a standard rank-  parabolic subgroup 
to be the stabiliser of a sub-flag of C that has length --1.
To match the numbering of Section <ref>, we use the corank to number the parabolic subgroups and define _--2 to be the set of standard rank-m parabolics.

sentence: For a given poset P=(V, ≤), let G_P=(V,E) be a graph with E={{u,v} | u≺ v   or v≺ u   or u∥ v }. Then we say that G_P is the cover-incomparability graph of P (or the C-I graph of P for short).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let  P=(V_P, ≤_P) be a poset.
   
   
   
  * We say that Q=(V_Q, ≤_Q) is a subposet of P=(V_P, ≤_P) if
   
   
  * V_Q ⊆ V_P and
   
  * for any u,v ∈ V_Q we have u ≤_Q v ⇔ u ≤_P v.
   



  * We say that R=(V_R, ≤ _R) is an isometric subposet of P=(V_P, ≤_P) if
   
 
  * V_R ⊆ V_P and
  
  * for any u,v ∈ V_R we have u ≤_R v ⇔ u ≤_P v and
   
  * for any u,v ∈ V_R such that u ≤_R v there exists a chain of a shortest length between u and v in P is also in R.
   


   
  * We say that S=(V_S, ≤_S) is a ≺-preserving subposet of P=(V_P, ≤_P) if
   
    
  * V_S ⊆ V_P and
  
  * for any u,v ∈ V_S we have u ≤_S v ⇔ u ≤_P v and
   
  * for any u,v ∈ V_S we have u ≺_S v ⇔ u ≺_P v.

for some unique ℓ≥ 1 and 1≤_1< <_ℓ=k, 0≤_1< <_ℓ=m.

to be the unordered increasing tree with v_1-decomposition given by

sentence: A {1,2,3}-decomposition of a matroid M̃ is a set of matroids ℳ (called the basic matroids ) and a rooted binary tree T in which M̃ is the root and the leaves are the elements of ℳ, with the property that every internal vertex is either the 1-, 2-, or 3-sum of its children.

sentence:
By a Zádori configuration of rank n∈ℕ, we mean an edge-colored graph F_n=a_0,a_1,…,a_n,b_0,…, b_n-1 with α-colored horizontal edges a_i-1a_i and b_j-1b_j for
i∈1,…,n and j∈1,…, n-1, β-colored vertical edges a_ib_i for i∈0,…, n-1, and γ-colored slanted edges (of slope 45^∘) 
 a_i-1b_i for i∈1,…, n; these edges are solid edges in our figures.  For example, F_6 is given in Figure <ref> but we have to disregard the dotted edges. 
We do not make a notational distinction between the graph and its vertex set, F_n. The colors α, β, and γ are also members of (F_n); we let a b∈α if there is an α-colored path from a to b in the graph, and we define the equivalences β,γ∈(F_n) analogously.

If r=3, then we call an edge e ∈ E(∂) fat if there are at least 2 distinct hyperedges h_1,h_2 with e ⊂ h_1,h_2.  If r>3, then we call an edge e ∈ E(∂) fat if there are at least k distinct hyperedges h_1,h_2,…,h_k in  with e ⊂ h_i for 1 ≤ i ≤ k. 




We call an edge e ∈ E(∂) thin if it is not fat.

sentence:
Fix a base point x_0 ∈ and let v_0 denote the corresponding vertex in the graph G. Choose a spanning tree ℬ for G, and let {e_1,…,e_b} denote the set of edges outside ℬ; choose an orientation on e_i. Let {γ_1,…,γ_b} denote a set of generators for the fundamental group of G, seen as closed walks based at v_0 through an isomorphism Γ→π_1(G,v_0), such that γ_i is a closed walk that passes through ℬ and γ_i, but not through γ_j for j ≠ i.  Choose an isomorphism α_b →Γ and set g_i:=α^-1(γ_i) as generators for _b. 
For γ∈Γ, let ℓ(γ) denote the length of the closed walk γ. 
If g ∈_b, we define the final edge τ(g) ∈ of g as follows: 
    τ(g)={[ e_i;; e_i; ].
 where g is written as a reduced word in the alphabet {g_i}. 
We also define the lifted final edge τ̂(g) ∈ of g to be the last occurence of a lift of τ(g) from G to  on the directed path from x_0 to α(g)(x_0) in .

Suppose Σ = {σ_1, …, σ_k }⊆(V) is a set of permutations on a set V. Define a directed, loopless multigraph G_Σ = (V,E) with a k-edge-colouring by putting a directed edge of colour i from u to v if and only if u ≠ v and (u)σ_i = v.

We also define the reduced graph G_Σ^0 to be the directed graph on V obtained by letting e = uv∈E(G_Σ^0) if and only if there is at least one directed edge from u to v in G_Σ.

sentence: Let G be a multigraph and E be a multiset of unordered pairs of elements of V(G). We denote by M(G,E) the set of (vertex sets of) components of G merged by E.

* We call p∈𝒫^∘∙_2,nb a bracket if p is projective, i.e. p=p^* and p^2=p, and if the lower row of p is a sector in p. 
             
  * The set of all brackets is denoted by B.

sentence:
Given p,p'∈𝒫^∘∙_2,nb and sectors S in p and S' in p', we number the points in (S) and (S') with respect to the cyclic order. We say that (p,S) and (p',S') are equivalent if the following four conditions are met:
	
		
  * The sectors S and S' are of equal size.
		
  * The same normalized colors occur in the same order in S and S'.
		
  * For all i, the point at position i in S belongs to a block crossing ∂ S in p if and only if the block of i-th point in S' crosses ∂ S' in p'. 
		
  * For all i,j, the points at positions i,j in S form a block in p if and only if the i-th and j-th points of S' constitute one of the blocks of p'.
                
                In other words: p restricted to S coincides with p' restricted to S' (up to rotation).

sentence:
*  
    Let  p be a bracket with lower row S.
    
    
  *  We call p residual of the first kind if p is connected and if (S) contains no turns of p.
    
  *  We call p residual of the second kind if p is connected and dualizable and if (S) contains exactly one turn of p.
    
  *  We call p residual if p is residual of the first or the second kind.
    
  
  * The set of all residual brackets is denoted by ℬ_res.

sentence:
We denote by () the set of all triples (a,b,U), where (a,b)∈, U⊆a,b, and a≠ b implies that a∉ U and b∈ U. We set U^=a,b∖ U, and
 
    abU=(x,y)a x y b ,
      x∉ U , and y∈ U ,   if a≠ b ,
    
     (a∪ U^)×
     (a∪ U) ,   if a=b ,

for each (a,b,U)∈(). Hence 
abU=∩(a∪ U^)×(b∪ U) in each case.


Observe that abU is bipartite iff a≠ b. If a=b,
we shall say that abU is a clepsydra .
[After “clessidra”, which is the Italian for “hourglass”,
  the latter describing the pattern of the associated transitive
  relation: the elements of U^ below; a in the middle; the
  elements of U above.]

sentence:
Let G be an r-graph on n vertices with average vertex degree d. Let τ >0. Given v∈ V(G) and 1≤ j≤ r, n, let

    d^(j)(v):= max{d(σ) : v∈σ⊆ V(G), |σ|=j }.

If d>0 we define δ_j= δ_j(τ) by the equation

    δ_j τ^j-1nd = ∑_v∈ V(G) d^(j)(v).

Then the co-degree function δ(G, τ) is defined by

    δ(G, τ):= 2^r2-1∑_j=2^r 2^-j-12δ_j.

If d=0 we define δ(G, τ):= 0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let p be a distribution on P_n□ P_2 and let A be a
  rung. An executable rubbling sequence S is called
  A-biased if each rubbling move that takes a pebble from
  A to another rung only use pebbles from the same vertex of
  A. So, if S is A-biased and (A,v w)∈ S
  where w ∉ V(A), then (A,v' w') ∉ S
  except in the case when w'=A. This also holds if we swap
  A and A.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The distribution we need to construct on G^R (mentioned on Page bizkezdet in the proof summary) is denoted by
  p^R, called reduced distribution .  It needs to satisfy
  the following conditions:


  * p^R(v)=p(v) or p^R(v)=p^R(w), if v is not contained by rung A or B and v and w contained in the same rung.

  * p^R(R)=p(R) if R is a rung other than A and B.

  * p^R(w)≥ p(w), if w is contained by rung A or B.

  * p^R(A)+p^R(A)+p^R(B)
+p^R(B)=p(A)+p(A)+p(B)
+p(B)+p(R)-2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let d(x,v) denote the distance between vertices x and v,
  i.e.  the length of the shortest path which connects them.  The
  weight-function of a vertex x with respect to pebble
  distribution p is:
  
    w_p(x)=∑_v∈ V(G)(1/2)^d(x,v)p (v).

  The left weight-function , denoted by Lw_p(x), is a similar
  function, the difference is that the summation is taken only for
  vertices that do not lie to the right of x (i.e. for vertices lying
  left and the other vertex of the rung containing x).  The
  right weight-function , denoted by Rw_p(x) is defined
  similarly.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let p be a distribution on the graph G=P_n□ P_2. Fix a
  vertex v and delete every vertex  located to the right of it. We get a
  shorter G'=P_m□ P_2 graph, m≤ n, which does not contain vertices located to the right
  of v. Let p' be a pebble distribution on G' such that
  p'(v)=p(v) for each vertex of G'. We say that v is left
    k-reachable in G if it is k-reachable in  G' under the
  distribution p'. Right k-reachability is defined similarly.
  Let L_p(v) (and R_p(v)) denote the maximum k for which v is
  left-k-reachable (right-k-reachable).

sentence:
The odometer u_G,Z(a,ρ, x) is the   number of visits to x strictly before hitting Z by the rotor walk with initial location a and initial rotor configuration ρ, i.e.

    u_G,Z(a,ρ, x):=|{t ≥ 0 | X_t=x }|.

sentence:
The Green function  
 _G,Z(a,x) is the expected number of visits to x  strictly before hitting Z by the simple random walk on G that starts at a.

sentence:
For any n≥ 1, 
we define

    S_G,Z,n(a,ρ,x):= ∑_i=0^n-1u_G,Z(a,σ^i(ρ), x),

if the rotor walks with ρ, σ(ρ),…, σ^n-1(ρ) as the initial rotor configuration are all transient,
and S_G,Z,n(a,ρ,x):=∞ otherwise.
That is, S_G,Z,n(a,ρ,x) is the  total  number of visits to x of n rotor walks performed without resetting the rotors in between walks.


The n-th occupation rate of the rotor walk  is  S_G,Z,n(a,ρ,x)/n.

sentence:
[Oriented spanning forest]

A Z-oriented spanning forest of G is an oriented subgraph F of G such that


  * Every vertex in Z has outdegree 0 in F;

  * Every vertex in G ∖ Z has outdegree 1 in F; and

  * F contains no directed cycles.

sentence:
[Oriented uniform spanning forest]

 The Z-oriented uniform spanning forest , denoted by (G,Z), is the uniform probability distribution on Z-oriented spanning forests of G.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Oriented spanning forests]
An oriented spanning forest of G is an oriented subgraph F of G such that


  * Every vertex of G has outdegree exactly 1 in F; and

  * There are no directed cycles in F.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Oriented wired uniform spanning forest]

The wired uniform spanning forest oriented toward infinity (G):= is the probability distribution on oriented subgraphs of G such that, for any finite subset B of directed edges of G, 

    [B ⊆ F]=lim_r →∞μ_r[B ⊆F_r],

where F is an oriented subgraph of G sampled from (G), and F_r is an Z_r-oriented subgraph of G_r sampled from μ_r.

sentence:
[Rotor walk stationarity]
A probability distribution μ on rotor configurations of G is rotor walk stationary with respect to  a given rotor walk if


  * For almost every rotor configuration ρ sampled from μ, the corresponding rotor walk is transient; and

  * If the initial configuration ρ is sampled from μ, then the final rotor configuration σ(ρ) also follows the law of μ.

We say a locally finite simple graph G
is S_1-out regular at x, if all vertices in S_1(x) have the same out degree.

sentence:
Let G = (V,E) be be a locally finite simple
  graph. An edge e ∈ E is called an (r,s)-bridge if the
  graph G decomposes after removal of the edge e = {x,y} into
  two separate non-empty components and if the degrees of the vertices
  x and y in each of the components after removal of e are r
  and s, respectively.

  and e ∈ E. The girth of e , denoted by girth(e)

  girth(e) = ∞.

sentence:
[Semi-strong coloring]
For a fixed c ≥ 2, a c-strong coloring of the hypergraph G is an assignment of colors
to its vertices such that each edge e of G covers vertices with at least min{c, |e|} distinct colors.
The c-strong chromatic number of G, denoted χ(G, c), is the minimum number of
colors required to c-strong color G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Chromatic number of intersecting hypergraphs]
Given two integers c ≥ 2 and t ≥ 0, the c-strong chromatic number of t-intersecting hypergraphs , denoted χ(t,c), is the minimum number of colors which suffices to c-strong color any t-intersecting hypergraph.
