sentence:
A simple weighted directed graph is an object Γ = (V, E, f). Here V is a set of vertices,

    E ⊂(a,b): a, b ∈ V

is a set of edges, the pair (a,b) being thought of as the edge from a to b, and

    f : E →ℕ

assigns to each edge an (integer) weight. To each such graph there corresponds a matrix A_Γ, which is square with row and columns indexed by V, and entries A_ab = f((a,b)) if (a,b) ∈ E and zero otherwise.

A graph is bipartite if we can decompose V = V_1 ⊔ V_2 so that the only edges (a,b) satisfy a ∈ V_1, b ∈ V_2 or vice versa. Equivalently, the matrix of a bipartite graph can be decomposed as

    A =
    [ 0 X; Y 0 ],

where X, Y are rectangular matrices.

In particular, we call the partition graph the graph with vertices V = P(n), the set of partitions of n, and (λ, μ) ∈ E if there are permutations α of cycle type λ and β of cycle type μ such that β = λτ, for τ a transposition. We define the weight function on the partition graph as

    f((λ, μ)) = t_λμz_μ/z_λ.

As already observed, the matrix corresponding to this graph is precisely A_n.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Denote by SP(N) the symmetric polynomials in N variables. One basis for this vector space are the power sum symmetric polynomials , defined by

    p_k(x_1, …, x_N) = ∑_i=1^N x_i^k

and, for a partition λ = 1^k_1 2^k_2…,

    p_λ = p_1^k_1 p_2^k_2….

Another basis for the same space are the Schur polynomials {s_λ}, also indexed by partitions. According to Corollary 7.17.5 in <cit.>,

    s_λ = ∑_ν1/z_νχ^λ(ν) p_ν.

This can be taken as the definition of χ^λ(ν), although these can also be computed using character values, or tableaux as in an Section <ref>. Incidentally, according to Corollary 7.17.4,

    p_ν = ∑_λχ^λ(ν) s_λ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For partitions λ = (λ_1, λ_2, …, λ_r) and 
μ = (μ_1, μ_2, …, μ_s), we define the dominance order  by
λμ if 

    λ_1 + λ_2 + ⋯λ_k ≤μ_1 + μ_2 + ⋯μ_k

for all k=1,2,…,r. 
In this case, we will say that μ dominates λ, or is more dominant
than λ.

sentence: If G is a quasiprimitive or a biquasiprimitive permutation group, then the socle (G) of G is isomorphic to a direct product T^l of isomorphic simple groups (where T is possibly abelian). We call T the socle factor of G.

sentence:
Let f:ℕ→ℕ. Then (Γ,G)∈𝒜(d) is said to be f-bounded if |G_α|≤ f(d) for every α∈ VΓ.  
Define f, f̃:ℕ→ℕ  by

    [                f(d)                   = (df(d)^d^df(d)^2d)!;               f̃(d)                   =               f(d');                     ]

where  d' is the unique element of ℕ such that (d'-1)(d'-2)<d≤ d'(d'-1).
For functions g_1,g_2:ℕ→ℕ and setting d_0=d(d-1),  define g_1∗ g_2:ℕ→ℕ  by 

    g_1∗ g_2(d)=(d_0(g_1(d_0)g_2(d_0))^d_0^d_0min{g_1(d_0),g_2(d_0)}^2d_0)!

sentence:
Let (Γ,G) be in 𝒜(d), and let N be a normal subgroup of G with N intransitive on VΓ. Let α^N denote the N-orbit containing α∈  VΓ. Then the normal quotient Γ_N is the graph whose vertices are the N-orbits on VΓ, with an edge between distinct vertices α^N and β^N if
and only if there is an edge of Γ between α' and β', for some α' ∈α^N and some β'∈β^N. The normal quotient is non-trivial if N1.

sentence: Let f_1,f_2:ℕ→ℕ be functions. Let Γ be a connected graph with every vertex of valency at most d and N≤(Γ). We say that (Γ,N) is (f_1,f_2)-bounded if the number of orbits of N on VΓ is at most f_1(d), and also |N_α|≤ f_2(d) for every α∈ VΓ.

sentence:
Let Γ be a G-vertex-transitive graph and Σ a system of imprimitivity for G in its action on VΓ. The quotient Γ_Σ is the graph whose vertices are the blocks σ of Σ, with an edge between two distinct blocks σ and η of Σ, if and only if there is an edge of Γ between α and β, for some α∈σ and some β∈η. 

The graph Γ_Σ is G-vertex-transitive but (despite the similarity with Definition <ref>) there is no upper bound on the valency of Γ_Σ in terms of  the valency of Γ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Axis-parallel decreasing walk]
We say that (x_ν)_1≤ν≤ k, x_ν∈^r, is a decreasing axis-parallel walk in ^r if for any two subsequent elements x_ν and x_ν+1 there is a coordinate s∈[r] such that x_ν+1,s<x_ν,s and x_ν+1,t=x_ν,t for all t∈[r]∖{s}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Extended walk, turning point, starting point/endpoint, segment, order]
Given some decreasing axis-parallel walk (x_ν)_1≤ν≤ k, x_ν∈^r, and some σ∈[r], we say that the pair ((x_ν)_1≤ν≤ k,σ) is an extended decreasing axis-parallel walk in ^r .
We refer to a point x_ν, 2≤ν≤ k-1, on this extended walk as a turning point if the coordinate in which x_ν differs from x_ν-1 is different from the coordinate in which x_ν differs from x_ν+1. We also define x_1 to be a turning point. Moreover, x_k is a turning point if and only if the coordinate in which x_k differs from x_k-1 is different from σ.

Given two consecutive turning points x_μ and x_ν, μ<ν, that differ in some coordinate s∈[r], we refer to the line segment that connects them as an s-segment , and we call x_μ the starting point and x_ν the endpoint of this segment. Furthermore, we refer to the line segment that connects the last turning point x_μ to the last point x_k of the walk as a σ-segment (if μ=k, this segment degenerates to a single point x_k). We call x_μ the starting point and x_k the endpoint of this segment.

For two points x_μ and x_ν, we say that x_μ is higher on the walk than x_ν (or equivalently, x_ν is lower on the walk than x_μ) if μ<ν. We extend this notion to segments on the extended walk by saying that an s-segment Γ is higher on the walk than an s'-segment Γ' (or equivalently, Γ' is lower than Γ) if the starting point of Γ is higher on the walk than the starting point of Γ'.

sentence:
The abelian complexity function ρ_𝐰: ℕ→ℕ of 𝐰 is defined by

    ρ_𝐰(n) := # (ℱ_𝐰(n)/∼_ab).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let k≥ 2 be an integer. The k-kernel of an infinite sequence 𝐰=(w(n))_n≥ 0 is the set of sub-sequences

    𝐊_k(𝐰):={ (w(k^en + c))_n ≥ 0 | e ≥ 0,0 ≤ c < k^e} .

𝐰 is k-automatic if 𝐊_k(𝐰) is finite. If the ℤ-module generated by its k-kernel is
finitely generated, then 𝐰=(w(n))_n≥ 0 is k-regular .
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
A configuration f is called compact if any two of the first n-1 entries differ by at most n, that is:
max_1≤ i,j ≤ n-1|f_i-f_j|≤ n.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The skew cylinder C_n of circumference 2n-1 is obtained from the usual two dimensional grid ℤ^2 by identifying two vertices of coordinates (i,j) and (i',j') if and only if (i',j') = (i,j)+k(n,n-1) for some k∈ℤ also denoted (i,j)∼_(n,n-1) (i',j').
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(of labeling and spiral traversal of vertices in a skew cylinder)
Label  0 the origin of the skew cylinder and then from the vertex labeled  i, the vertices of label i+1, and  i-1 are obtained by a diagonal north-east step (+1,+1) for the first and  a south-west step (-1,-1) for the second.
Hence, the visit of vertices in increasing order according to the label in ℤ describes what we call a spiral traversal of the vertices.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence: A doubly pointed cut skew cylinder C_n[w](s,x) is defined by a triplet (w,s,x)∈ D_n×ℤ×ℤ where s and x  describe a pointer on the vertices with  labels s and respectively x in the cut skew cylinder C_n[w].
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(shift and flip on skew cylinders)

The unit diagonal shift on ℤ^2 is defined by  shift((i,j))=(i+1,j+1).
This symmetry is compatible with the equivalence ∼_(n,n-1) defining C_n hence induces 
a shift with similar notations on skew cylinder C_n.

The flip symmetry flip((i,j))=(-i,-j) on the two dimensional grid ℤ^2 is also compatible with the relation ∼_(n,n-1) hence induces a flip with similar notations on skew cylinder C_n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Cut the n ≥ 2 card deck into a piles by picking pile sizes
  according to the mult(a;p = (p_1,…,p_a)) distribution.
That is, choose b_1,…,b_a with probability
nb_1,…,b_aΠ_i=1^a p_i^b_i. Then choose
uniformly one of  the nb_1,…,b_a ways of interleaving
the packets, leaving the cards in each pile in their original order.
The resulting probability distribution on S_n is called the
p-biased riffle shuffle distribution and is denoted by
P_n,p. When p is the uniform distribution over [a]:{1,2,…,a} for some a ∈ℕ, we write  P_n,a to denote the resulting distribution and call
the resulting shuffle  an a-shuffle .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
The Ĳ-associahedron _I, J() is a polyhedral complex whose poset of cells is anti-isomorphic to the poset of interior faces of the Ĳ-Tamari complex. 
In particular, 


  * Its faces correspond to covering Ĳ-forests.

  * Its vertices correspond to Ĳ-trees.

  * Two vertices are connected if and only if the corresponding trees are connected by a flip. That is, the edge graph of _I, J() is isomorphic to the Hasse diagram of the Ĳ-Tamari lattice.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Ĳ-cyclohedron _I, J() is a polyhedral complex whose poset of cells is anti-isomorphic to the poset of interior faces of the cyclic Ĳ-Tamari complex. 
In particular, 


  * Its faces correspond to covering cyclic Ĳ-forests.

  * Its vertices correspond to cyclic Ĳ-trees.

  * Two vertices are connected if and only if the corresponding cyclic trees are connected by a flip. That is, the edge graph of _I, J() is isomorphic to the Hasse diagram of the cyclic Ĳ-Tamari poset.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let A ⊂. T(A) is the number of ordered collinear triples in A × A. That is ordered triples (u,v,w) ∈ (A × A) ×  (A × A) ×  (A × A) such that u, v and w are all incident to the same line. Q(A) is the number of ordered collinear quadruples in A × A.

sentence:
Two point sets A, B⊂ℝ^2 are called separated if (A)∩(B)=∅. Two separated m-element sets, A and B, are said to form an -avoiding pair for some ≥0 if  
    ι(A,<_B)+ι(B,<_A)≤ m^2.
 For simplicity, a 0-avoiding pair is called avoiding . See Figure <ref> (left).

sentence: Given a geometric graph G=(V,E) and a number δ≥ 0, a pair {A,B} of disjoint m-element subsets of V is δ-dense with respect to G if |E(A,B)|≥δ m^2.

sentence:
A filling σ : λ→ [n] is called non-attacking if σ(u)σ(v) whenever  u and v attack each other. 
Let 𝒯(λ,n) denote the set of non-attacking fillings.

sentence:
The maj and inv statistics on fillings σ are defined by

    (σ):=∑_u∈(σ)(u) ,     (σ):=| Inv(σ)|-∑_u∈(σ)(u) .

sentence:
<cit.>
An alcove path is a sequence of alcoves
 such that any two consecutive ones are adjacent. 
We say that an alcove path (A_0,A_1,…,A_m) is reduced if m is the minimal 
length of all alcove paths from A_0 to A_m.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An alcove walk is a sequence 
Ω=(A_0,F_1,A_1, F_2, … , F_m, A_m, F_∞) 
such that A_0,…, A_m are alcoves; 
F_i is a codimension one common face of the alcoves A_i-1 and A_i,
for i=1,…,m; and 
F_∞ is a vertex of the last alcove A_m. The weight F_∞ is called the weight of the alcove walk, and is denoted by μ(Ω).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A folding position j of the alcove walk Ω=(A_0,F_1,A_1, F_2, … , F_m, A_m, F_∞) is called a positive folding if the alcove A_j-1=A_j lies on the positive side of the affine hyperplane containing the face F_j. Otherwise, the folding position is called a negative folding .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: The filling map is the map f from folding pairs (w,T) to fillings σ=f(w,T) of the shape λ, defined by σ(i,j):=π_j(i).

sentence: The filling map is the map f from positive folding pairs (w,T) to fillings σ=f(w,T) of the shape λ, defined by C_ij=π_ij[1,λ_i'] and C_ik'=π_ik'[1,λ_i'].
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
group
arithmetic progression 

Let G be a group and A ⊆ G with |A|=k.  Then A is a
group arithmetic progression if there exists both g and h in
G such that A = { g + ih | 1 ≤ i < k }.

sentence:
Given a matrix, a critical set is 
a collection of rows whose sum is all-even 
(i.e., the sum is the 0 vector in ).

sentence:
If s_i ∈ supp(w), we say that s_i supports w.  We also
say that column i supports w.  If w is fully commutative and 
connected then supp(w) = {s_i, s_i+1, …, s_j}
for some i, j, and since every minimal pair of entries in the heap of w has
a distinct resolution we must have exactly one entry in columns i and j of
the heap.  In this situation, we call columns i+1, i+2, …, j-1 the internal columns of the heap of w and we call columns i and j the extremal columns of the heap of w.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A class  of graphs admits low rank-width colorings
if there exist functions N:→ and 
Q:→ such that for all p∈, every graph 
G∈ can be vertex colored with at most 
N(p) colors such that the union of any i≤ p
color classes induces a subgraph of rank-width at most Q(i).
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a graph, X⊆ V(G) and r≥ 2. 
A superset X'⊇ X is called an r-shortest path hitter for X
if for all u,v∈ X with 1<_G(u,v)≤ r, X' contains an internal vertex of some shortest path between u and v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a graph, let c be a coloring of G, and r≥ 2 
and d≥ 1. A coloring c' is a (d,r)-good refinement of c
if for every vertex set X that receives at most p colors under c', 
there exists an r-shortest path hitter X' of X that receives at 
most d· p colors under c.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a graph, let X⊆ V(G), and let r≥ 1 be an integer.
A superset X'⊇ X is called an r-shortest path closure of X 
	if for each u,v∈ X with _G(u,v)=ℓ≤ r, G[X'] contains a path  of length ℓ between u and v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: an r-shortest path closure of X

sentence:
Let G be a graph, let c be a coloring of G, and let r≥ 2 and d≥ 1. 
	A coloring c' is a (d,r)-excellent refinement of c if for every vertex set X⊆ V(G) 
	there exists an r-shortest path closure X' of X such that if X receives p colors in c', then X' receives at most d· p colors in c.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a positive integer n, a graph on the set of 3n^2 vertices A∪ B∪ C, where
A={v_1, …, v_n^2}, B={w_1, …, w_n^2}, and C={z_(i,j) 1≤ i,j≤ n}, is called a twisted chain graph of order n
if 


  * for integers x,y, i, j∈{1, …, n} and k=n(x-1)+y, 
v_k is adjacent to z_(i,j) if and only if either 
(x<i) or (x=i and y≤ j);

  * for integers x,y, i, j∈{1, …, n} and k=n(x-1)+y,
w_k is adjacent to z_(i,j) if and only if either
(x<j) or 
(x=j and y≤ i);

  * the edge relation within A∪ B and within C is arbitrary.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  Given a weak composition a, the monomial slide polynomial _a is defined by
    
    _a = ∑_b ≥ a 
    (b) = (a) x^b.

[<cit.>]
  Given a weak composition a, the fundamental slide polynomial _a is defined by
  
    _a = ∑_b ≥ a 
    (b)  refines (a) x^b.

sentence:
Given a weak composition a, a quasi-key tableau of shape a is a filling of D(a) with positive integers satisfying


  * entries weakly decrease along rows, and no entry of row i exceeds i

  * entries in any column are distinct, and entries increase up the first column

  * if an entry i is above an entry k in the same column with i<k, then there is a label j immediately right of k, with i<j

  * Given two rows with the higher row strictly longer, then if entry i is in column c of the lower row and entry j in column c+1 of the higher row, then  i<j.

Denote the set of quasi-key tableaux of shape a by (a); for example, see Figure <ref>. Moreover, let ^(1)(a) be all quasi-key tableaux of shape a whose first column entries are equal to their row index.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a weak composition a, the quasi-key polynomial _a is defined by
  
    _a = ∑_T ∈(a) x^(T).

sentence:
Given a weak composition a, the column quasi-key polynomial ^(1)_a is defined by
  
    ^(1)_a = ∑_T ∈^(1)(a) x^(T).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  A quasi-key tableau is quasi-Yamanouchi if the leftmost occurrence of each entry i is either
  
  
  * in row i, or
  
  * weakly left of some entry i+1.
  
  Denote the set of quasi-Yamanouchi quasi-key tableaux of shape a by (a).

sentence:
Let a be a weak composition. A slide of a is a weak composition that can be obtained from a via a sequence of local moves of the form

    … 0k …→… ij …

where i+j = k and i,j≥ 0. A fixed slide of a is a weak composition that can be obtained from a via a sequence of the above local moves subject to an additional condition:  that if k occupies a position that is nonzero in a, then j>0. Let (a) denote the set of all slides of a and (a) the set of all fixed slides of a.

sentence:
A semi-skyline filling T∈(a) is particle-highest if for every i that appears as an entry in T, either 


  * the leftmost i is in the first column, or 

  * there is an i^↑ in some column weakly to the right of the leftmost i, where i^↑ is the smallest label greater than i appearing in T. 

Let (a) denote the set of particle-highest elements of (a).

sentence:
Cauchy-Schwarz inequality(from <cit.>, Theorem 3.14)Let f,g∈ℱ^σ, then

    f^2_σ· g^2_σ≥ fg_σ^2.

In particular (g=1_σ),

    f^2_σ·σ≥ f_σ^2,

which in turn implies

    f^2_σ≥ 0.
word_labels: B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G=(V,E) be a connected graph. A vertex v ∈ V is resolved by S={v_1,…,v_n}⊂ V if the ordered list (d(v,v_1),d(v,v_2),…,d(v,v_n)) is unique. S is a resolving set for G if it resolves all the elements of V. The metric dimension μ(G) of G is the size of a smallest resolving set for it. A metric basis of G is a resolving set for G of size μ(G).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let s and t be positive integers. 

A point-line incidence geometry 𝒢=(𝒫, ℒ, I)

is a generalized quadrangle of order (s,t) if it satisfies the following axioms.




  (GQ1)

Each point is incident with t+1 lines and two distinct points are incident with at most one line.


  (GQ2) 

Each line is incident with s+1 points and two distinct lines are incident with at most one point.


  (GQ3)

If (P,ℓ )⊂𝒫×ℒ is a non-incident point-line pair then there is 

a unique pair (P',ℓ ')⊂𝒫×ℒ for which

P I ℓ ' I  P' I ℓ.

sentence: A triple (x,y,z) of points is called a triad if no two of them are collinear. A point u is a center of a triad if u is collinear with each of the three points of the triad.

[<cit.>]

    F_D(X) = ∑_i_1 ≤⋯≤ i_n 
     j∈ D ⇒ i_j < i_j+1 x_i_1⋯ x_i_n .

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  The Schur function for λ is
  
    s_λ(X) = ∑_T ∈SYT(λ) F_(w(T))(X),

  where SYT(λ) is the set of standard Young tableaux of shape λ.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  Given a partition μ, define the μ-descent set of w , denoted by Des_μ(w), to be the set of cells of μ such that the w-entry is strictly greater than the w-entry immediately below in μ. Define the μ-major index of w , denoted by _μ(w), by
  
    _μ(w) = ∑_c∈Des_μ(w)leg(c)+1 ,

  where leg(c) is the number of cells strictly above c in μ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: μ-descent set of w;μ-major index of w

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  Given a partition μ, define the μ-inversion set of w , denoted by Inv_μ(w), to be the set of pairs (w_i>w_j) with i<j and either w_i and w_j are in the same row, or w_j is one row lower and strictly left. Define the μ-inversion number of w , denoted by _μ(w), by
  
    _μ(w) = |Inv_μ(w)| - ∑_c∈Des_μ(w)arm(c) ,

  where arm(c) is the number of cells strictly right of c in μ.

plain_text_term: μ-inversion set of w;μ-inversion number of w

sentence:
[<cit.>]

    H_μ(X;q,t) = ∑_w ∈𝔖_n q^_μ(w) t^_μ(w) F_(w)(X) .

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  Define the elementary dual equivalence involution d_i, 1<i<n, on permutations w as follows. If i lies between i-1 and i+1 in w, then d_i(w)=w. Otherwise, d_i interchanges i and whichever of i± 1 is further away from i.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  Define the elementary twisted dual equivalence involution d_i, 1<i<n, on permutations w as follows. If i lies between i-1 and i+1 in w, then d_i(w)=w. Otherwise, d_i cyclically rotates i-1,i,i+1 so that i lies on the other side of i-1 and i+1.

sentence:
We call a row or column of a 0-1 matrix or Ferrers diagram non-zero if it contains at least one 1 element.
We say that a 0-1 matrix or Ferrers diagram is complete , if all of its columns are non-zero.

sentence:
An (n,k)-Callan sequence is a sequence (R_1,C_1),…,(R_m,C_m) for some m∈_0 such that R_1,…,R_m are pairwise disjoint nonempty subsets of {1,…,n},
and C_1,…,C_m are pairwise disjoint nonempty subsets of {1,…,k}. The set of (n,k)-Callan sequences is denoted by (n,k).

sentence:
In a 0-1 matrix or Ferrers diagram, we call an element 1 top-1 if it is the highest 1 in its column.
For an n× k 0-1 matrix M, the set of positions of top 1's is denoted by top(M), i.e.

    top(M):={(i,j)∈{1,…,n}×{1,…,k}: M_ij is a top-1 in M},

where M_ij is the element in the i^th row and j^th column of M, with respect to Convention <ref>.

sentence:
For a given Ferrers shape , on -Callan sequence we mean a sequence (R_1,C_1),…,(R_m,C_m) for some m∈_0 such that


  * R_1,…,R_m are pairwise disjoint non­empty subsets of L_r(),

  * C_1,…,C_m are pairwise disjoint nonempty subsets of L_c(), and 

  * max R_i < min C_i, for all i=1,…,m.

The set of -Callan sequences is denoted by ().
We say that an -Callan sequence (R_1,C_1),…,(R_m,C_m) is complete , if 
∪_i=1^m C_i = L_c(), i.e. if {C_1,C_2,…,C_m} is a partition of L_c().
For example, if  is the Ferrers shape from Figure <ref>, then the sequence

    ({3},{4,7,10}), ({1},{2,5,6,12}), ({8,11},{13})

is a complete -Callan sequence.
The set of complete -Callan sequences is denoted by ().

sentence:
An n-permutation is a permutation of the integers {1, 2,…,n}. Fix an n-permutation α=a_1a_2… a_n.
We say that the element a_i is an ascent bottom of α, if i≤ n-1 and a_i<a_i+1.
We say that the element a_i is a descent top of α, if i≤ n-1 and a_i>a_i+1.
The set of ascent bottom elements and the set of descent top elements of α are denoted by A(α) and D(α), respectively.
Note that A(α)∪̇D(α)={1,2,…,n}∖{a_n}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a Ferrers shape  with semiperimeter s, 
an -Dumont permutation is an (s+1)-permutation δ=d_1d_2… d_s+1, such that
d_s+1=s+1 and A(δ)=L_r(). We note that these conditions also imply that D(δ)=L_c().

For example, if  is the Ferrers shape from Figure <ref>, then

    5,4,2,1,9,13,8,12,10,7,6,3,11,14

is an -Dumont permutation.
The set of -Dumont permutations is denoted by ().

sentence:
The unsigned Genocchi number |G_2n+2| counts the number of those (2n+1)-permutations α for which


  * the last element of α is 2n+1,

  * A(α)={1,3,5,…,2n-1}, and

  * D(α)={2,4,6,…,2n},

where A(α) and D(α) are the ascent bottom and descent top sets defined in Definition <ref>.
We note that permutations satisfying the above conditions are called (classical) Dumont permutations of the first kind
in the literature.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence: [trivial]We say a degree sequence is trivial if its maximum element is less than k. Otherwise it is nontrivial .

sentence:
[elementary step]
Let D and E be multisets such that for some positive integers x and y

    
  (i)
D is obtained from E by first performing an (x-1)-increment and then performing a (y-1)-increment where x ≤ y ≤max(E)+1; or
    
  (ii)
D is obtained from E by first performing an x-decrement and then performing a (y-1)-increment where either x > max(k,y) or x < y ≤ k.

We say that D is obtained from E by an elementary step .  We call a
step of type (i) an (x,y)-addition step and a step of type (ii) an
(x,y)-transfer step .

sentence:
[Butterfly Minor]
		
		Let D be a .
		An edge e=u,v∈D is butterfly-contractible if e is the only outgoing edge of u or the only incoming edge of v.
		
		In this case the graph D' obtained from D by butterfly contracting e is the graph with vertex set D∖u,v∪x_u,v, where x_u,v is a new vertex and the edge set
		
    D   ∖ee ∼ u  or  e ∼ v
       ∪w,x_u,vw,u∈D or w,v∈D
       ∪x_u,v,wu,w∈D or v,w∈D.

		
		We denote the result of butterfly contracting an edge e in D by D/e.
		
		A D' is a butterfly-minor of D if it can be obtained from a subgraph of D by butterfly contractions.

sentence:
[Properties of empty 4-simplices, <cit.>]

 


  * There are infinitely many lattice empty 4-simplices of width 1 (e.g., cones over empty tetrahedra) and of width 2 <cit.>. 

  * Among the simplices of determinant ≤ 1600 there are 178 of width three, one of width four, and none of larger width, and their maximum determinant is 179. The computation up to determinant 1000 was done by Haase and Ziegler <cit.> and the extension up to 1600 by Perriello <cit.>.

  * The total amount of empty lattice 4-simplices of width greater than 2 is finite <cit.>. 

  * Every empty 4-simplex is cyclic <cit.>. The same is not true in dimension five.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let P be a cyclic lattice 4-simplex of determinant D and let u∈_D^4. We say that the quintuple u generates P if the barycentric coordinates of every element in ^4/Λ(P) with respect to P are multiples of u (modulo D). That is, if the point of ^4/Λ(P) with barycentric coordinates 1/Du is a generator for the cyclic group ^4/Λ(P).

sentence:
For T a Young tableau with columns C^1, C^2 … , C^m where C^i = c^i_1, c^i_2, …, c^i_k with c^i_j being the (j,i)th entry of T, we define the column reading word of T to be the word τ(T) = C^m C^m-1… C^1. 
Note if T is row and column strict then P(τ(T)) = T and each column of Q(τ(T)) has consecutive entries.
For w a reduced word, we define τ(w) to be  τ(P(w)). 
By the previous observation, w and τ(w) are Coxeter-Knuth equivalent.

sentence:
Given a graph G, we define its adjacency polytope to be
    
    ∇_G =
            (∇_G,1∪⋯∪∇_G,n) =
            ( {± (𝐞_i-𝐞_j) | (i,j) ∈ E(G) }).

    The normalized volume (∇_G) is called the
    adjacency polytope bound of G.

sentence:
The well-known recursive sequence (<cit.>) of pairwise coprime natural numbers b_0:=2, b_n:=1+b_0⋯ b_n-1 (n ≥ 1) is called Sylvester Sequence .
	It starts as b_0=2, b_1=3, b_2=7, b_3=43, b_4=1807.

sentence:
<cit.> Two vertices that are not adjacent in a graph G
are said to be independent . A set S of vertices is independent if any two vertices of S are independent. The vertex independence number or simply the independence number , of a graph G, denoted by  α(G) is the maximum cardinality among
the independent sets of vertices of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: <cit.> A subset M of the  edge set of G, is called a matching in G if no two of the edges in M are adjacent. In other words, if for any two edges e and f in M, both the end vertices of e are different from the end vertices of f.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: <cit.> A perfect matching of a graph G is a matching of G containing n/2 edges, the largest possible, meaning perfect matchings are only possible on graphs with an even number of vertices.  A perfect matching sometimes called a complete matching or 1-factor.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: <cit.> The matching number of a graph G, denoted by ν(G), is the size of a maximal independent edge set. It is also known as edge independence number . The matching number ν(G)  satisfies the inequality ν(G)≤⌊n/2⌋. Equality occurs only for a perfect matching and graph G has a perfect matching if and only if |G|=2 ν(G), where |G|=n is the vertex count of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: <cit.>A maximum independent set in a line graph corresponds to maximum matching in the original graph.

sentence: <cit.> For n≥ 3, a wheel graph W_n+1 is the graph K_1+ C_n.  A wheel graph W_n+1 has n+1 vertices and 2n edges.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: <cit.> Helm graphs are graphs obtained from a wheel by attaching one pendant edge to each vertex of the cycle.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: <cit.> An n-sun or a trampoline , denoted by S_n, is a chordal graph on 2n vertices, where n ≥ 3, whose vertex set can be partitioned into two sets U = {u_1, u_2, u_3, . . . , u_n} and W = {w_1, w_2, w_3, . . . , w_n} such that U is an independent set of G and u_i is adjacent to w_j if and only if j = i or j = i + 1 (n). A complete sun is a sun G where the induced subgraph  ⟨ U⟩ is complete.

sentence: <cit.> The armed crown is a graph G obtained by adjoining a path P_m to every vertex of a cycle C_n.

sentence:
Let (X,T) be a system. The points  x_1,x_2∈ X are proximal if

    inf_n∈d(T^nx_1,T^nx_2)=0.

A set F⊂  X is proximal if every pair of points in F is proximal.

We say that the factor map π (X,T)→ (Y,S) is  a proximal extension if the fiber π({y_0}) of every y_0∈ Y is proximal.

sentence: Recall that a set E⊂ is syndetic if there exists r≥ 1 such that every interval of length r contains at least one element of E. The smallest integer r with this property is called the syndeticity constant of E.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let r≥ 2.
A set S of integers is r-syndetic large if every syndetic set with syndeticity constant less than or equal to r contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions with step in S.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For n≥ b≥ 1, an (n,b)-domino tower is a fixed polyomino created by sequentially placing n-b dominoes horizontally on a convex, horizontal base composed of b dominoes, such that if a non-base domino is placed in position indexed by {(x,y),(x+1,y)}, then there must be a domino in position {(x-1,y-1), (x,y-1)}, {(x,y-1), (x+1,y-1)}, or {(x+1,y-1), (x+2,y-1)}.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a convex domino tower, identify the row of maximum length, b, which is at minimum level ℓ≥ 0.  For some n≥ 0, the tower of n blocks consisting of all dominoes on levels strictly less than ℓ is called a supporting (n,b)-domino tower .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A (n,b)-domino stack is a convex domino tower of n dominoes with base b dominoes such that all columns of the polyomino intersect the base.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A right-skewed (n,b)-domino tower is parallelogram (n,b)-domino tower such that there exists at least one column of the polyomino to the right of the base that does not intersect the base of the polyomino.  Similarly, define a left-skewed (n,b)-domino tower to be a reflection of a right-skewed domino tower across a vertical axis.

sentence: A set of tilings is said to be sofic if it can be seen as the set of τ-tilings of some finite tileset τ.

sentence:
A combinatorial substitution is a finite set of rules (P,Q,γ), where P is a tile, Q is a finite connected tiling, and γ:∂ P→∂ Q maps distinct facets on disjoint sets of facets.
The tiling Q is called a macro-tile , and if f is the k-th facet of P, then γ(f) is called the k-th macro-facet of Q.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let σ be a combinatorial substitution.
A tiling T by tiles of σ and a tiling T' by macro-tiles of σ are said to be σ-related if there is a one-to-one correspondence between the tiles of T and the macro-tiles of T' which preserves the combinatorial structure, that is, such that the a-th facet of a first tile of T matches the b-th facet of a second tile of T if and only if the a-th macro-facet of the first corresponding macro-tile of T' matches the b-th macro-facet of the second corresponding macro-tile of T'.
One calls T a preimage of T' and T' an image of T.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: The limit set of a combinatorial substitution σ, denoted by Λ_σ, is the set of complete tilings which admit an infinite sequence of preimages.

sentence: Let η≥ 0 and let G be a balanced bipartite graph on 2n vertices.  Let c:E(G)→{1,2} be a 2-coloring of the edges of G.  We say that c is an η-extremal coloring if there exists X'⊆ X and a partition {Y_1, Y_2} of Y such that |X'|, |Y_1|, |Y_2|≥ (1/2-η)n, e_R(X', Y_1)≤η n^2, and e_B(X',Y_2)≤η n^2.

sentence:
<cit.>



  (i) A configuration (v_r,b_k) is an incidence structure of v
points and b lines such that each line contains k points, each point
lies on r lines, and two distinct points are connected by at most
one line.


  (ii) If v=b and, hence, r=k, the configuration
    is symmetric , and it is referred to as a
    configuration v_k.


  (iii) The deficiency d of a configuration (v_r,b_k) is
the value d=v-r(k-1)-1.

sentence:
<cit.>



  (i) A Golomb ruler G_k of order k is an
ordered set of k integers (a_1,a_2,… ,a_k) such that 0≤
a_1<a_2<… <a_k and all the differences {a_i-a_j | 1≤
j<i≤ k} are distinct. The length L_G(k) of the
ruler G_k is equal to a_k-a_1.


  (ii) A Golomb ruler G_k is an
    optimal Golomb ruler OG_k if no
    shorter Golomb ruler of the same order k exists. Let
    L_OG(k) and L_G(k)
    be the length of an optimal ruler OG_k and
of the shortest known Golomb ruler G_k, respectively.


  (iii) A (v,k) modular Golomb ruler is an ordered set of k
integers (a_1,a_2,… ,a_k) such that 0≤ a_1<a_2<…
<a_k and all the differences {a_i-a_j | 1≤ i,j≤ k; i≠
j} are distinct and nonzero modulo v.

and let v_k be a symmetric configuration. Let

d. We say that 𝐌(v,k) has Structure E if
every d× d block is either a permutation matrix 𝐏_d or the zero d× d matrix
0_d.

sentence: In the sequel an expression of a morphism g between basic bimodules means a sequence (^i_ωd_ω, … , ^i_1d_1), with d_i∈Lo, such that ^i_ωd_ω∘⋯∘ ^i_1d_1 =g. If ν is an expression of g, we define ν=g, and we say that ν is representing g. An R-expression is an expression representing a morphism from a basic bimodule to R. Sometimes we will consider a good g-expression simply like an expression in the obvious way.  Finally, if we consider a formal 𝒜-linear combination of expressions ν=∑_i∈ Iλ_iν_i, with λ_i∈𝒜, we define ν=∑_i∈ Iλ_iν_i

sentence:
(Transfer)

Consider the space T(W) of all paths of the permutation tree W. The operation λ that sends the permutation g∈ S_n of level n by translation to permutation h∈ S_n-1 of level n-1 induces the map Λ:T(W)→ T(W): the path {g_1,g_2,g_3 …} goes to the path {λ(g_2),λ(g_3), …}; we call this operation Λ transfer on the tree W. Because g≺ h gives λ(g)≺λ(h)   (two removals commute), this operation defines the mapping of the paths of our tree.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
A transformation
  
    Λ: T(Γ)→ T(Γ)

  is called a transfer if it is continuous
   in compact topology of the space of paths, and satisfies the following locality property: for each path t={t_n}_n∈ T(Γ)  its image is the path Λ(t)≡{t'_n} that is defined inductively:
  this means that the edge t'_n depends on the fragment of initial path {t_k}_1^n+1 and on the end of the previous edge t'_n-1.

  We say that a transfer is Markov if the fragment above reduces to the pair of edges {t_k}_n^n+1.

sentence:
Let c_0, c_1, …, c_n-1∈ and A ∈ M_m(𝔽_q).
Given any n-tuple (𝐬_0, …, 𝐬_n-1) of
elements of  𝔽_q^m, let (𝐬_i)_i=0^∞
denote the infinite sequence of elements of 𝔽_q^m
determined by the following linear recurrence relation:

    𝐬_i+n=𝐬_i(c_0A)+𝐬_i+1(c_1A)
              +⋯ +𝐬_i+n-1(c_n-1A)
                 i=0,1,….

The system (<ref>) is a transformation shift register
(TSR) of order n over 𝔽_q^m, while the sequence
(𝐬_i)_i=0^∞ is the sequence generated
by the TSR (<ref>).


  * The n-tuple (𝐬_0,𝐬_1,…, 𝐬_n-1) is the initial state of the TSR.

  * The polynomial I_mX^n -(c_n-1A)X^n-1- ⋯ -(c_1A)X-(c_0A) with matrix coefficients is the tsr-polynomial
		of the TSR (<ref>). Here I_m denotes the m× m identity matrix over .

  * The sequence (𝐬_i)_i=0^∞ is ultimately periodic if there are integers r, n_0 with
		r≥ 1 and n_0≥0 such that 𝐬_j+r=𝐬_j for all j ≥ n_0.

  * The least positive integer r with this property is the period of (𝐬_i)_i=0^∞
and the corresponding least nonnegative integer n_0 is the preperiod of (𝐬_i)_i=0^∞. The sequence
(𝐬_i)_i=0^∞ is periodic if its preperiod is 0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
Let M be a matroid.
A fan of M is an
ordered sequence, (e_1,…, e_n),
of n≥ 3 distinct elements such that

    {e_1,e_2,e_3},
    {e_2,e_3,e_4},…,
    {e_n-2,e_n-1,e_n}

is an alternating sequence of triangles and triads.

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a graph and let ℬ be a set of circuits.
We define the group Γ(G,ℬ) via the presentation

    Γ(G,ℬ) = ⟨E⃗ | ℬ⟩,

i.e., Γ(G,ℬ) is generated by the oriented edges and each circuit C=(x_1,…,x_n) ∈ℬ gives a relation
(x_1x_2) … (x_n-1x_n)(x_n x_1) = e_Γ where we identify (xy)=(yx)^-1∈E⃗.
There is a natural gain function ϕ_ℬ  given by the natural mapping of E⃗ into Γ(G,ℬ), and the corresponding gain graph (G,ϕ_ℬ,Γ(G,ℬ)) is called the canonical gain graph associated with the biased graph (G,ℬ).

sentence:
A subset ℬ⊂(G,) is called an -cycle basis of G if ℬ is a vector space basis of  (G,).
In the literature, a -cycle basis is also called a directed cycle basis and an _2-cycle basis is also called an undirected cycle basis.

sentence:
A set ℬ = {C_1, . . . , C_r}⊂𝒞(G,) of oriented circuits of a graph G is an integral cycle basis of G if every oriented circuit C of G can be written as an integer linear combination of circuits in ℬ, i.e., there exist λ_i ∈ s.t.

    C= λ_i C_i + … + λ_r C_r.

sentence: A -cycle basis ℬ = {C_1, . . . , C_r}⊂𝒞(G,) of a graph G is a totally unimodular cycle basis of G if its cycle matrix M(ℬ, ) is totally unimodular, i.e., each sub determinant is either 0 or ± 1.

sentence:
A set ℬ = {C_1,…,C_r} of circuits  of a graph G is a weakly fundamental cycle basis of G if there exists some permutation σ such that for all i=2,…,r,

    C_σ(i)∖ (C_σ(1)∪…∪ C_σ(i-1)) ≠∅.

sentence: A set ℬ of circuits of a graph G is a strictly fundamental cycle basis of G, if there exists some spanning tree T ⊆ E such that ℬ = {C_e : e ∈ E ∖ T }, where C_e denotes the unique circuit in T ∪{e}.

sentence:
[Canonical gain graph]
Let G=(V,E) be a graph and let ℬ be a set of circuits.
We define the group Γ(G,ℬ) via the presentation

    Γ(G,ℬ) = ⟨E⃗ | ℬ⟩,

i.e., Γ(G,ℬ) is generated by the oriented edges and each circuit C=(x_1,…,x_n) ∈ℬ gives a relation
(x_1x_2) … (x_n-1x_n)(x_n x_1) = e_Γ where we identify (xy)=(yx)^-1∈E⃗.
There is a natural gain function ϕ_ℬ  given by the natural mapping of E⃗ into Γ(G,ℬ), and the corresponding gain graph (G,ϕ_ℬ,Γ(G,ℬ)) is called the canonical gain graph associated with the biased graph (G,ℬ).

sentence:
[Combinatorial circuit generator]

We say, ⊂𝒮 is a combinatorial circuit generator if the linear subclass generated by  is the entire set of circuits 𝒮(G).

sentence:
[-cycle basis]
A subset ℬ⊂(G,) is called an -cycle basis of G if ℬ is a vector space basis of  (G,).
In the literature, a -cycle basis is also called a directed cycle basis and an _2-cycle basis is also called an undirected cycle basis.

sentence:
[Integral cycle basis] A set ℬ = {C_1, . . . , C_r}⊂𝒞(G,) of oriented circuits of a graph G is an integral cycle basis of G if every oriented circuit C of G can be written as an integer linear combination of circuits in ℬ, i.e., there exist λ_i ∈ s.t.

    C= λ_i C_i + … + λ_r C_r.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: [Totally unimodular cycle basis] A -cycle basis ℬ = {C_1, . . . , C_r}⊂𝒞(G,) of a graph G is a totally unimodular cycle basis of G if its cycle matrix M(ℬ, ) is totally unimodular, i.e., each sub determinant is either 0 or ± 1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Weakly fundamental cycle basis]
A set ℬ = {C_1,…,C_r} of circuits  of a graph G is a weakly fundamental cycle basis of G if there exists some permutation σ such that for all i=2,…,r,

    C_σ(i)∖ (C_σ(1)∪…∪ C_σ(i-1)) ≠∅.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Strictly fundamental cycle basis]
A set ℬ of circuits of a graph G is a strictly fundamental cycle basis of G, if there exists some spanning tree T ⊆ E such that ℬ = {C_e : e ∈ E ∖ T }, where C_e denotes the unique circuit in T ∪{e}.

sentence:
[Combinatorial circuit generator]

sentence:
[path homology]
The path homology groups of the graph G over the field  are

sentence:
[Bakry-Émery Curvature]
A graph G is said to satisfy the curvature dimension inequality CD(K,n) for some K∈ and n∈(0,∞] if for all f,

    Γ_2(f) ≥1/n (Δ f)^2 + K·Γ(f).

    V^ϕ   = V×Γ
    
    E^ϕ   = {{(u,g),(v,gϕ(uv))}: uv∈ E, g∈Γ}.


  * For ϕ a gain function into the symmetric group S_n, σ_uv = ϕ(uv), we define the permutation derived graph G^σ = (V^σ,E^σ) as

    V^σ   = V×{1,...,n}
    
    E^σ   = {{(u,i),(v,σ_uv(i))}:uv∈ E, i=1,...,n}.

sentence:
Call a graph treeish if it can be constructed recursively via the following rules.  


  * An edge or a triangle is treeish. 

  * If G is treeish and v is a vertex of G, adding a new vertex w and a new edge {v, w} results in a treeish graph. 

  * If G is treeish, and {v, w} is an edge of G, then the graph obtained from G by adding a new vertex z and the edges {v, z} and {w, z} is treeish.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We call a pure (d-1)-dimensional simplicial complex treeish if it can be constructed recursively via the following rules. 


  * A single (d-1)-simplex or a boundary of a d-simplex is treeish.  

  * If Σ is treeish and F is a (d-1)-simplex, then Σ⊔_E' = E F is treeish, where E' and E are (d-2)-dimensional faces of Σ and F, respectively. 

  * If Σ is treeish and Δ is the boundary of a d-simplex, then Σ⊔_E' = EΔ is treeish, where E' and E are (d-2) or (d-1)-dimensional faces of Σ and Δ, respectively.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G = (V, E) be a graph.
The
domination polynomial D(G, x) is 
given by 

    D(G,x)=∑_i=0^|V| d_i(G) x^i ,

where d_i(G) is the number of dominating sets of size i in G. 
The domination number of a graph G, denoted γ(G), is the smallest i such that d_i(G)>0.

sentence:
A feasible partition P of a graph G=(V,E) is a
  partition of the vertex set V into two or more subsets,
  {V_1, … , V_k_P}, such that each of the induced subgraphs
  G(V_i) is connected. The corresponding edge set, E_P, is defined
  to be the set of edges in G that connect vertices belonging to different V_i's.

An orientation of a simple undirected graph G=(V,E) will be

acyclic if the resulting directed graph does not contain directed
cycles.  Let (G) denote the set of acyclic orientations of G
and let a(G)=|(G)|. By a result of Stanley <cit.>, a(G) can be computed by evaluating the chromatic polynomial of G at -1.

sentence: Let I ⊆ S be a monomial ideal, and let Q be a poset on {x_1, x_2, …, x_n}.  We say that I is Q-Borel if whenever x_i <_Q x_j and m∈ I is a monomial divisible by x_j, then m ·x_i/x_j∈ I.  In this case, we may also say that Q stabilizes I, or that I is Borel with respect to Q .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let X ⊆ S be a set of monomials, and let Q be a poset.  If I is the smallest Q-Borel ideal containing X, we say that I is generated as a Q-Borel ideal by X and write I=(X).  In this case, we call X a Q-Borel generating set for I.  Every Q-Borel ideal I has a unique minimal Q-Borel generating set; we call the monomials in this set the -generators of I.  

Of particular interest is the case when X consists of a single monomial m.  We say in this case that I is a principal Q-Borel ideal , and write I=(m).

sentence: If Q is a poset with x_i ≤_Q x_j and m is a monomial with x_j|m, we call the replacement of m with m ·x_i/x_j a Q-Borel move .

sentence: Let I be a monomial ideal with minimal generating set G(I), where the monomials in G(I) are all of the same degree.  Then I is called polymatroidal if the following exchange condition is satisfied:  For two monomials m, m' ∈ G(I) and any variable x_i appearing to a greater power in m than in m', there exists a variable x_j, appearing to a greater power in m' than in m, such that m ·x_j/x_i∈ G(I).

sentence: Suppose I=(m_1,…,m_r) ⊂ S, and the m_i are monomials such that m_1 ≤⋯≤ m_r. We say that I has linear quotients if, for each 1 < i ≤ r, the ideal quotient (m_1, …, m_i-1):m_i is generated by a subset of x_1, …, x_n.  If an ideal generated in a single degree has linear quotients, it has a linear resolution (see, for instance, <cit.>).

sentence:
An o-minimal structure over 
a real closed field 
 is a sequence 
𝒮() = (𝒮_n)_n ∈ℕ, where 
each 𝒮_n is a collection of subsets of ^n
(called the definable sets in the structure) satisfying the 
following axioms (following the exposition in <cit.>). 



  * All algebraic subsets of ^n are in 𝒮_n.

  * The class 𝒮_n is closed under complementation and
finite unions and intersections.

  * If A ∈𝒮_m and B ∈𝒮_n then
A × B ∈𝒮_m+n.

  * If π: ^n+1→^n is the projection map on the
first n co-ordinates and A ∈𝒮_n+1, then 
π(A)  ∈𝒮_n.

  * The elements of 𝒮_1 are precisely finite unions of points
and intervals.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An S-map f ∈{X;Y} is an S-equivalence 
(also called a stable homotopy equivalence) if it admits an
inverse f^-1∈{Y;X}. In this case we say that X and Y are
stable homotopy equivalent.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We call a map f: |^[n]| → |^[n]| 
to be diagram preserving
if f(|_I|) ⊂ |_I| for every I ⊂ [n]. 
(Notice that the above property is equivalent to 
f(|A_i|) ⊂ |B_i| for every i ∈ [n] but the previous property
will be more convenient for us later when we extend the definition    
of diagram preserving maps to homotopy co-limits (see 
Definition <ref>).)
We say that two maps
f,g: |^[n]| → |^[n]| are diagram homotopic if 
there exists a homotopy 
h: |^[n]| × [0,1] → |^[n]|, such that
h(·,0)= f, h(·,1) = g and h(·,t) is diagram preserving for
each t ∈ [0,1].

More generally,
we call a map 
f: ^N |^[n]| →^N |^[n]| 
to be diagram preserving
if f(^N |_I|) ⊂^N |_I| 
for every I ⊂ [n]. We say that two maps
f,g: ^N |^[n]| →^N |^[n]| 
are diagram homotopic if there exists
a homotopy h: ^N |^[n]| × [0,1] →^N |^[n]| such that
h(·,0)= f, h(·,1) = g and h(·,t) is diagram preserving for
each t ∈ [0,1].


We say that f: | ^[n]| → |^[n]| is a diagram preserving
homeomorphism if there exists a diagram preserving  inverse map
g: |^[n]| → |^[n]|  such that the induced maps
g∘ f : | ^[n]| → | ^[n]| and
f∘ g : |^[n]| → |^[n]| are 
Id_| ^[n]| and 
Id_|^[n]|, respectively.


We say that f: |^[n]| → |^[n]| is a diagram preserving
homotopy equivalence if there exists a diagram preserving  inverse map
g: |^[n]| → | ^[n]|  such that the induced maps
g∘ f : | ^[n]| → | ^[n]| and
f∘ g : |^[n]| → |^[n]| are diagram
homotopic to Id_| ^[n]| and 
Id_|^[n]|, respectively.


We say that an S-map f ∈{ |^[n]|;|^[n]| } 
is a diagram preserving stable homotopy equivalence if it is
represented by a diagram preserving map

    f̃: ^N | ^[n]| →^N |^[n]|

such that there exists a diagram preserving  inverse map

    g̃: ^N |^[n]| →^N | ^[n]|

for which the induced maps

    g̃∘f̃ : ^N | ^[n]| →^N | ^[n]|,
 
and

    f̃∘g̃ : ^N |^[n]| →^N |^[n]|

are diagram homotopic to Id_^N | ^[n]| and 
Id_^N |^[n]|, respectively.

sentence:
A map f: X → Y between two regular cell complex is called a 
k-equivalence if the induced homomorphism 

    f_*: π_i(X) →π_i(Y)

is an isomorphism for all 0 ≤ i < k, and an epimorphism for i=k,
and we say that X is k-equivalent to Y. (Note that k-equivalence
is not an equivalence relation).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
(<cit.>)
Let L_U be an 𝔽_q-linear set of (W,𝔽_q^n)=(1,q^n) of rank n with maximum field of linearity 𝔽_q.

We say that L_U is of -class s if s is the greatest integer such that there exist 𝔽_q-subspaces U_1,…,U_s of W with L_U_i=L_U for i ∈{1,…,s} and there is no f ∈ΓL(2,q^n) such that U_i=U_j^f for each i≠ j, i,j ∈{1,2,…,s}. If L_U has ΓL-class one, then L_U is said to be simple .

We say that L_U is of 𝒵()-class r if r is the greatest integer such that there exist _q-subspaces U_1, U_2, …, U_r of W with L_U_i=L_U for i ∈{1,2,…,r} and U_i ≠λ U_j for each λ∈_q^n^* and for each i ≠ j, i, j ∈{1,2,…,r}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A partition of n is a non-increasing sequence of positive integers summing to n, i.e. a sequence α = (α_1, …, α_l) with α_1≥α_2≥…≥α_l≥ 1 and ∑_i=1^lα_i=n.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The Young diagram of α = (α_1,…,α_l) is an array of n cells, having l left-justified rows where row i contains α_i cells.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A permutation π∈_n contains a
  permutation p ∈_k if there exists a sequence of indices 1≤ i_1
    < i_2 < ⋯ < i_k ≤ n such that the subsequence
  c = π(i_1) π(i_2) ⋯π(i_k) of π is order
  isomorphic to p. The subsequence c is called an occurrence of
  p in π. If such a subsequence does not exist then π avoids
  p. In this context p is called a classical ( permutation )
  pattern .
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
[Brändeén and Claesson <cit.>]
  A mesh pattern is an ordered pair p=(τ,R) where τ∈_k,
  and R is a subset of the (k+1)^2 unit squares in
  [0,k+1]^2. The set R is the mesh (shading) and squares of
  the mesh are indexed by their lower-left corners; that is, i,j∈
  R refers to the square [i,i+1] × [j,j+1]. The mesh pattern
  (τ,R) is depicted graphically by drawing τ as above, and shading the
  squares of the mesh R. The size of the mesh pattern p is k and
  denoted |p|.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Two patterns p and q are said to be coincident if p = q,
	denoted p ≍ q.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let p=(τ,R) and q=(σ,T) be mesh patterns. If u=τ(u_1) …τ(u_k) and v=τ(v_1)…τ(v_k) are occurrences of q in
    p, then we say that
    
        
  * u is above v with respect to the point (i,σ(i)) if τ(u_i)>τ(v_i),
        
  * u is below v with respect to the point (i,σ(i)) if τ(u_i)<τ(v_i),
        
  * u is left of v with respect to the point (i,σ(i)) if u_i<v_i, and,
        
  * u is right of v with respect to the point (i,σ(i)) if u_i>v_i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a mesh pattern p = (τ,R), with τ∈_k, we
define a force on it as a tuple of pairs F = ((τ_i_1, a_1), (τ_i_2, a_2),
…, (τ_i_ℓ, a_ℓ)) where ℓ∈ [0, k], the
indices i_j ∈ [1, k] are distinct, and a_j ∈{↑, ↓, ←,
→} represents the direction we are forcing the point
τ_i_j in. The size of the force F is ℓ and denoted |F|.

Let p be a mesh pattern with force F. If we have an occurrence c =
c_1 c_2 ⋯ c_k of p in a permutation π, then for each (τ_i_j,
a_j) we define the strength of the point c_i_j with respect to
the force F as

    _F(π,c,i_j) = {[       -c_i_j  if  a_j = ↑;       -c_i_j  if  a_j = ↓; -π^-1(c_i_j)  if  a_j = ←; -π^-1(c_i_j)  if  a_j = → ].

Finally, we define the strength of an occurrence c of p in a
permutation π with respect to the force F as the tuple

    _F(π, c) = (_F(π, c, i_1), _F(π, c, i_2), …, _F(π, c, i_ℓ)).

An occurrence c in π is stronger than another occurrence c' in π
( with respect to F ) if _F(π, c) > _F(π, c'), in
the lexicographical order, otherwise it is weaker .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Define pπ as the number of occurrences of a pattern p
in a permutation π.
    A pattern p is binary if pπ≤
    1 for every permutation π.
    A pattern p is binary with respect to a permutation class
    𝒞 if pπ≤ 1 for every π∈𝒞.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: binary;binary with respect to a permutation class

sentence:
A mesh pattern p is anchored if for every point p_i_1
    of the pattern there exists a sequence of points p_i_1 p_i_2… p_i_n such
    that p_i_ℓ is anchored to p_i_ℓ+1 and p_i_n is
    anchored to a boundary.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A forced pattern is a tuple (p, F) of a pattern
    p and a force F.  An occurrence of a forced pattern (p, F)
    in a permutation π is an occurrence  c of p in π such that
      
    strength_F(π, c) = max_occ. c' of p
         in πstrength_F(π, c')

    where the force strengths are compared in the lexicographical order.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For any fixed r,n ∈ with r ≤ n and CW complex X, _X is a functor from (r,n) to .  Furthermore, if X is equipped with a free Γ-action for some group Γ, then _X^Γ is a functor from (r,n) to Γ-.
