sentence:
A lattice L is called geometric if (1) it is semimodular (i.e. 
    (p) + (q) ≥(p ∧ q) + (p ∨ q)
 for all p,q ∈ L); and (2) every element is the join of atoms.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A weak map is a function τ : M → N satisfying the condition if X ⊆ E(M) such that τ|_X is injective and τ(X) ∈(N), then X ∈(M).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A strong map is a function σ : M → N satisfying the condition that the preimage of any flat in N is a flat of M.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a rank r matroid M, the kth truncation T^k(M) of M is the matroid of rank r - k on E(M) whose rank function  is given as follows:  For X ⊆ E(M), 
    (X) =  r - k    _M(X) ≥ r - k, 
    _M(X)    otherwise.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Whitney numbers w_k(M) of the first kind are given by 
    w_k(M) = ∑_X  :  (X) = k |μ(0̂,X)|,
 where the sum is over all the rank k flats X in (M), and μ is the Möbius function of (M).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The colimit of a diagram : P → is the space 
    _P  = ∐_p ∈ P D(p)  /  ∼
 where the relation ∼ is generated by x ∼ y for each x ∈ D(p) and y ∈ D(q) if and only if d_pq(x) = y.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The homotopy colimit of a diagram : P → is the space 
    _P  = ∐_p ∈ P (Δ(P_≤ p) × D(p))  /  ∼
 where ∼ is the transitive closure of the relation (a,x) ∼ (b,y) for each a ∈Δ(P_≤ p), b ∈Δ(P_≤ q), x ∈ D(p) and y ∈ D(q) if and only if p ≥ q, d_pq(x) = y, and a = b.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For any P-diagram , define J() as the join of all spaces in the diagram realized by embedding them in skew affine subspaces.  The points of J() can be parametrized as 
    {∑_p ∈ P t_p x_p   | .  x_p ∈ D(p),  0 ≤ t_p ≤ 1  for all  p ∈ P,  and ∑_p ∈ P t_p = 1 }.
  Then the geometric realization of _P consists of the following set of points: 
    {t_0x_0 + ... + t_mx_m ∈ J()  |  x_i ∈ D(p_i),  p_0 ≤ ... ≤ p_m,  d_p_i+1 p_i(x_i+1) = x_i}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a CW complex X, an X-arrangement consists of a CW complex Y and a finite collection  of subcomplexes of Y such that:  
  * The complex Y is homotopy equivalent to X^*d for some d, and (Y) = (X^*d). 
  * Each complex A in  is homotopy equivalent to X^*(d-1) and (A) = (X^*(d-1)). 
  * Each intersection B of complexes in  is homotopy equivalent to some X^*e, and (B) = (X^*e). 
  * Every free action of a group Γ on X induces a free action of Γ on Y and every intersection of complexes in . 
  * If B ≃ X^*e is an intersection of complexes in , the complex A is in , and A ⊉ B, then A ∩ B ≃ X^*(e-1).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let M be a matroid and ρ∈ such that ρ≥(M).  A ρ-immersion of M is a rank- and order-reversing poset map l : (M) → B_ρ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given ρ-immersions l:M → B_ρ and l':N → B_ρ of matroids M and N, a weak map τ : M → N is called ρ-admissible if for every p ∈(M), l(p) ⊆ l'(τ^#(p)).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The arm a(□) of a cell □ is the number of cells contained in λ and above □, and the leg l(□) of a cell is the number of cells contained in λ and to the right of □.
The hook length h(□) of a cell is a(□)+l(□)+1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
For a,b relatively prime, the rational Catalan number , or (a,b) Catalan number _a,b is

    _a,b=1/a+ba+ba
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
Let a<b be relatively prime, and λ an (a,b)-core. The b-boundary of λ consists of all cells □∈λ with h(□)<b.

Group the parts of λ into a classes, according to λ_i-i a; (note, at least one of the a classes is empty since λ is an a-core). The a-parts of λ consist of the maximal λ_i among each of the i residue classes.

The skew length of λ, (λ) is the number of cells of λ that are in an a-row of λ and in the b-boundary of λ. The co-skew-length ^'(λ) is (a-1)(b-1)/2-(λ). Note that the skew length depends on a and b; where necessary, where we refer to the (a,b) skew length.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: b-boundary;a-parts of λ;skew length of λ, (λ);co-skew-length

sentence:
Let a<b be relatively prime. The (q,t)-rational Catalan number is

    _a,b(q,t)=∑_λ∈𝒞_a,b q^ℓ(λ)t^^'(λ)
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
Let _1/2^± denote the set of all positive/negative half integers, respectively.

The vacuum ⊂_1/2 is the set _1/2^-.

A state S is a set S⊂+1/2 so that the symmetric
difference 

    S =(S∩_1/2^+)∪ (S^c∩_1/2^-)

 is finite.  States should be interpreted as a finite collection of electrons – 
the elements of S∩^+_1/2, which we will denote by S^+, and a finite collections of positrons – the elements of S^c∩^-_1/2, which we will denote by S^-.

The charge c(S) of a state S is the number of positrons minus the number of electrons:

    c(S)=| S^-| -| S^+|


The energy e(S) of a state S is the sum of all the energies of the positrons and the electrons:

    e(S)=∑_k∈ S^+  k +∑_k∈ S^-  -k
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A hyperplane arrangement 𝒜^' is a deformation of an arrangement 𝒜 if every hyperplane in 𝒜^' is parallel to one in 𝒜.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The Catalan arrangement 𝒞_a is the union of the 3a2 hyperplanes x_i-x_j∈{-1,0,1}, i<j.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For λ and (a,b)-core, let ^T_i,j(λ) be the number of cells in the ith a-part with unoccupied state on the jth runner.

Furthermore let _ij^S(λ) be the number of such cells with hook length less than b, and _ij^B(λ) be the number of such cells with hook length greater than b.
 
Here, T, S and B are short for total, small and big .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
The rotated lattice Λ_R is the a-1 dimensional lattice

    Λ_R={𝐳=(z_1,… z_a)|𝐳∈^a+ℤ(1/a,1/a,…, 1/a), ∑_i=1^a z_i=0}
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A valid sequence of length n is a sequence of integers a_i, 1≤ i≤ n such that 0≤ a_i<i.  Let _n denote the set of valid sequences; clearly ||=n!.

A permutation code is a bijection ϕ:_n→ S_n.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O
plain_text_term: valid sequence of length n;permutation code

sentence:
A family C of k-cycles is a sequence C_k, k∈, with C_k∈ S_K a k-cycle.

The right factorization code associated to a family of k-cycles C_k is the sequence of maps R^C_n:_n→ S_n defined by

    R_n(a)=α_k=C_2^a_2C_3^a_3⋯ C_n^a_n


Similarly, the left factorization code associated to a family of k-cycles C_k is the the sequence of maps L^C_n:_n→ S_n defined by

    L^C_n(a)=C_n^a_nC_n-1^a_n-1⋯ C_2^a_2
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: family C of k-cycles;right factorization;left factorization

sentence:
Let 𝒜 be an alphabet and G be the set of all involutory antimorphisms on 𝒜^*.
Let Δ = δ_1 δ_2 … and Θ = ϑ_1 ϑ_2 …, where δ_i ∈𝒜 and ϑ_i ∈ G for all i ∈ℕ. The infinite generalized pseudostandard word 𝐮(Δ, Θ) generated by the generalized pseudopalindromic closure is the word whose prefixes w_n are obtained from the recurrence relation

    w_n+1 = (w_n δ_n+1)^ϑ_n+1,
 
    w_0 = ε.
 The sequence Λ = (Δ, Θ) is called the directive bi-sequence of the word 𝐮(Δ, Θ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence: A directive bi-sequence Λ=(Δ, Θ) of a binary generalized pseudostandard word 𝐮(Δ, Θ) is called normalized if the sequence of prefixes (w_n)_n≥ 0 of 𝐮(Δ, Θ) contains all palindromic and E-palindromic prefixes of 𝐮(Δ, Θ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a graph with distinct vertices a and b. The shortest path graph of G with respect to a and b is the graph S(G,a,b) in which every vertex U corresponds to a shortest path in G between a and b, and two vertices U,W ∈ V(S(G,a,b)) are adjacent if and only if their corresponding paths in G differ in exactly one vertex.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For p ∈ (0,1) and n ∈_0, let τ(p,n) denote the first time
          that, during a Bernoulli process with parameter p, one has encountered
          n successive successes.
          Its expectation is given by
          
    [ τ(p,n) ]  = 1 - p^n/p^n (1-p).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let H=(V,E) be a hypergraph. We say that a hypergraph  H'=(V', E') is a shadow of H if 
     
		
  (a) V'⊆ V; and
	 	
  (b) |E|=|E'| (same cardinalities) and  e∩ V' ∈ E' for each e∈ E.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that graphs G_1, …, G_k are in a k-sunflower position
if there exists a set of vertices I such that G_i ∩ G_j = I for every
i ≠ j. Otherwise we say that these graphs are in a non-sunflower
position.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that a set  of vertices is node-well-linked in
  G, iff for every pair (',”) of disjoint equal-sized subsets of
  , there is a collection :'” of node-disjoint paths in G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that two disjoint subsets (_1,_2) of vertices of G are α-linked for 0<α≤ 1, iff for every pair '_1⊆_1 and _2'⊆_2 of equal-sized vertex subsets, there is a flow F:_1'_1/α_2' in G. We say that they are node-linked , iff for every pair '_1⊆_1 and _2'⊆_2 of equal-sized vertex subsets, there is a collection of |'_1| node-disjoint paths connecting the vertices of '_1 to the vertices of _2'.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a graph, and let T⊆ V(G) be a subset of its vertices. Given a parameter 0<ρ≤ 1/2, a partition (A,B) of V(G) is called a ρ-balanced cut of G with respect to T, iff |A∩ T|,|B∩ T|≥ρ |T|. It is called a minimum ρ-balanced cut of G with respect to T, if it minimizes |E(A,B)| among all ρ-balanced cuts, and subject to this, minimizes min|A∩ T|,|B∩ T|.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a graph G, 
we say that a cluster C⊆ V(G) has the boundary property iff all vertices in Γ_G(C) have degree less than 3.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A (,⋃_i=1^ℓ-1_i) of width w and length ℓ in a graph G consists of:

 

  * A sequence =(S_1,…,S_ℓ) of ℓ disjoint vertex subsets of G, where for each i, G[S_i] is connected;

 

  * For each 1≤ i≤ℓ, two disjoint sets A_i,B_i⊆ S_i of w vertices each; the vertices of A_1∪ B_ℓ must have degree at most 2 in G; and

 


  * For each 1≤ i<ℓ, a set _i:B_i A_i+1 of w paths, such that all paths in ⋃_i_i are mutually node-disjoint, and do not contain the vertices of ⋃_S_j∈S_j as inner vertices (see Figure <ref>).


 We refer to vertex sets A_1 and B_ℓ as the anchors of the .
 
We say that it is an α-weak , if for all 1≤ i≤ℓ, A_i∪ B_i is α-well-linked in G[S_i]; we say that it is a good , if for all 1≤ i≤ℓ, B_i is 1-well-linked in G[S_i], and (A_i,B_i) are -linked in G[S_i]. Finally, we say that it is a perfect , if for each 1≤ i≤ℓ, A_i is node-well-linked in G[S_i], B_i is node-well-linked in G[S_i], and (A_i,B_i) are node-linked in G[S_i].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let C⊆ V(G)∖ T be any cluster containing non-terminals vertices only, and let (A,B) be the minimum 1/4-balanced cut in G∖ C with respect to T_1. 
We say that C is a good cluster, iff |E(A,B)|< k/28.  We say that it is a perfect cluster, iff k/28≤ |E(A,B)|≤ 7k/32.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence: A subset S⊆ V(G) of vertices is called a good router , iff (i) |S∩|≤ ||/2; (ii) there is a set of w'/2 edge-disjoint paths connecting the vertices of Γ(S) to the vertices of T∖ S in G, and (iii) Γ(S) is (w',α)-well-linked in G[S].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A subset C⊆ V(G) of vertices is called a good cluster iff G[C] is connected; C is a small cluster, and |C∩ T|≤ |T|/2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let H be any graph with non-negative integral width values w(e) for each edge e∈ E(H), and let G be any graph. A variable-width embedding of H into G consists of the following:



  * for every vertex v∈ V(H), a subset S(v)⊆ V(G) of vertices of G, such that G[S(v)] is connected, and all resulting clusters S(v)_v∈ V(H) are disjoint; and


  * for every edge e=(u,v)∈ E(H), a set (e) of w(e) disjoint paths in graph G, where each path P∈(e) connects a vertex of S(u) to a vertex of S(v), and it is internally disjoint from ⋃_x∈ V(H)S(x). The paths in =⋃_e∈ E(H)(e) must be all mutually disjoint.


For every vertex v∈ V(H) and edge e∈δ_H(v), let U(v,e) be the set of all endpoints of the paths in (e) that belong to S(v), and let U(v)=⋃_e∈δ_H(v)U(v,e). We say that the embedding is perfect, if for every vertex v∈ V(H): (i) for every edge e∈δ_H(v), set U(v,e) of vertices is node-well-linked in G[S(v)]; (ii) for every pair e, e'∈δ_H(v) of edges with e≠ e', (U(v,e),U(v,e')) are node-linked in G[S(v)]; and (iii) set U(v) is 1/5-well-linked in G[S(v)].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A hunter strategy on a graph G, denoted by H=(H_1, H_2, …, H_m), is a finite sequence of multi-sets, where H_i⊆ V(G) for all i. We think of H_i as the collection of vertices shot by hunters at time i. 
The concatenation of two hunter strategies, H_1=(H_1,H_2,…, H_m) and H_2=(H'_1, H'_2, …, H'_n), is defined as 

    H_1· H_2 = (H_1, H_2,…,H_m,H'_1,H'_2,…,H'_n).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that a bipartite graph G has isoperimetric nesting if there exists total orders ≤_E on E and ≤_O on O satisfying the following conditions: 


  * N((≤_E,k)) = (≤_O, (k)),

  * N((≤_O,k)) = (≤_E, (k)).


The orders ≤_E and ≤_O are together called the nest order. When the parity is clear, we will denote this order by ≤.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Fix {i,j}⊆ [n]. Let A ⊂ Q^n_even. From A, build auxiliary sets A_0,0, A_1,0, A_0,1, A_1,0∈ Q^n-2, where 

    A_0,0    =   { x :x ∈ A, i ∉ x, j ∉ x}, 
    
     A_0,1    =   { x ∖{i} :x ∈ A, i ∈ x, j ∉ x}, 
    
     A_1,0   =    {x ∖{j}: x ∈ A, i ∉ x, j ∈ x},  and
    
     A_1,1   =   {x ∖{i,j}: x ∈ A, i ∈ x, j ∈ x }.

Since each element of A contributes exactly once to {A_0,0, A_0,1, A_1,0, A_1,1}, we can think of the sets A_0,0, A_0,1, A_1,0, A_1,1 as a decomposition of A.

The (i,j)-compression of A , denoted C_i,j(A)=B is the set B such that 

    B_0,0    =    (<_wlexeven,| A_0,0|), 
    
     B_0,1    =    (<_wlexodd,| A_0,1|), 
    
     B_1,0    =    (<_wlexodd,| A_1,0|),  and
    
     B_1,1    =    (<_wlexeven,| A_1,1|).


If C_i,j(A)=A, we say that A is (i,j)-compressed . If A is (i,j)-compressed for all i,j, then we say A is compressed .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The difference sequence of a graph G is the sequence (a_k)_k=1^| V(G) | where a_k=(k)-(k-1).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Isoperimetric nesting]
We say that a bipartite graph G has isoperimetric nesting if there exists total orders ≤_E on E and ≤_O on O satisfying the following conditions: 


  * N((≤_E,k)) = (≤_O, (k)),

  * N((≤_O,k)) = (≤_E, (k)).


The orders ≤_E and ≤_O are together called the nest order. When the parity is clear, we will denote this order by ≤.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Hunter strategy]
A hunter strategy on a graph G, denoted by H=(H_1, H_2, …, H_m), is a finite sequence of multi-sets, where H_i⊆ V(G) for all i. We think of H_i as the collection of vertices shot by hunters at time i. 
The concatenation of two hunter strategies, H_1=(H_1,H_2,…, H_m) and H_2=(H'_1, H'_2, …, H'_n), is defined as 

    H_1· H_2 = (H_1, H_2,…,H_m,H'_1,H'_2,…,H'_n).

sentence:
[Hunter number] 
Given a graph G, the hunter number of G is given by 
    (G)=min_H ∈ℋ(G)max_i | H_i | ,
 where ℋ(G) = { H : there exists an n ∈ such that r_H(n)=0}
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The minimum union of k neighborhoods for a graph G is 
    (k):= min{| N(W) |: W ⊆ V(G), | W | = k}.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Minimum union of k even or odd neighborhoods]
For a bipartite graph G, the minimum union of k even neighborhoods is 
    (k):= min{| N(V) |: V ⊆ E, | V | = k}
 and the minimum union of k odd neighborhoods
is 
    (k):= min{| N(V) |: V ⊆ O, | V | = k}.
 

We then define analogously 
    u^E(G)=max_k{(k)-k}
 and 
    u^O(G)=max_k{(k)-k}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: minimum union of k even neighborhoods;minimum union of k odd neighborhoods

sentence:
[Lexographical order]
For x,y ∈ Q^n, we say x is lexographically less than y, denoted x ≤_lex y, if min{x y}∈ x.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Weightlex order] 
For vertices x, y ∈ Q^n, we say x is weightlex less than y, denoted x≤_wlex y, if |x| < |y| or |x|= |y| and x ≤_lex y.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[(i,j)-Compression] Fix {i,j}⊆ [n]. Let A ⊂ Q^n_even. From A, build auxiliary sets A_0,0, A_1,0, A_0,1, A_1,0∈ Q^n-2, where 

    A_0,0    =   { x :x ∈ A, i ∉ x, j ∉ x}, 
    
     A_0,1    =   { x ∖{i} :x ∈ A, i ∈ x, j ∉ x}, 
    
     A_1,0   =    {x ∖{j}: x ∈ A, i ∉ x, j ∈ x},  and
    
     A_1,1   =   {x ∖{i,j}: x ∈ A, i ∈ x, j ∈ x }.

Since each element of A contributes exactly once to {A_0,0, A_0,1, A_1,0, A_1,1}, we can think of the sets A_0,0, A_0,1, A_1,0, A_1,1 as a decomposition of A.

The (i,j)-compression of A , denoted C_i,j(A)=B is the set B such that 

    B_0,0    =    (<_wlexeven,| A_0,0|), 
    
     B_0,1    =    (<_wlexodd,| A_0,1|), 
    
     B_1,0    =    (<_wlexodd,| A_1,0|),  and
    
     B_1,1    =    (<_wlexeven,| A_1,1|).


If C_i,j(A)=A, we say that A is (i,j)-compressed . If A is (i,j)-compressed for all i,j, then we say A is compressed .

sentence:
[Difference sequence]
The difference sequence of a graph G is the sequence (a_k)_k=1^| V(G) | where a_k=(k)-(k-1).

sentence:
* Let v be a vertex in an L-colored graph M with edge coloring given by ξ, and A a finite subset of M∖{v}. The diagram of v over A is the function 
    φ_v,A:A→ L
 given by 
    φ_v,A(u)=ξ(v,u).
 

  * Suppose that f:A→ B is a finite surjective monomorphism and c∉ A. Define ζ_f,c:B→ L by 
    ζ_f,c(b)=φ_c,A(f^-1(b)).


  * Given two functions φ,φ':A→ L, we will write φ≼φ' if for all a∈ A, φ(a)≤φ'(a)
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[van der Waerden's theorem - see, e.g. , chapter 3 in <cit.>]
If  is partitioned into k classes, then one of the classes contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A half transversal-set T_h determined by a cell (i_1,j_1,k_1) in the starting 
Latin cube of order n is a set of t cells (i_2,j_2,k_2) such that

    𝒞={(i_1,j_1,k_1),  (i_1,j_2,k_1), (i_2,j_1,k_1), 
    (i_2,j_2,k_1), (i_1,j_1,k_2), (i_1,j_2,k_2), (i_2,j_1,k_2), (i_2,j_2,k_2)}

is a subcube.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A transversal-set of the starting Latin cube of order n is a union of two related half transversal-sets.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let L be the starting Latin cube of order n.
A row block of L is a set of n rows R_i,k such that for every pair 
of rows R_i_1,k_1={(i_1,j,k_1): j ∈ [n]} and 
R_i_2,k_2 = {(i_2,j,k_2): j ∈ [n]} in this set, L(i_1,x,k_1)=L(i_2,x,k_2) for every x ∈{1,…,n}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A symbol-set of the starting Latin cube L of order n in a row layer (or column layer or file layer)
 is a set of n cells such that all these cells contain the same symbol.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A symbol block of the starting Latin cube L of order n is a set of n^2 cells such that all these cells contain the same symbol.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A symbol-column block of the 
starting Latin cube L is a set 𝔰  of n^2 cells 
satisfying that

	
	
  * all cells of 𝔰 that are in the same column layer
	contain the same symbol, and
	
	
  * for every cell of 𝔰, there are n-1 other cells that have
	the same row and file coordinate.


Symbol-file blocks are defined similarly.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
A half symbol-set of the starting Latin cube L of order n=2t
 is a set of t cells in a quadrant of a row layer such that all these cells contain the same symbol.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A half column in the starting Latin cube of order n=2t is a set of t cells in a column such that the symbols used in this set
are 𝒮_1={1,2,…,t} or 𝒮_2={t+1,…,n}.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A first half column block determined by (i_1,j_1,k_1) in the starting Latin cube of order n 
is a set containing every half column 
with the property that it has a cell
(i_1,j_2,k_2) satisfying that

    𝒞={(i_1,j_1,k_1),  (i_1,j_2,k_1), (i_2,j_1,k_1), 
    (i_2,j_2,k_1), (i_1,j_1,k_2), (i_1,j_2,k_2), (i_2,j_1,k_2), (i_2,j_2,k_2)}

is a subcube.
A second half column block determined by (i_1,j_1,k_1) 
in the starting Latin cube of order n is a set containing every 
half column 
with the property that it has a cell
(i_2,j_2,k_2) satisfying that 𝒞 is a subcube.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: first half column block;second half column block

sentence:
A first half transversal block determined by (i_1,j_1,k_1) in the starting Latin cube of order n 
is a set containing every half transversal-set
with the property that it has a cell
(i_1,j_2,k_2) satisfying that

    𝒞={(i_1,j_1,k_1),  (i_1,j_2,k_1), (i_2,j_1,k_1), 
    (i_2,j_2,k_1), (i_1,j_1,k_2), (i_1,j_2,k_2), (i_2,j_1,k_2), (i_2,j_2,k_2)}.

is a subcube.
A second half transversal block determined by (i_1,j_1,k_1) 
in the starting Latin cube of order n 
is a set containing every half transversal-set
with the property that it has a cell
(i_2,j_1,k_1) satisfying that 𝒞 is a subcube.

is a subcube.

sentence:
Let G = (V, E) be a simple connected graph and d_G(u, v) be the length of the shortest
path between the vertices u and v in G. For an ordered set S ={u_1,⋯, u_t} of vertices in V and a vertex v, we call r(v|S) = (d_G(v, u_1), ⋯, d_G(v, u_t)) the metric representation of v with respect to S.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
[Metric representation]
Let G = (V, E) be a simple connected graph and d_G(u, v) be the length of the shortest
path between the vertices u and v in G. For an ordered set S ={u_1,⋯, u_t} of vertices in V and a vertex v, we call r(v|S) = (d_G(v, u_1), ⋯, d_G(v, u_t)) the metric representation of v with respect to S.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
[Resolving set and metric dimension]
Let G = (V, E) be a simple connected graph. A set S⊂ V(G) is said to be a
resolving set for G if any pair of vertices of G have different
metric representations with respect to S. A resolving set of the smallest
possible cardinality is called a metric basis , and its cardinality the
metric dimension of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: A generalized spline on the edge-labeled graph (G,L) is a vertex labeling satisfying the following: if two vertices are connected by an edge e_i then the labels on the two vertices are equivalent modulo the label on the edge. We denote a generalized spline ^(G,L)=(g_1,...,g_n) where g_i is the label on vertex v_i for 1 ≤ i ≤ n. The set of generalized splines is denoted {^(G,L)}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
Fix a cycle with edge labels (C_n,L). The smallest flow-up class _k=(0,...,0,g_k+1,...,g_n) on (C_n,L) is the flow-up class whose nonzero entries are positive and if _k'=(0,...,0,g_k+1',...,g_n') is another flow-up class with positive entries then g_i' ≥ g_i for all entries. By convention we consider 
 _0=(1,...,1) the smallest flow-up class _0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let A ∈^d × n be a non-basic matrix of rank d.  The
    ramification cycle is the algebraic cycle of dimension d-2 in
    ^n-1 defined by the ramification scheme _A.  By
    Corollary <ref>, the push-forward of the ramification cycle
    under the morphism A : ℒ^-1→^d-1 is a cycle
    of codimension 1. We define the entropic discriminant  of A to
    be the homogeneous polynomial H_A()̱ that represents this cycle in
    ^d-1. 
    
    It is unique up to multiplication by a
    non-zero constant.

sentence:
Surreal numbers are totally ordered by ≥.  That is, two surreal numbers
are never incomparable.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(Number Avoidance Theorem)
Let x be a number and G = {G^L|G^R} be a short game
that does not equal any number.  Then

    G + x = {G^L + x|G^R + x}.

plain_text_term: that does not equal any number.

sentence:
There is a unique largest
equivalence relation ∼ on S having the following properties:


  (a) If x ∼ y then (x) = (y).

  (b) If 1 ≤ i ≤ k, and if x_1, …, x_n_i, y_1, …, y_n_i are games in S
for which x_j ∼ y_j for every 1 ≤ j ≤ n_i, then f_i(x_1,…,x_n_i) ∼ f_i(y_1,…,y_n_i).

sentence:
If G is a ℤ-valued game and n is an integer (possibly negative), we define G cooled by n , G_n,
to be G is G is a number, and otherwise ⟨ (G^L)_n - n  |  (G^R)_n + n⟩, where
G^L and G^R range over the left and right options of G.  We define G heated by n
to be G_-n, G cooled by -n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
If [a_1,…,a_m] and [b_1,…,b_n] are rational tangles, then they are equivalent if and only if

    a_m + 1/a_m-1 + 1/⋱ + 1/a_1 = b_n + 1/b_n-1 + 1/⋱ + 1/b_1.

The knot or link [a_1,…,a_m] is a knot (as opposed to a link) if and only if

    a_m + 1/a_m-1 + 1/⋱ + 1/a_1 = p/q,

where p,q ∈ℤ and p is odd.
Finally, [a_1,…,a_m] is the unknot if and only if q/p is an integer.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A game graph is a set S of positions , a designated starting position (S) ∈ S,
and two relations L→ and R→
 on S.  For any x ∈ S, the y ∈ S
such that x L→ y are called the left options of x,
and the y ∈ S such that x R→ y are called the right options of x.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
A game graph is well-founded or loopfree if there are no infinite sequences
of positions a_1, a_2, … such that

    a_1 → a_2 → a_3 →⋯.

We also say that the game graph satisfies the ending condition .
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: The outcome of a game is the outcome class (1, 2, L, or R) of its starting position.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If S_1 and S_2 are game graphs, we define the sum S_1 + S_2 to be a game graph
with positions S_1 × S_2 and starting position (S_1 + S_2) = ((S_1),(S_2)).
The new L→ relation is defined by

    (x,y) L→ (x',y')

if x = x' and y L→ y', or x L→ x' and y = y'.  The new R→ is defined similarly.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If S is a game graph, the negation -S has the same set of positions,
and the same starting position, but L→ and R→ are interchanged.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A (partizan) game is an ordered pair (L,R) where L and R are sets of games.
If L = {A,B,…} and R = {C,D,…}, then we write (L,R) as

    {A,B,…|C,D,…}.

The elements of L are called the
left options of this game, and the elements of R are called its
right options .  The positions of a game G are G and all the positions
of the options of G.

Following standard conventions in the literature, we will always denote
direct equality between partizan games with ≡, and refer to this relation
as identity .[The reason for this will be explained in Section <ref>.]

sentence:
If G ≡{A,B, … |C,D,…} and
H ≡{E,F,… |X,Y,…} are games, then the sum G + H is recursively
defined as

    G + H = {G + E, G + F, …, A + H, B + H, … |

    G + X, G + Y, …, H + C, H + D, …}

sentence: A short game is a partizan game with finitely many positions.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: A game G is a zero game if G = 0.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
A partially-ordered abelian group is an abelian group G
with a partial order ≤ such that

    x ≤ y  x + z ≤ y + z

for every z.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a (form of a) game.  Then a left
option G^L is dominated if there is some other left option
(G^L)' such that G^L ≤ (G^L)'.  Similarly, a
right option G^R is dominated if there is some
other right option (G^R)' such that G^R ≥ (G^R)'.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If G is a game, G^L is a left option of G, and G^LR is a right 
option of G^L such that G^LR≤ G, then we say that G^L
is a reversible option , which is reversed through 
its option G^LR.

Similarly, if G^R is a right option, having a left option G^RL with
G^RL≥ G, then G^R is also a reversible option, reversed through
G^RL.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A game G is in canonical form if every position of G has no dominated or reversible moves.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A (surreal) number is a partizan game x such that every option of x
is a number, and every left option of x is  every right
option of x.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A surreal number is dyadic if it occurs in the range of the map
from dyadic rationals to surreal numbers in the previous theorem.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let x and y be dyadic rational numbers (short surreal numbers).  We say that
x is simpler than y if x has a smaller denominator than y,
or if |x| < |y| when x and y are both integers.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a short game.  We recursively define the
left stopping value LS(G) and the right stopping value
RS(G) by


  * If G equals a number x, then LS(G) = RS(G) = x.

  * Otherwise, LS(G) is the maximum value of RS(G^L)
as G^L ranges over the left options of G; and
RS(G) is the minimum value of LS(G^R) as G^R ranges
over the right options of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A game is infinitesimal (or small ) if it is less than every positive
number and greater than every negative number, i.e., if L(G) = R(G) = 0.  A game is all-small in form
 if every one of its positions (including itself) is infinitesimal.  A game is
all-small in value if it equals an all-small game.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
A short game G is even in form if every option is odd in form, and odd in form
if every option is even in form and G  0.  G is even (odd) in value
if it equals a short game that is even (odd) in form.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a short game.  Then G is even-tempered in form
if it equals a (surreal) number, or every option is odd-tempered in form.
Similarly, G is odd-tempered in form if does not equal a number, and every option
is even-tempered in form.  Also, G is odd- (even-)tempered in value
if it equals a short game that is odd or even tempered in form.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a class of games and a list of operations on games, we define indistinguishability (with respect to the given operations)
to be the equivalence relation from the previous theorem, and denote it as
≈_f_1,f_2,…,f_k.  The quotient space of S is the indistinguishability quotient .

plain_text_term: indistinguishability (with respect to the given operations);indistinguishability quotient

sentence:
A Boolean game born on day n is


  * One of the values True or False if n = 0.

  * A pair (L,R) of two finite sets L and R of Boolean games born on day n - 1, if n > 0.  The elements
of L and R are called the left options and right options of (L,R).

We consider a game born on day 0 to have no options of either sort.

The sum G ∨ H of two Boolean games G and H born on days n and m is the logical OR of G and H when n = m = 0,
and is otherwise recursively defined as

    G ∨ H = ({G^L ∨ H, G ∨ H^L},{G^R ∨ H, G ∨ H^R}),

where G^L ranges over the left options of G, and so on.

The left outcome of a Boolean game G is True if G =True, or
some right option of G has right outcome True.  Otherwise, the left outcome of G is False.

Similarly, the right outcome of a Boolean game G is False if G =False, or
some left option of G has left outcome False.  Otherwise, the left outcome of G is True.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: Boolean game;left options;right options;left outcome;right outcome

sentence:
For G ∈𝒲_𝒮 we define (G) = (G) = n if G = n ∈𝒮,
and otherwise, if G = ⟨ L_1, L_2, … |  R_1, R_2, …⟩, then we define

    (G) = max{(L_1), (L_2), …}


    (G) = min{(R_1), (R_2), …}.

For any G ∈𝒲_𝒮, (G) is called the left outcome
of G, (G) is called the right outcome of G, and the ordered pair
((G),(G)) is called the (full) outcome of G, denoted (G).

sentence:
If G is an 𝒮-valued game, then its negative -G is the (-𝒮)-valued game
defined recursively as -n if G = n ∈𝒮, and as

    -G = ⟨ -R_1, -R_2, … |  -L_1, -L_2, …⟩

if G = ⟨ L_1, L_2, … |  R_1, R_2, …⟩.

sentence:
If G is an 𝒮-valued game and H is a 𝒯-valued game, then the sum
G + H is defined in the usual way if G and H are both numbers, and otherwise defined recursively as

    G + H = ⟨ G + H^L,  G^L + H  |  G + H^R,  G^R + H ⟩

where G^L and G^R range over all left and right options of G, and H^L and H^R range over all left and right
options of H.

sentence:
An i-game is a ℤ-valued game G which has the property that
every option is an i-game, and if G is even-tempered, then (G) ≥(G).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If G_1, G_2 ∈𝒲_ℤ, then we say that G_1 and G_2 are equivalent ,
denoted G_1 ≈ G_2, iff (G_1 + X) = (G_2 + X) for all X ∈𝒲_ℤ.
We also define a preorder on 𝒲_ℤ by
G_1 ≲ G_2 iff (G_1 + X) ≤(G_2 + X) for all X ∈𝒲_ℤ.

sentence:
Let G be a well-tempered scoring game.  Then G has length 0 if G is a number,
and has length n+1 if every option of G has length 0.  A well-tempered game is fixed-length
if it has length n for any n.

the final move, and the right-final outcome (G) is the outcome when Right makes the final move.
In other words, if G is odd-tempered (whoever goes first also goes last), then

    (G) = (G)


    (G) = (G)

while if G is even-tempered, then

    (G) = (G)


    (G) = (G).

sentence:
We say that f S_1 ×⋯× S_k → T is (weakly) order-preserving
if whenever (a_1, …, a_n) ∈ S_1 ×⋯× S_k and
(b_1, …, b_n) ∈ S_1 ×⋯× S_k satisfy a_i ≤ b_i for every
1 ≤ i ≤ k, then f(a_1, …, a_n) ≤ f(b_1, …, b_n).

sentence:
If G is in I_-2, then the representation of G , denoted ψ(G), is defined recursively by ψ(n) = n (as a surreal number)
if n ∈ℤ, and by

    ψ(G) = {ψ(G^L)|ψ(G^R)}

if G = ⟨ G^L | G^R ⟩ is not a number.

sentence:
If G is a 3-valued game, then we recursively define ψ^+(G) to be

    ψ^+(n) = n

when n = 0,1,2, and otherwise

    ψ^+(G) = “{ψ^+(G^L)|ψ^+(G^R) }”,

where “{H^L|H^R}” is {H^L|H^R} unless there is more than
one integer x satisfying H^L  x  H^R for every H^L and
H^R, in which case we take the largest such x.

Similarly, we define ψ^-(G) to be

    ψ^-(n) = n

when n = 0,1,2, and otherwise

    ψ^-(G) = ,,{ψ^-(G^L)|ψ^-(G^R)},,,

where ,,{H^L|H^R},, is {H^L|H^R} unless there is more than
one integer x satisfying H^L  x  H^R for every H^L and
H^R, in which case we take the smallest such x.

sentence:
A pseudodiagram S is obtained by a phony Reidemeister I move from a pseudodiagram T if S is obtained
from T by removing a loop with an unresolved crossing from T, as in Figure <ref>.  We denote this T 1→ S.

sentence:
A pseudodiagram S is obtained by a phony Reidemeister II move from a pseudodiagram T if S is obtained
from T by uncrossing two overlapped strings, as in Figure <ref>, where the two crossings eliminated are unresolved.

sentence:
An odd-even shadow is a shadow of the form 
    [(a_1),(a_2),…,(a_n)],

where all a_i ≥ 1, exactly one of a_1 and a_n is odd, and all other
a_i are even.

sentence:
A rational knot shadow reduces to an odd-even shadow
if it reduces to an odd-even shadow via phony Reidemeister I moves.

sentence:
Let K be a knot diagram with n crossings and n strands.  Create a matrix
M such that M_ij is -1 if the ith strand terminates at the jth crossing,
2 if the ith strand passes over the jth crossing, and 0 otherwise.  The
knot determinant is defined as |(M')|, where M' is any
(n-1)×(n-1) submatrix of M.

sentence:
Let S_≤ d be the d-skeleton of a piecewise
linear 2d-sphere and let M be a missing d-face of
S_≤ d, i.e. M=d, M∉S_≤ d and the boundary ∂ M is contained
in S_≤ d. Then the union :=S_≤
d∪{M} does not embed in the 2d-sphere.

sentence:
Given a (possibly looped) graph H and a function :V(H)→ (0,∞), we define the weight of a homomorphism ϕ∈(G,H) to be
	
    w^(ϕ)=∏_v∈ V(G)(ϕ(v)).

	The analogue of the number of homomorphisms is the total weight of all homomorphisms from G to H.  We write
	
    Z^(G,H)=∑_ϕ∈(G,H) w^(ϕ).

sentence: Let K be a finite set of colors and let Ł be a collection of multisets of K.  We say that ϕ:V(G)→ K is a Ł-legal neighborhood coloring of the graph G if ϕ(N(v))∈Ł for all v∈ V(G).  Note that we are considering the multiset image of N(v) under ϕ.  Similarly, we say that ϕ:V(G)→ K is a Ł-legal closed neighborhood coloring of the graph G if ϕ(N[v])∈Ł for all v∈ V(G).  We let ł(G,Ł) be the number of Ł-legal neighborhood colorings of G and (G,Ł) the number of Ł-legal closed neighborhood colorings of G.  We refer to Ł as a coloring condition .

sentence: Suppose that G and H are graphs with H possibly having loops.  We say that a map ϕ:V(G)→ V(H) is an existence homomorphism if, for every v∈ V(G), there is a w∈ N(v) such that ϕ(v)ϕ(w)∈ E(H).  We let (G,H) be the set of all existence homomorphisms from G to H and set (G,H)=(G,H).

sentence:
a) A word W is n-divisible in ordinary sense if there exist
u_1, u_2,…,u_n such that W=v· u_1⋯
u_n and u_1≻…≻ u_n.

b) In our proof we will call a word W n-divisible in tail sense if there exist tails
u_1,…,u_n such that u_1≻ u_2≻…≻ u_n and for any
i=1, 2,…, n - 1 the beginning of u_i is to the left from the beginning of
u_i+1. If the contrary is not specified, an n-divisible word means n-divisible
in tail sense.

c) A word W is n-cancellable if either it is
n-divisible in ordinary sense or there exists a word of the form u^d⊆ W..

sentence:
We define the future-subgraphs G_t inductively. Initially G_0 = G.  When we run the Swapping Algorithm, as we encounter a bad-event (k_1, x_1, y_1), …, (k_r, x_r, y_r) at time t, we form G_t+1 from G_t as follows:


  * Suppose that k_i = k^*, and G_t contains a source node v labeled (x_i,y_i). Then G_t+1 = G_t - v.

  * Suppose that k_i = k^*, and G_t has a source labeled (x_i, y”) where y”≠ y_i or (x”, y_i) where x”≠ x_i. Then, as will be shown in Proposition <ref>, we can immediately conclude G is impossible; we set G_t+1 =, and we can abort the execution of the Swapping Algorithm.

  * Otherwise, we set G_t+1 = G_t.

sentence:
Suppose v ≈ (x, y) has in-degree at most one, and the backward path contains an even number of edges, terminating at vertex v' ≈ (x', y'). We refer to this alternating path as a W-configuration . (See Figure <ref>.)

Any W-configuration can be written (in one of its two orientations) as a path of vertices labeled 
    (x_0, y_1), (x_1, y_1), (x_1, y_2), …, (x_s, y_s), (x_s, y_s+1);
 here the vertices (x_1, y_1), …, (x_s, y_s) are at the “base” of the W-configuration. Note here that we have written the path so that the x-coordinate changes, then the y-coordinate, then x, and so on. When written this way, we refer to (x_0, y_s+1) as the endpoints of the W-configuration.

If v ≈ (x,y) is a source node, then it defines a W-configuration with endpoints (x,y). This should not be considered a triviality or degeneracy, rather it will be the most important type of W-configuration.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[witness subdags]
For a permutation π_k, a witness subdag for π_k is defined to be a directed acyclic simple graph, whose nodes are labeled with pairs of the form (x,y). If a node v is labeled by (x,y), we write v ≈ (x,y). This graph must in addition satisfy the following properties:


  * If any pair of nodes overlaps in a coordinate, that is, we have v ≈ (x,y) ∼ (x', y') ≈ v', then nodes v, v' must be comparable (that is, either there is a path from v to v' or vice-versa). 

  * Every node of G has in-degree at most two and out-degree at most two.


We also may label the nodes with some auxiliary information, for example we will record that the nodes of a witness subdag correspond to bad-events or nodes in a witness tree τ.

We will use the same terminology as for witness trees: vertices on the “bottom” are close to the source nodes of G (appearing earliest in time), and vertices on the “top” are close to the sink nodes of G (appear latest in time).
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Projection of a witness tree]
For a witness tree τ, we define the projection of τ onto permutation π_k which we denote Proj_k(τ), as follows.

Suppose we have a node v ∈τ which is labeled by some bad-event B = (k_1, x_1, y_1), …, (k_r, x_r, y_r). For each i with k_i = k, we create a corresponding node v'_i ≈ (x_i, y_i) in the graph Proj_k(τ). We also include some auxiliary information indicating that these nodes came from bad event B, and in particular that all such nodes are part of the same bad-event.

The edges of Proj_k(τ) are formed follows. For each node v' ∈Proj_k(τ), labeled by (x,y) and corresponding to v ∈τ, we find the node w_x ∈τ (if any) which satisfies the following properties:


  (P1) The depth of w_x is smaller than the depth of v

  (P2) w_x is labeled by some bad-event B' which contains (k,x, *)

  (P3) Among all vertices satisfying (P1), (P2), the depth of w_x is maximial


If this node w_x ∈τ exists, then it corresponds to a node w_x' ∈Proj_k(τ) labeled (k, x, *); we construct an edge from v' to w_x'. Note that, since the levels of the witness tree are independent under ∼, there can be at most one such w_x and at most one such w_x'.

We similary define a node w_y satisfying:


  (P1') The depth of w_y is smaller than the depth of v

  (P2') w_y is labeled by some bad-event B' which contains (k,y, *)

  (P3') Among all vertices satisfying (P1), (P2), the depth of w_y is maximial

If this node exists, we create an edge from v' to the corresponding w_y' ∈Proj_k(τ) labeled (k,*,y).

Note that since edges in Proj_k(τ) correspond to strictly smaller depth in τ, the graph Proj_k (τ) is acyclic. Also, note that it is possible that w_x = w_y; in this case we only add a single edge to Proj_k(τ).

Expository Remark: In the special case when each bad-event contains a single element, the witness subdag is a “flattening" of the tree structure. Each node in the tree corresponds to a node in the witness subdag, and each node in the witness subdag points to the next highest occurrence of the domain and range variables.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: projection of τ onto permutation π_k;strictly

sentence:
[Alternating paths] Given a witness subdag G, we define an alternating path in G to be a simple path which alternately proceeds forward and backward along the directed edges of G. For a vertex v ∈ G, the forward (respectively backward) path of v in G, is the maximal alternating path which includes v and all the forward (respectively backward) edges emanating from v. Because G has in-degree and out-degree at most two, every vertex v has a unique forward and backward path (up to reflection); this justifies our reference to “the" forward and backward path. These paths may be even-length cycles.

Note that if v is a source node, then its backward path contains just v itself. This is an important type of alternating path which should always be taken into account in our definitions.

sentence:
[The W-configuration]
Suppose v ≈ (x, y) has in-degree at most one, and the backward path contains an even number of edges, terminating at vertex v' ≈ (x', y'). We refer to this alternating path as a W-configuration . (See Figure <ref>.)

Any W-configuration can be written (in one of its two orientations) as a path of vertices labeled 
    (x_0, y_1), (x_1, y_1), (x_1, y_2), …, (x_s, y_s), (x_s, y_s+1);
 here the vertices (x_1, y_1), …, (x_s, y_s) are at the “base” of the W-configuration. Note here that we have written the path so that the x-coordinate changes, then the y-coordinate, then x, and so on. When written this way, we refer to (x_0, y_s+1) as the endpoints of the W-configuration.

If v ≈ (x,y) is a source node, then it defines a W-configuration with endpoints (x,y). This should not be considered a triviality or degeneracy, rather it will be the most important type of W-configuration.

sentence:
[Active conditions of a future-subgraph]
We refer to the conditions implied by Proposition <ref> as the active conditions of the graph G_t. More formally, we define

    Active(G) = { (x, y)  |(x,y) are the end-points of a W-configuration of G}

We also define A^t_k to be the cardinality of Active(G_t), that is, the number of active conditions of permutation π_k at time t. (The subscript k may be omitted in context, as usual.)

sentence:
Let n ≥ 3. We say that a digraph D on the vertex set [n] is a cycle digraph if, up to a relabeling of the vertices, E(D) = E(D) ∪E(D), where

    E(D)    = {(1,2),(2,3),…,(n-1,n),(n,1)},
    E(D)    ⊆{(n,n-1),(n-1,n-2),…,(2,1),(1,n)}.

If such a relabeling exists, D is completely determined by E(D), and we denote it by D=C_n^S, where S ⊆ [n] is the set of the tails of the directed edges in E(D). As an example see Figure <ref>.

sentence:
We call a naturally labeled poset P on [n] such that, for i,j,k∈ [n],
  
    i<j<_Pk i<_P k
 a factorial poset , and by _n we denote the set of
  factorial posets on [n]. Similarly, we call a naturally labeled
  poset P on [n] such that, for i,j,k∈ [n],
  
    i>j>_P k i>_P k
 a dually factorial poset .

  }, and we denote by (j)=#(j) the number of predecessors

sentence:
Let f be a mapping from a given color set 
to the set of non-negative integers.
An edge-colored graph (G, , color) is said to be
f-chromatic
if |E_c(G)| ≤ f(c) for any color c ∈.

sentence:
A covering array (N;t,k,v) of strength t is an N × k
array of symbols from [0,v-1] such that in every
N × t subarray, every t-tuple occurs in at least one row. A covering array is optimal if it has the
smallest possible N for given t, k, and v, and uniform
if every symbol occurs either ⌊ N/v ⌋ or ⌈ N/v ⌉
times in every column.

Let G=G_k,v be a k-partite hypergraph graph with vertex set V(G) = { v_i,a:i ∈ [1,k], a ∈ [0,v-1]}. A row of a covering array c∈ [0,v-1]^k avoids G if for
all {i_1, i_2, … , i_t}⊂ [1,k], we have {v_i_1, c_i_1,…,v_i_t, c_i_t}∉E(G). A covering array with forbidden edges (N;G) is a (N;t,k,v) where every row avoids G.

sentence: A cylindric intersection set L in X^A is a set L = ⋂_{B : B ⊊ A}π_B^-1(Y_B), where each Y_B ⊆ X^B is measurable.

sentence: A directed r-uniform hypergraph H on X is ϵ-regular if for any cylindric intersection set L in X^[r] with μ(L) ≥ϵ, | μ(H ∩ L) - μ(H)μ(L) | < ϵ.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Let X be a finite T_0–space and let A⊆ X. We say that A is a dbp–retract (resp. ubp–retract ) of X if A can be obtained from X by successively removing down beat points (resp. up beat points), that is, if there exist n∈_0 and a sequence X=X_0⊇ X_1⊇⋯⊇ X_n=A of subspaces of X such that, for all i∈{1,…,n}, the space X_i is obtained from X_i-1 by removing a single down beat point (resp. up beat point) of X_i-1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Graph H is special if the following properties are fulfilled:


  * The diameter of H is two.

  * H does not have a dominating edge.

  * H has two vertices, called a special pair , u and v such that:


  * Distance between u and v is two.

  * If we remove u or v from H then the obtained subgraph does 
not have a dominating edge. 

  * (N(u)∩ N(v))∪{u,v} is a dominating set of H.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose that we have distributions D and D' on graph G, such that D< D'. Denote the difference of the size of these distribution by  Δ p_D,D'=|D'|-|D|=|Δ_D,D'|. 
We use  Δ𝒯_D,D' for set 𝒯(D') ∖𝒯(D) and Δ t_D,D' denotes the cardinality of this set. 

We say that the strengthening ratio of the expansion D<D' is:

    ℰ(D,D')=Δ t_D,D'/Δ p_D,D'

The strengthening ratio of distribution D≠ 0 is ℰ(0,D), and the strengthening ratio of D=0 is ∞.

sentence:
The orbit of b∈ B under the promotion operator  is the family

    b (b) ^2(b) ⋯^n(b)  b ,

(or any cyclic shift thereof).

sentence:
A promotion operator  on a crystal B of type A_n is an operator :B→ B
such that:
  
    
  *   shifts the content: If (b)=(w_1,…,w_n+1) is the content 
      of the crystal element b∈ B, then ((b))=(w_n+1,w_1,…,w_n);
    
  *  Promotion has order n+1: ^n+1 = 𝕀;
    
  *  ∘ e_i = e_i+1∘ and ∘ f_i = f_i+1∘ for 
      i∈{1,2,…,n-1}.
  
If condition (<ref>) is not satisfied, but  is still
bijective, then  is a weak promotion operator.

sentence:
For J ⊂ I={1,2,…,n}, the element b∈ B is
  J-highest weight if e_i(b)= for all i∈ J. It is
  highest weight if it is I-highest weight. Similarly, b∈ B is
  J-lowest weight if f_i(b)= for all ∈ J.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  
A finite regular crystal B with weights in ^0 is a simple crystal if B satisfies


  * There exists λ∈^0 such that the weight of any extremal vector of B is
contained in W_clλ;

  * The weight space of B of weight λ has dimension one.

sentence:
Suppose (A,ℱ) is an algebra, m∈ℕ, and f A^m → A. We say that f  is an orderly composition of ℱ iff
there exist n ∈ℕ, k_1,k_2, …, k_n∈ℕ, and g,h_1,h_2, …, h_n∈ℱ such that


  * g   A^n → A;

  * h_i   A^k_i→ A for i=1,2,…,n;

  * m=∑_i=1^n k_i; and

  * if x⃗_i∈^<ωA and |x⃗_i|=k_i for i=1,2,…, n and x⃗=x⃗_1∗x⃗_2∗…∗x⃗_n, then

    f(x⃗)=g(h_1(x⃗_1), h_2(x⃗_2), …, h_n(x⃗_n)).


We say that ℱ is closed under orderly composition iff f ∈ℱ whenever f is an orderly composition of ℱ. The collection of orderly terms over ℱ is  the smallest collection of operations on A that includes ℱ, contains the identity function[In <cit.> this containment of the identity function is mistakenly omitted. However, all the collections ℱ encountered later in the paper do contain the identity function.] on A and is closed under orderly composition.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: orderly composition;closed under orderly composition;orderly terms

sentence:
Suppose (A,ℱ) is an algebra and a⃗, b⃗ are infinite sequences in A.
We say b⃗ is a reduction of a⃗ with respect to ℱ, and write b⃗≤_ℱa⃗ iff there are finite sequences a⃗_k and orderly terms f_k over ℱ for all
k ∈ω such that a⃗_0 ∗a⃗_1 ∗a⃗_2 ∗… is a subsequence of a⃗ and b⃗(k)=f_k(a⃗_k) for all k ∈ω.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Suppose (A,ℱ) is an algebra and b⃗ is an infinite sequence in A. A finite reduction of b⃗ with respect to ℱ is an element of the form f(b⃗_0) for some orderly term f over  ℱ  and    some finite subsequence b⃗_0 of b⃗. The set of all finite reductions of b⃗ with respect to ℱ is denoted by _ℱ(b⃗).

sentence:
Suppose (A,ℱ) is an algebra. We say that (A, ℱ) is a Ramsey algebra iff
for every a⃗∈^ωA and X ⊆ A, there exists b⃗≤_ℱa⃗ such that b⃗ is homogeneous for X (with respect to ℱ), meaning that _ℱ(b⃗) is either contained in or disjoint from X.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A preorder with approximations[In <cit.> a preorder was called  a pre-partial order. Hence, a preorder with approximations was originally called a pre-partial order with appromixations by Carlson.] is a pair
ℜ=(R, ≤) such that R is a nonempty set of infinite sequences and ≤ is a preorder on R. 
If a⃗,b⃗∈ R and b⃗≤a⃗, then b⃗ is called a reduction of a⃗ with respect to ℜ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose ℜ=(R,≤) is a preorder with approximations. For n ∈ω and a⃗∈ R, define 

    [n,a⃗]_ℜ={ b⃗∈ R|b⃗≤a⃗ and b⃗↾ n=a⃗↾ n }.

The natural topology on ℜ is the topology generated by the sets [n,a⃗]_ℜ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Suppose ℜ= (R, ≤) is a preorder with approximations. Assume X is a subset of R. We say that X is Ramsey iff for every n ∈ω and a⃗∈ R, there exists b⃗∈ [n,a⃗]_ℜ such that [n,b⃗]_ℜ is either contained in or disjoint from X. Assuming the Axiom of Choice, ℜ is a Ramsey space iff every subset of ℜ (endowed with the natural topology) which has the property of Baire is Ramsey.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (𝒫, ) be a poset (partially ordered set). A linear extension L of 𝒫 is a total order which satisfies (x  y ∈𝒫)  (x  y ∈ L). A realiser of 𝒫 is a set of linear extensions of 𝒫, say ℛ, which satisfy the following condition: for any two distinct elements x and y, x y ∈𝒫 if and only if x  y ∈ L, ∀ L ∈ℛ.  
The poset dimension of 𝒫, denoted by dim(𝒫), is the minimum integer k such that there exists a realiser of 𝒫 of cardinality k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A open interval on the real line, denoted as (a,b), where a,b ∈ and a < b, is the set {x ∈ℝ : a <  x < b}. For a collection C of open intervals on the real line the partial order (C, ) defined by the relation (a,b)  (c,d) if b ≤ c in  is called the interval order corresponding to C. The poset dimension of this interval order (C,) is called the interval dimension of C and is denoted by (C).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: For a positive integer n, let C_n = {(a,b) : a, b ∈ [n], a < b } be the collection of all the n  2 open intervals which have their endpoints  in [n]. Then (C_n,), the interval order corresponding to the collection C_n, is called the canonical open interval order.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A family  of permutations of V(H) is pairwise suitable for a hypergraph H if, for every two disjoint edges e,f ∈ E(H), there exists a permutation σ∈  which separates e and f. The cardinality of a smallest family of permutations that is pairwise suitable for H is called the separation dimension of H and is denoted by (H).
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For a non-negative integer k, a graph G is k-degenerate if the vertices of G can be enumerated in such a way that every vertex is succeeded by at most k of its neighbours. The least number k such that G is k-degenerate is called the degeneracy of G and any such enumeration is referred to as a degeneracy order of V(G).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: The arboricity of a graph G, denoted by 𝒜(G), is the minimum number of spanning forests whose union  covers all the edges of G. The star arboricity of a graph G, denoted by 𝒮(G), is the minimum number of spanning star forests whose union covers all the edges of G.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Poset dimension]

Let (𝒫, ) be a poset (partially ordered set). A linear extension L of 𝒫 is a total order which satisfies (x  y ∈𝒫)  (x  y ∈ L). A realiser of 𝒫 is a set of linear extensions of 𝒫, say ℛ, which satisfy the following condition: for any two distinct elements x and y, x y ∈𝒫 if and only if x  y ∈ L, ∀ L ∈ℛ.  
The poset dimension of 𝒫, denoted by dim(𝒫), is the minimum integer k such that there exists a realiser of 𝒫 of cardinality k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Interval dimension]

A open interval on the real line, denoted as (a,b), where a,b ∈ and a < b, is the set {x ∈ℝ : a <  x < b}. For a collection C of open intervals on the real line the partial order (C, ) defined by the relation (a,b)  (c,d) if b ≤ c in  is called the interval order corresponding to C. The poset dimension of this interval order (C,) is called the interval dimension of C and is denoted by (C).
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
The multiset [L_1,L_2] is  locally-restrictive if there exists a constant c ∈ℕ
such that, if Γ is a finite  G-locally-transitive graph with (Γ,G) locally
[L_1,L_2] and {u,v} is an edge of Γ, then |G_uv|≤ c.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let k≥ 2. A rank k amalgam is a finite set  𝒜  together with a set of k subsets
P_1,…,P_k, where each P_i forms a group, ⋃_i=1^k P_i=𝒜, ⋂_i=1^k
P_i≠∅ and, for every  i,j∈{1,…,k} the group operations defined on P_i and
P_j coincide when restricted to P_i ∩ P_j. 

The Borel subgroup  of 𝒜  is ⋂_i=1^k P_i and is denoted
ℬ(𝒜). If there is no nontrivial subgroup of ℬ(𝒜) that is
normalised by each of P_1,…,P_k then we say that 𝒜 is faithful . The
permutation type of 𝒜  is the multiset [L_1,…,L_k] where L_i is the
permutation group induced by P_i in its action on the right cosets of ℬ(𝒜) in
P_i.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A limit permutation is a Lebesgue measurable function Z:[0,1]^2 →[0,1] satisfying the following conditions:


  (a) for every x∈[0,1], the function Z(x,·) is a cdf, continuous at the point 0, for which Z(x,1)=1;


  (b) for every y∈[0,1], the function Z(·,y) is such that

    ∫_0^1 Z(x,y) dx = y.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given permutations σ_1,σ_2:[n] → [n], the rectangular distance between σ_1 and σ_2 is given by

    d_□(σ_1,σ_2) = 1/nmax_S,T∈ I[n] ||σ_1(S)∩ T|-|σ_2(S)∩ T||.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given an integer k, a weighted permutation is a matrix Q:[k]^2 → [0,1] with the following two properties:



  (a) for every i ∈ [k] and j ≤ j' ∈ [k], we have Q(i,j) ≤ Q(i,j');


  (b) for every j ∈ [k], we have

    j-1 ≤∑_i=1^k Q(i,j) ≤ j.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a limit permutation Z:[0,1]^2 → [0,1] and a positive integer n, a Z-random permutation σ(n,Z)
is a permutation of [n] generated as follows. A set of n pairs (X_1,a_1),…,(X_n,a_n) in [0,1]^2
is independently generated, where, for each i, X_i is chosen uniformly and a_i is chosen according to the probability
distribution induced by the cdf Z(X_i,·). These pairs define the functions R,S:[n]→[n],
where R(i)= |{j : X_j ≤ X_i}| and S(i)= |{j : a_j ≤ a_i}| for every i.
The random permutation is given by the composition σ(n,Z)=S · R^-1, that is, σ(n,Z)(i)=S(R^-1(i)) for every i∈[n].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Alexandrov's Portmanteau Theorem]
Let Ω be a separable metric space and let μ, μ_1, μ_2, … be probability measures over the Borel sets of Ω. The following assertions are equivalent.


  (a) For every bounded continuous function g:Ω→ℝ, lim_n →∞∫_Ω g dμ_n   =  ∫_Ω g dμ.  


  (b) lim_n →∞μ_n(A)=μ(A) for every A ⊆Ω whose boundary ∂ A satisfies μ(∂ A)=0. The boundary ∂ A of A is the set of points x of A for which every open ball centered at x contains a point in Ω\ A.


  (c) lim sup_n →∞μ_n(C) ≤μ(C) for every closed set C ⊆Ω.


  (d) lim inf_n →∞μ_n(U) ≥μ(U) for every open set U ⊆Ω.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Subpermutation density]
For positive integers k, n ∈, let τ∈ S_k and π∈ S_n. 
The number of occurrences Λ(τ,π)  of the permutation τ in π is the number of k-tuples
 (x_1,x_2,…,x_k) ∈ [n]^k_< such that
 π(x_i) < π(x_j) if and only if τ(i)<τ(j). 
The density of the permutation τ as a subpermutation of π is given by 

    t(τ,π)=
    nk^-1Λ(τ,σ)     if  k≤ n
     0     if   k> n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Convergence of a permutation sequence]
A permutation sequence (σ_n)_n ∈ℕ is convergent if, for every fixed permutation τ, the sequence of real numbers (t(τ,σ_n))_n ∈ℕ converges.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Limit permutation]
A limit permutation is a Lebesgue measurable function Z:[0,1]^2 →[0,1] satisfying the following conditions:


  (a) for every x∈[0,1], the function Z(x,·) is a cdf, continuous at the point 0, for which Z(x,1)=1;


  (b) for every y∈[0,1], the function Z(·,y) is such that

    ∫_0^1 Z(x,y) dx = y.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Graph of a permutation]
Given a permutation σ:[n] → [n], the graph G_σ of σ is the bipartite graph  with disjoint copies of [n] as color classes A and B, where {a,b}, with a ∈ A and b ∈ B, is an edge if and only if σ(a)<b.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Rectangular distance]
Given permutations σ_1,σ_2:[n] → [n], the rectangular distance between σ_1 and σ_2 is given by

    d_□(σ_1,σ_2) = 1/nmax_S,T∈ I[n] ||σ_1(S)∩ T|-|σ_2(S)∩ T||.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Weighted permutation]
Given an integer k, a weighted permutation is a matrix Q:[k]^2 → [0,1] with the following two properties:



  (a) for every i ∈ [k] and j ≤ j' ∈ [k], we have Q(i,j) ≤ Q(i,j');


  (b) for every j ∈ [k], we have

    j-1 ≤∑_i=1^k Q(i,j) ≤ j.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given weighted permutations Q_1,Q_2:[k]^2→[0,1],
the rectangular distance between Q_1 and Q_2 is given by

    d_□(Q_1,Q_2) = 1/kmax_S∈ I[k]
    a<b∈[k+1]|∑_x∈ S((Q_1(x,b)-Q_1(x,a))-(Q_2(x,b)-Q_2(x,a)))|.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Subpermutation density in a weighted permutation]

Given a weighted permutation Q:[k]^2→[0,1]
and a permutation τ:[m]→[m], m<k, the subpermutation density of τ in Q is given by

    t(τ,Q)=km^-1∑_X∈[k]^m_<∑_A∈[k+1]^m_<∏_i=1^m(Q(x_i,a_τ(i))-Q(x_i,a_τ(i)-1)),

where we use the notation X=(x_1,…,x_m) and A=(a_1,…,a_m).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For m>1, let τ:[m]→[m] be a permutation and let Z:[0,1]^2→[0,1]
be such that Z(x,·) is a cdf for every x∈[0,1]. The core function of Z is the function  L_τ,Z:[0,1]^m→[0,1] mapping x=(x_1,…,x_m)∈[0,1]^m to

    L_τ,Z(x) = ∫_[0,1]^m_<dZ(x_τ^-1(1),·)  dZ(x_τ^-1(2),·)⋯ dZ(x_τ^-1(m),·).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Subpermutation density in a limit permutation]
For a permutation τ:[m]→[m] (m>1) and a limit permutation Z:[0,1]^2→[0,1],
the subpermutation density of τ in Z is given by

    t(τ,Z) = m!∫_[0,1]^m_<L_τ,Z(x)dx


    = m!∫_[0,1]^m_<(∫_[0,1]^m_<dZ(x_τ^-1(1),·)  ⋯ dZ(x_τ^-1(m),·))
       dx_1⋯ dx_m.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: subpermutation density of τ in Z

sentence:
[Z-random permutation]
Given a limit permutation Z:[0,1]^2 → [0,1] and a positive integer n, a Z-random permutation σ(n,Z)
is a permutation of [n] generated as follows. A set of n pairs (X_1,a_1),…,(X_n,a_n) in [0,1]^2
is independently generated, where, for each i, X_i is chosen uniformly and a_i is chosen according to the probability
distribution induced by the cdf Z(X_i,·). These pairs define the functions R,S:[n]→[n],
where R(i)= |{j : X_j ≤ X_i}| and S(i)= |{j : a_j ≤ a_i}| for every i.
The random permutation is given by the composition σ(n,Z)=S · R^-1, that is, σ(n,Z)(i)=S(R^-1(i)) for every i∈[n].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Rectangular distance between limit permutations]
Given functions Z_1,Z_2:[0,1]^2→[0,1] such that Z(x,·) is a cdf for every x∈[0,1], the rectangular distance between Z_1 and Z_2 is defined by

    d_□(Z_1,Z_2) = sup_x_1<x_2∈ [0,1]
    α_1<α_2∈[0,1]|∫_x_1^x_2∫_α_1^α_2dZ_1(x,·)dx
      -∫_x_1^x_2∫_α_1^α_2dZ_2(x,·)dx|.

sentence:
Let A = [ A^+; A^- ] and B = [ B^+; B^- ] be two binary matrices with the same even number of rows.
We say that the matrix ([ 1 0; 0 1 ]) is a compatible submatrix of ([ A B ])  if there exist ℓ, k, k' such that

    A^+_ℓ k   = 1,     B^+_ℓ k'   = 0,
    
    
    A^-_ℓ k   = 0,     B^-_ℓ k'   = 1.

In that case, we will write A _ℓ, k, k' B. We denote by γ_ℓ, k, k'(A, B) (γ_ℓ, k^±(A), γ^±_ℓ, k'(B)) the pair of binary matrices that we obtain if we replace the submatrix ([ 1 0; 0 1 ]) by ([ 0 1; 1 0 ]).

sentence: Let G be a finite graph. We denote by (G) the number of spanning trees of G. When G is connected, (G) is often called the complexity of G. For a finite graph G with connected components G_1, …, G_μ, we define the complexity T(G) to be the product (G_1) ⋯(G_μ).

the Laplacian matrix L of a finite graph G is the difference D - A, where 
D is the diagonal matrix of degrees of G, and A is the adjacency matrix of G, with A_i,j equal to the number of edges between the ith and jth vertices of G. Loops in G are ignored.

A graph G is robust if for every v ∈
  V(G), every component of G[N(v)] has order at least 5.

sentence:
Let G_1 and G_2 be graphs. A k-sum of G_1 and G_2 is any
  graph obtained by identifying the vertices of a k-clique in G_1 with
  a k-clique in G_2 and then possibly deleting some edges of the merged
  k-clique. (In particular, a 0-sum is a disjoint union.)

  We say that a pair (M,Q) as above witnesses H.
