sentence:
A vector-relation configuration on G consists of choices of 


  * a nonzero vector v_w ∈ V for each w ∈ W and

  * a non-trivial linear relation R_b among the vectors {v_w : w ∈ N(b)} for each b ∈ B.

In particular, each set {v_w : w ∈ N(b)} must be linearly dependent.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Consider a vector-relation configuration on a graph G as above and suppose λ≠ 0.  The gauge transformation by λ at a black vertex b ∈ B scales the relation R_b by λ (and keeps all other vectors and relations the same).  The gauge transformation by λ at a white vertex w ∈ W scales v_w by 1/λ and scales the coefficient of v_w by λ in each relation in which it appears to compensate.  Two vector-relation configurations are called gauge equivalent if they are related by a sequence of gauge transformations.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A vector-relation configuration on a plabic graph G is a choice of vector v_w ∈ V=ℂ^k for each w ∈ W and a non-trivial linear relation R_b among the neighboring vectors of each b ∈ B such that


  * the vector v_w at each internal white vertex w is nonzero,

  * the boundary vectors v_1,…, v_n span V, and

  * the M × N matrix K = (K_ij) is full rank.

Two configurations are called gauge equivalent if they are related by a sequence of gauge transformations, in the sense of Definition <ref>, at internal vertices.

sentence:
A rooted binary phylogenetic network N=(V,E) on a finite set X of taxa is ♌a directed acyclic graph

(DAG) with no parallel edges where the leaves (nodes of indegree-1 and outdegree-0) are bijectively labelled by X, there is a unique node of indegree-0 and outdegree-1 – the root – and all other nodes are either  tree nodes (indegree-1 and outdegree-2) or  reticulations (indegree-2 and outdegree-1). 
We will write V(N), L(N) to denote the nodes and leaves of N, respectively.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let N, N' be two networks with leaves labeled with X.
 Then an isomorphism between N and N' is a bijection ϕ: V(N) → V(N') such that 
 
  
  * two nodes u,v ∈ V(N) are adjacent in N if and only if ϕ(u) and ϕ(v) are adjacent in N';
  
  * for any leaf u ∈ L(N), ϕ(u) is the leaf in L(N') that has the same label as u.
 
We say N and N' are isomorphic if there exists an isomorphism between N and N'.

sentence: Let X be a finite set of taxa. The k-th tier <cit.> on X is the set of all networks with label set X ♌and reticulation number k.

sentence: Let e=(u,v) be an edge in a  network. Then e is called non-movable ♌if u is the root, ♌if u is a reticulation, or if the removal of e followed by ♌suppressing u creates parallel edges. Otherwise, e is called movable .

sentence: Let N be a  network and let x,u,y be nodes of N. We say x,u and y form a ♌triangle if there are edges (x,u), (u,y) and (x,y). The edge (x,y) is called the long edge and (u,y) is called the bottom edge ♌of the triangle.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
A mycorrhizal forest[
 Mycorrhizal forests are so-called because of their similarity to real-life mycorrhizal networks, in which a number of trees may be connected together by an underground network of fungi.] with leaves X is a network M=(𝒯,R) defined by:


  * a set of t trees 𝒯 = (T_1,… ,T_t) with leaf sets X_1,… ,X_t respectively (the tree components ),

  * a network R (the root component ) with t leaves x_1,…,x_t, such that deleting all these leaves and the root makes R biconnected.

The mycorrhizal forest is the network where the root edge of T_i is identified with the edge leading to leaf x_i in R (see Figure <ref> for an example). A mycorrhizal forest with t=1 is called a mycorrhizal tree .

If M and M' are mycorrhizal forests with tree components T_1,… ,T_t and T'_1,… ,T'_t, respectively, both having leaf sets X_1,… ,X_t, then we denote d_treeSPR(M,M'):=∑_id_rSPR(T_i,T_i'), which is the distance induced by rSPR moves only within tree components (treeSPR moves).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let 𝒯={T_i}_1≤ i≤ t be a set of trees with labels X. An agreement forest (AF) of 𝒯 is a partition {X_j} of X∪{ρ} (where ρ denotes the root), such that all T_i|_X_j are isomorphic for each fixed j and all T_i|_X_j are node-disjoint for a fixed i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Rootable network]
An unrooted network U is called rootable if there exists a rooted network N such that U(N)=U.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let U be an unrooted network, and let {u,v}, {x,u}, {u,y} and e be edges of U.   
The SPR move of the u-end of {u,v} to e consists of the subdivision of e with u', the removal of {u,v}, the suppression of u, and the addition of edge {u',v}. The move is only valid if the resulting graph is an unrooted network, i.e. if it is connected and has no parallel edges.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝒮 be the combinatorial class of all rooted plane trees τ, where the
  rightmost leaves in all branches attached to the root of τ have an odd
  distance to the root. In particular,  itself, i.e., the tree consisting of
  just the root belongs to 𝒮 as well. We call the trees in 𝒮
  Catalan–Stanley trees.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let τ∈𝒮 be a Catalan–Stanley tree. Then we define α(τ), the
  age of τ, to be the number of expansions required to grow τ from the
  tree of size one, . In particular, we want
  
    α(τ) = r     τ∈ (ρ^-1)^r()  and τ∉(ρ^-1)^r-1()

  for r∈_≥ 1, and we set α() = 0.

sentence: Let G be a graph and A,B⊆ V(G). Denote by  d(A,B):=e(G[A,B])/|A||B| the density of the pair (A,B). Given >0, a pair X,Y⊆ V(G) is -regular if for every A⊆ X and B⊆ Y with |A|≥ |X| and |B|≥ |Y|, |d(A,B)-d(X,Y)|≤. A vertex partition of G, V(G)=C_1∪…∪ C_m is -regular if all but m^2 pairs of (C_i,C_j) are -regular.

sentence:
For every >0, positive integer t, and an n-vertex graph G=(V,E), let ={C_1, …, C_m} be an -regular partition of V(G) with m≥ t. Denote by R the cluster graph (with respect to ) with vertex set , and C_i and C_j are adjacent if the pair (C_i,C_j) is -regular with density at least 10. We now define the weighted cluster graph , R=(,w) (with respect to ), on the vertex set  as follows. For an -regular pair (C_i,C_j), we will define:

    w(C_i,C_j):={[ 0d(C_i,C_j)≤ 10(C_i,C_j),; 1/210<d(C_i,C_j)≤ 1/2+10,;       1d(C_i,C_j)>1/2+10. ].

sentence:
A weighted graph G is an ordered triple (V,E,w) where E:=V 2, set of all unordered pairs of vertices, and w:E→{0,1/2,1}. Define G_1/2=(V,E_1/2) where E_1/2={e∈ E: w(e)≥ 1/2} and G_1=(V,E_1) 
where E_1={e∈ E: w(e)=1}. Denote by e(G)=∑_e∈ E(G)w(e).

For two weighted graphs G=(V,E,w) and G'=(V,E,w'), define G∩ G'=(V,E,w”) where w”(e)=min{w(e),w'(e)}. For X⊆ Y⊆ V, we call (X,Y) a weighted (|X|,|Y|)-clique or weighted complete subgraph of size ℓ if X 2⊆ E_1 and Y 2⊆ E_1/2 and |X|+|Y|=ℓ. Also, let the weighted clique number of G be the size of the largest weighted complete subgraph of G. 

For a triangle T=e_1e_2e_3, let w(T)=∏_i=1^3 w(e_i). Also, let 
T(G)=∑_T∈ w(T), where  is the set of all triangles in G. For X⊆ V(G), denote T(X)=∑_T∈ G[X]w(T).

sentence:
<cit.>  Let x be a large quantity, let 𝒜 be a set of integers, ℒ = {L_1,…,L_k} a finite set of linear forms, and B a natural number. We allow 𝒜, ℒ, k, B to vary with x.  Let 0 < θ < 1 be a quantity independent of x.  Let ℒ' be a subset of ℒ.  We say that the tuple (𝒜, ℒ, 𝒫, B, x, θ) obeys Hypothesis 1 at ℒ' if we have the following three estimates:


  (1) (𝒜(x) is well-distributed in arithmetic progressions) We have

    ∑_q ≤ x^θmax_a | #𝒜(x;q,a) - #𝒜(x)/q| ≪#𝒜(x) /log^100k^2 x.


  (2) (𝒫_L,𝒜(x) is well-distributed in arithmetic progressions) For any L ∈ℒ', we have

    ∑_q ≤ x^θ; (q,B)=1max_a: (L(a),q)=1| #𝒫_L,𝒜(x;q,a) - #𝒫_L,𝒜(x)/φ_L(q)| ≪#𝒫_L,𝒜(x) /log^100k^2 x.


  (3) (𝒜(x) not too concentrated)  For any q < x^θ and a ∈ we have

    #𝒜(x;q,a)  ≪#𝒜(x)/q.

	G_γ(X;q,t)  to be

       =  ∑_α: α ^+= γ  E_(α)^β (α )(X;q,t),

where the sum is over all weak compositions α for which α^+=γ.
	Then G_γ(X; q, t) satisfies properties 
	(A), (B), (C), and (D).

sentence: Given a filling σ of the diagram of a partition λ, we say that σ is a sorted tableau if, for all positive integers h, when we read all columns of height h from left to right, the columns appear in weakly increasing order with respect to .  We write (λ) for the set of all sorted tableaux of shape λ.

sentence:
Given a rotationally symmetric n-Venn diagram, we label the curves as C_1, C_2, …, C_n according to the clockwise order in which
   they touch the unbounded outermost face.
 Assume that we have a cluster with the property that every curve intersects the cluster in a segment and that
   cluster S_k contains the crosscut for curve C_k.
 Let L_i,k be the list of curves that we encounter as we follow C_i in the cluster S_k in clockwise order, and
   let ℓ_i,k denote the length of L_i,k.
 A rotationally symmetric n-Venn diagram has crosscut symmetry if it can be partitioned into n such clusters
   S_1, S_2, … , S_n in such a way that for every cluster S_k, for any i  k,
   the list L_i,k is palindromic, that is, for 1 ≤ j ≤ℓ_i,k, we have L_i,k[j] = L_i,k[ℓ_i,k-j+1].

sentence:
[Cayley graph G(Γ,A)]
  
  Let Γ be an abelian group and let A⊂Γ∖{0}
  be symmetric, that is, A=-A.  The Cayley graph G=G(Γ,A) is
  defined to be the graph on Γ, with two vertices γ
  and γ'∈Γ adjacent in G if and only if γ'-γ∈ A.

sentence:
A connected graph is distance regular if, for any integer k and any vertices x,y, the number of vertices at distance k from x and adjacent to y only depends on (x,y).
A connected  bipartite  graph is distance biregular if, for any integer k and any vertices x,y, the number of vertices at distance k from x and adjacent to y only depends on (x,y) and the bipart containing x.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A connected graph with diameter at least s is s-distance regular if, for any integer k and any vertices x,y at distance at most s, the number of vertices at distance k from x and adjacent to y only depends on (x,y).
A connected  bipartite  graph with diameter at least s  is s-distance biregular graph if, for any integer k and any vertices x,y at distance at most s, the number of vertices at distance k from x and adjacent to y only depends on (x,y) and the bipart containing x.

sentence:
Let C_1 and C_2 be two disjoint alternating cycles in a 2-ℳ-closed graph G. We will say that C_1 blue-dominates (resp. red-dominates) C_2 whenever the following conditions are satisfied:


  * [x, y]∈ E(G) for every x ∈ C_1 and y∈ C_2.

  * G[I_C_1] and G[P_C_1] are complete graphs.

  * All the edges in G[I_C_1] are blue (resp. red).

  * All the edges in G[P_C_1] are red (resp. blue).

  * All the edges between I_C_1 and C_2 are blue (resp. red).

  * All the edges between P_C_1 and C_2 are red (resp. blue).


  
    < g r a p h i c s >

  C_1 blue-dominates C_2.


See Figure <ref>. Whenever C_1 blue-dominates or red-dominates C_2, we say that C_1 color-dominates C_2.

sentence:
For a graph G = (V,E) and δ, η > 0, a (δ, η)-cut is
a partition of V into two sets of size at least δ|V| such that there
are at most η|V| cross-edges (i.e. edges that have one endpoint in
each of the sets).

sentence:
A distance function . : 𝕋^d →ℝ_≥ 0 in the sense of Section <ref> satisfies a stochastic triangle inequality if there is a constant C>0 such that the following two conditions hold. 


  * For every >0 let x_1 = x_1(),x_2 = x_2() be uniformly at random in the -ball {x ∈𝕋^d |x≤}. Then

    lim inf_→ 0[x_1-x_2≤ C ] > 0.


  * Moreover,

    lim inf_→ 0({x ∈𝕋^d |x≤})/({x ∈𝕋^d |x≤ C })> 0.

sentence:
Let G and H be two rooted graphs. The one-point union G H of G and H is the graph obtained by identifying the roots of G and H. Namely, the set of vertices of G H is the wedge sum of the pointed sets (V(G),v_0(G)) and (V(H),v_0(H)) and two vertices x,y of G H are adjacent in G H if and only if 
	
		
  * there exist representatives of x and y in G that are adjacent in G, or
		
  * there exist representatives of x and y in H that are adjacent in H.
	
	
	Without loss of generality, we can always assume that v_0(G)=v_0=v_0(H) and V(G)∩ V(H)={v_0}, in which case, G H is just the union of the graphs G and H, that is, G H=(V(G)∪ V(H),E(G)∪ E(H),v_0). Under this assumption, it is clear that x and y are adjacent in G H if and only if 
	
		
  * x,y∈ V(G) and x∼_G y, or
		
  * x,y∈ V(H) and x∼_H y.
	
	
	Moreover, any path in G H from a vertex of H to a vertex of G must include the root v_0. Hence, it is easy to see that 
	
    d_G H(x,y)=
    		d_G(x,y)   if x,y∈ V(G),
    
    		d_H(x,y)   if x,y∈ V(H),
    
    		d_G(x,v_0)+d_H(v_0,y)   if x∈ V(G) and y∈ V(H),
    
    		d_H(x,v_0)+d_G(v_0,y)   if x∈ V(H) and y∈ V(G).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G and H be two rooted graphs. The rooted product G∘ H of G and H is the graph with set of vertices V(G)× V(H) and root (v_0(G),v_0(H)), where two vertices (g,h) and (g',h') are adjacent if and only if either
	
		
  * h=h'=v_0(H) and g∼_G g', or
		
  * g=g' and h∼_H h'.
	
	
	It is clear that 
	
    d_G∘ H((g,h),(g',h'))={[                        d_H(h,h')                         if g=g',; d_H(h,h_0)+d_G(g,g')+d_H(h_0,h')                        if g≠ g', ].

	for every g,g'∈ V(G) and h,h'∈ V(H), where h_0=v_0(H).

Let n∈. For k∈_0 we recursively define the perfect n-ary tree of depth k , denoted by T^k_n, as follows.
	
		
  * T_n^0 is the only possible graph with one vertex.
		
  * For k∈, we define 
    T_n^k=⋁_i=1^nT^k-1_n.
  
	
	It is easy to see that |T_n^k|=n^k+1-1/n-1 for every k∈_0.

sentence:
Let M be a family of r-element subsets of the ground set { a_1,…,a_n }. 
If every edge of the polytope P_M is parallel to 
e_i -e_j for some 1≤ i,j ≤ n we call M a matroid . The elements of M are called bases of the matroid. The polytope P_M is 
the matroid polytope .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
The Bergman Fan B(M) is the subfan of the inner fan of P_M consisting of the matroid types which are loopless. 
The Bergman Complex B(M) is the intersection  B(M)∩𝕊 where 
𝕊={ω∈^n : ∑_i=1^n ω_i= 0 , ∑_i=1^n ω_i^2 =1}.

sentence:
For a finite lattice ℒ a subset 𝒢 in ℒ_> 0̂ is a building set 
if for any X∈ℒ_> 0̂ with 
𝒢_≤ X={ G_1,… ,G_k } the map 

 Φ_X : Π_j=1^k [0̂ , G_j]  ⟶[0̂,X]
induced by the inclusions of the intervals [0̂ , G_j] ⊆ [0̂ , X] is an isomorphism of posets.

sentence:
Let ℒ be a finite lattice and 𝒢 a building set containing the top element 1̂. A subset S⊆𝒢 
is called nested if for any set of 
incomparable elements X_1,… ,X_k of at least two elements of S 
the join X_1 ∨…∨ X_k does not lie in the building set 𝒢 again. Since subsets of S 
fulfill the same condition, again this is a simplicial complex. Topologically, it is a cone with apex {1̂}. Its link 
𝒩(ℒ,𝒢) is the nested set complex of ℒ with respect to the building set 𝒢.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: <cit.>, <cit.> An integer additive set-labeling f is said to be an integer additive set-indexer (IASI, in short) if the induced edge function f^+:E(G) →(X) defined by f^+ (uv) = f(u)+ f(v) is also injective.  A graph G which admits an integer additive set-indexer is called an integer additive set-indexed graph .

sentence: Let X be a non-empty finite set of non-negative integers. A graph G which admits a graceful IASI with respect to the set X is said to be a graceful graph-realisation of the set X with respect to the IASL f.

sentence: For G=(V,E) let ℓ(G) be the digraph G with all loops removed. We say the nonempty vertex set S⊆ V is a structural set of G if S̅ induces no cycles in ℓ(G) and for each v_i∈S̅, ω(e_ii≠λ). We denote by st(G) the set of all structural sets of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For G=(V,E) with S={v_1,…,v_m}∈ st(G) let ℬ_ij(G;S) be the set of paths or cycles from v_i to v_j in G having no interior vertices in S. Furthermore, let 
    ℬ_S(G)=⋃_1≤ i,j ≤ mℬ_ij(G;S).
 We call the set ℬ_S(G) the set of all branches of G with respect to S.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G=(V,E,ω) and β∈ℬ_S(G) for some S∈ st(G). If β=v_1,…,v_m for m>2 we define 
    𝒫_ω(β)=ω(e_12)∏_i=2^m-1ω(e_i,i+1)/λ-ω(e_ii)
 as the branch product of β. If m=2 we define 𝒫_ω(β)=ω(e_12).

sentence:
Let G=(V,E,ω) with structural set S={v_1 …,v_m}. Define ℛ_S(G)=(S,ℰ,μ) to be the digraph such that e_ij∈ℰ if ℬ_ij(G;S)≠∅ and 

    μ(e_ij)=
      ∑_β∈ℬ_ij(G;S)𝒫_ω(β),   1≤ i,j≤ m.

We call ℛ_S(G) the isospectral reduction of G over S.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
For G=(V,E,ω) suppose S_1,…,S_m⊆ V such that S_1∈ st(G), ℛ_1(G)=ℛ_S_1(G) and 
    S_i+1∈ st(ℛ_i(G))  where ℛ_S_i+1(ℛ_i(G))=ℛ_i+1(G),   1≤ i≤ m-1.
 If this is the case then we say S_1,…,S_m induces a sequence of reductions on G and we write ℛ_i(G)=ℛ(G;S_1,…,S_i) for 1≤ i ≤ m-1. Moreover, we let 
    𝒩(G;S_1,…,S_i)=𝒩(G;S_1,…,S_i-1)∪𝒩(ℛ_i-1(G);S_i),  2≤ i≤ m.

sentence:
Let G,𝒳∈𝔾 be graphs with a common branch decomposition both with respect to the same set
S. Then 𝒳 is a branch expansion of G with respect to S if any two β_1,β_2∈ℬ_S(𝒳) are independent and each vertex of 𝒳 is on a branch of ℬ_S(𝒳).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say a cycle of G is a simple cycle if it contains no vertices in D_out(G). We call the set of vertices D_out(G) together with the vertices on the simple cycles of G the basic structural set of G and denote this by bas(G).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: For a polynomial f(x) of degree n, the reciprocal polynomial of f(x) is f_(R)(x):=x^nf(1/x).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence: For a polynomial f(x)∈𝔽_2[x], define the length of f(x) to be the number of monomials in f(x).  This can also be viewed as the number of terms in f(x) with coefficient 1 and is denoted by ℓ_1(f(x)).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We call a polynomial f(x) robust if the first coordinate of β(f(x)) exceeds the second coordinate by more than one, so ℓ_1(f^*(x))>ℓ_0,D-1(f^*(x))+1, where D is the order of f(x).  This is equivalent to saying that ℓ_1(f^*(x))>(D+1)/2.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G=(V_G,E_G) and H=(V_H,E_H) be graphs and let u ∈ V_G and v∈ V_H be two vertices. The glued graph of G and H at u and v is the graph G uv H with vertex set (V_G ∖{u})∪ (V_H ∖{v}) ∪{w} (where w is a new vertex) and for which xy is an edge if and only if xy is an edge of G or H or y=w and xu is and edge of G or xv is an edge of H.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For n≥ 2, the hanging split graph of size n, H_n, is the graph composed of a clique of size n with vertex set {v,v_1,… , v_n-1} and an independent of size n-1 with vertex set {u_1,…,u_n-1}. Add an edge u_iv_i for all 1 ≤ i≤ n-1.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose H is a non-empty hypergraph. We say w: [n] → [2] is a special isolating weight for H if there is an edge e satisfying the following conditions:


  * For all i ∈ e, j ∉ e we have w(i) ≤ w(j).

  * For all e' ≠ e, e' ∈ H we have w(e') > w(e).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For any edge e ⊆ [n] and i ∈ e, we define the next vertex of e as follows. If there is some vertex j ∈ e such that j > i, then Next(i,e) is defined to be the smallest such j. Otherwise, if i is the largest element of e, then we define Next(i,e) to be the smallest element of e.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]

In any coloring of a complete graph with at least 2 vertices containing no rainbow triangle, there exists a non-trivial partition of the vertices (called a Gallai partition ) such that there are at most two colors on the edges between the parts and only one color on the edges between each pair of parts.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given two graphs G and H, the k-colored Gallai-Ramsey number gr_k(G : H) is defined to be the minimum integer n such that every coloring of the complete graph on n vertices using at most k colors contains either a rainbow copy of G or a monochromatic copy of H.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A subset C ⊆ V(G) of the vertices of G is a
  pseudo-clique if its size is bounded by (1-4)k<
  |C|≤ (1+)k, and the minimum degree of G[C] is at least
  (1-4)k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>] 
The superization of a symmetric function f() is

    f̃(, ) := ω_ f[ + ]

(the subscript  denotes that ω acts on f[ + ] = f(, ) considered as a symmetric
function of the  variables only).
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For X ∈𝒞^𝕏, we define the embedding probability of X as S_0^𝕏(X)=ℙ(X↪ Y|X) where Y∼μ^𝕐.  We define S_0^𝕐(Y) similarly and suppress the notation 𝕏,𝕐 when the context is clear.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A hyperplane H in V is ^+-admissible if it
is spanned by a set of vectors of ^+.



When ^+=Δ^+_n(λ) or Δ^+(A,B) then an ^+-admissible hyperplane will be also called   a noncompact wall.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For positive integers ℓ_1,…,ℓ_r a partition 
    =(U_i i∈∏_i∈[r]{0,… ,ℓ_i-1})
 of  indexed by the cube ∏_i∈[r]{0,… ,ℓ_i-1} is called a cube partition (of  of order (ℓ_1,…,ℓ_r)).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence: For a cube partition  of , define the cube colouring c_ on  as follows: Consider an edge (m,n)∈ E(). If m,n∈ U_i_1,…,i_r, then colour both (m,n) and (n,m) with colour r+1. If not, suppose that m∈ U_i_1,…,i_r and n∈ U_j_1,…,j_r. Let k={k'∈ [r] i_k'≠ j_k'} and i_k<j_k (say). Colour (m,n) with colour r+1 and (n,m) with colour k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Cube partition]
For positive integers ℓ_1,…,ℓ_r a partition 
    =(U_i i∈∏_i∈[r]{0,… ,ℓ_i-1})
 of  indexed by the cube ∏_i∈[r]{0,… ,ℓ_i-1} is called a cube partition (of  of order (ℓ_1,…,ℓ_r)).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
Let M be a loopless matroid on E, and let 𝒫 be an order filter of 𝒫_M.
5pt

  * The Bergman fan Σ_M,𝒫 satisfies the mixed hard Lefschetz theorem: For any multiset

    ℒ:={ℓ_1,ℓ_2, …, ℓ_r-2q}⊆𝒦_M,𝒫,

 the linear map  given by the multiplication

    L_ℒ^q: A^q(M,𝒫)_ℝ⟶ A^r-q(M,𝒫)_ℝ,      a ⟼( ℓ_1 ℓ_2 ⋯ℓ_r-2q)  · a

is an isomorphism for all nonnegative integers q ≤r/2.

  * The Bergman fan Σ_M,𝒫 satisfies the mixed Hodge-Riemann Relations: For any multiset

    ℒ:={ℓ_1,ℓ_2, …, ℓ_r-2q}⊆𝒦_M,𝒫  and any  ℓ∈𝒦_M,𝒫,

the symmetric bilinear form given by the multiplication

    Q^q_ℒ: A^q(M,𝒫)_ℝ× A^q(M,𝒫)_ℝ⟶ℝ,      (a_1,a_2) ⟼ (-1)^q deg ( a_1 · L_ℒ^q(a_2))

is positive definite on the kernel of ℓ· L^q_ℒ for all nonnegative integers q ≤r/2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: mixed hard Lefschetz theorem;mixed Hodge-Riemann Relations

sentence:
Let S_M be the polynomial ring

    S_M:=ℝ[x_F| F is a nonempty proper flat of M].

The Chow ring of M is defined to be the quotient 

    A^*(M)_ℝ:=S_M/(I_M+J_M),

 where I_M is the ideal  generated by the quadratic monomials 

    x_F_1x_F_2,   F_1 and F_2 are two incomparable nonempty proper flats  of M,

and  J_M is the ideal  generated by the linear forms 

    ∑_i_1 ∈ F x_F - ∑_i_2 ∈ F x_F,   i_1 and i_2 are  distinct elements of the ground set E.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: When I is a proper subset of  min ℱ, we say that I is compatible with ℱ in E, and write I<ℱ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Bergman complex of an order filter 𝒫⊆𝒫(E) is the collection of simplices

    Δ_𝒫:={▵_I < ℱ  for I ∉𝒫 and ℱ⊆𝒫}.

The Bergman fan of an order filter 𝒫⊆𝒫(E) is the collection of simplicial cones

    Σ_𝒫:={σ_I < ℱ  for I ∉𝒫 and ℱ⊆𝒫}.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: When I is a subset of min ℱ of cardinality less than rk_M(min ℱ), we say that I is compatible with ℱ in M, and write I<_Mℱ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Bergman fan of an order filter 𝒫⊆𝒫(M) is the set of simplicial cones

    Σ_M,𝒫:={σ_I < ℱ  for cl_M(I) ∉𝒫 and ℱ⊆𝒫}.

The reduced Bergman fan of 𝒫 is the subset of the Bergman fan

    Σ_M,𝒫:={σ_I <_Mℱ  for cl_M(I) ∉𝒫 and ℱ⊆𝒫}.

When 𝒫=𝒫(M), we omit 𝒫 from the notation and write the Bergman fan by Σ_M.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let ℓ be a piecewise linear function on Σ, and let σ be a cone in  Σ.
5pt

  * The function  ℓ is convex around σ if it is equivalent to a piecewise linear function that is zero on σ and nonnegative on the link of σ.

  * The function ℓ is strictly convex around σ if it is equivalent to a piecewise linear function that is zero on σ and positive on the link of σ.

The function ℓ is convex if it is convex around every cone in Σ, and strictly convex if it is strictly convex around every cone in Σ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The ample cone of Σ is the open convex cone

    𝒦_Σ:={classes of strictly convex piecewise linear functions on Σ}⊆ A^1(Σ)_ℝ.

The nef cone of Σ is the closed convex cone

    𝒩_Σ:={classes of convex piecewise linear functions on Σ}⊆ A^1(Σ)_ℝ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The combinatorial geometry of M is the simple matroid M on E
 determined by its poset of nonempty proper flats 𝒫(M) = 𝒫(M).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A k-dimensional Minkowski weight on Σ is a function 

    ω: Σ_k ⟶ℤ

which satisfies the balancing condition: For every (k-1)-dimensional cone τ in Σ,

    ∑_τ⊂σω(σ) 𝐞_σ/τ is contained in the subspace generated by τ.

The group of Minkowski weights on Σ is the  group

    MW_*(Σ):=⊕_k ∈ℤMW_k(Σ),

where
MW_k(Σ):={k-dimensional Minkowski weights on Σ}⊆ℤ^Σ_k.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: k-dimensional Minkowski weight;balancing condition;group of Minkowski weights

sentence:
The Chow  ring of Σ is the commutative graded algebra

    A^*(Σ):=S_Σ/(I_Σ+J_Σ),

where I_Σ and J_Σ are the ideals of S_Σ defined by

    I_Σ   :=the ideal generated by the square-free monomials not in Z^*(Σ),
    
    J_Σ   :=the ideal generated by the linear forms ∑_𝐞∈ V_Σ⟨𝐞, m ⟩  x_𝐞 for m ∈ M.

We write A^k(Σ) for the degree k component of A^*(Σ), and set 

    A^*(Σ)_ℝ:=A^*(Σ) ⊗_ℤℝ  and   A^k(Σ)_ℝ:=A^k(Σ)⊗_ℤℝ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The degree map of M is the homomorphism
obtained by taking the cap product 

    deg: A^r(Σ_M) ⟶ℤ,     ξ⟼ξ∩ 1_M,

where 1_M=1 is the constant r-dimensional Minkowski weight on  Σ_M.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A morphism between smooth algebraic varieties X_1 → X_2 is a Chow equivalence
if the induced homomorphism between the Chow rings A^*(X_2) → A^*(X_1) is an isomorphism.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let S_E ∪𝒫 be the polynomial ring  over ℤ with variables indexed by E ∪𝒫:

    S_E ∪𝒫:=ℤ[x_i,x_F]_i ∈ E,F∈𝒫.

The Chow ring of  (M,𝒫) is the commutative graded algebra

    A^*(M,𝒫):=S_E ∪𝒫/(ℐ_1+ℐ_2+ℐ_3+ℐ_4),

where ℐ_1, ℐ_2, ℐ_3, ℐ_4 are the ideals of S_E ∪𝒫 defined below.
5pt

  (Incomparability relations) The ideal ℐ_1 is generated by the  quadratic monomials 

    x_F_1x_F_2,

where F_1 and F_2 are two incomparable flats  in the order filter 𝒫.

  (Complement relations) The ideal ℐ_2 is generated by the  quadratic monomials 

    x_ix_F,

where F is a flat in the order filter 𝒫 and i is an element in the complement E ∖ F.

  (Closure relations) The ideal ℐ_3 is generated by the monomials

    ∏_i ∈ I x_i,

where I is an independent set  of M whose closure is in 𝒫∪{E}.

  (Linear relations) The ideal ℐ_4 is generated by the linear forms 

    (x_i+∑_i ∈ F x_F) -(x_j+ ∑_j ∈ F x_F),

where i and j are  distinct elements of E and the sums are over flats F in 𝒫.


When 𝒫=𝒫(M), we omit 𝒫 from the notation and write the Chow ring by A^*(M).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The matroidal flip from 𝒫_- to 𝒫_+ is the modification of fans Σ_M,𝒫_-⇝Σ_M,𝒫_+.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A graded Artinian ring R^* satisfies the Poincaré duality of dimension r if
5pt

  * there are isomorphisms
R^0 ≃ℝ and R^r ≃ℝ, 

  * for every integer q>r, we have R^q ≃ 0, and,

  * for every integer q ≤ r,
the multiplication defines an isomorphism

    R^r-q⟶Hom_ℝ(R^q,R^r).


In this case, we say that R^* is a Poincaré duality algebra of dimension r .
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O
plain_text_term: Poincaré duality of dimension r;Poincaré duality algebra of dimension r

sentence:
Let ℓ be an element of R^1, and let q be a nonnegative integer ≤r/2.
5pt

  * The Lefschetz operator on R^q associated to ℓ is the linear map

    L^q_ℓ: R^q ⟶ R^r-q,      a ⟼ℓ^r-2q  a.


  * The Hodge-Riemann form on R^q associated to ℓ is  the symmetric bilinear form

    Q^q_ℓ: R^q × R^q ⟶ℝ,      (a_1,a_2) ⟼ (-1)^q deg ( a_1 · L_ℓ^q (a_2) ).


  * The primitive subspace of R^q associated to ℓ is the subspace

    P^q_ℓ:={a ∈ R^q |ℓ· L_ℓ^q(a)=0}⊆ R^q.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that Σ satisfies the Poincaré duality of dimension r if A^*(Σ)_ℝ is a Poincaré duality algebra of dimension r.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Σ be a fan that satisfies Poincaré duality of dimension r.
We say that
5pt

  * Σ satisfies the hard Lefschetz property if A^*(Σ)_ℝ satisfies HL(ℓ) for all ℓ∈𝒦_Σ,

  * Σ  satisfies the Hodge-Riemann relations if A^*(Σ)_ℝ satisfies HR(ℓ) for all ℓ∈𝒦_Σ, and

  * Σ  satisfies the local Hodge-Riemann relations  if the Poincaré duality algebra 

    A^*(Σ)_ℝ/ann(x_𝐞)

satisfies HR(ℓ_𝐞) with respect to the degree map induced by x_𝐞 for all ℓ∈𝒦_Σ  and  𝐞∈ V_Σ.

Hereafter we write ℓ_𝐞  for the image of ℓ in the quotient A^*(Σ)_ℝ/ann(x_𝐞).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: hard Lefschetz property;Hodge-Riemann relations;local Hodge-Riemann relations

sentence:
The reduced characteristic polynomial χ_M( λ) is

    χ_M( λ):=χ_M( λ)/ ( λ-1).

We define a sequence of integers μ^0(M),μ^1(M),…,μ^r(M) by the equality

    χ_M( λ)=∑_k=0^r (-1)^kμ^k(M) λ^r-k.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let ℱ={F_1⊊ F_2⊊⋯⊊ F_k} be a k-step flag of nonempty proper flats of M.
5pt

  * The flag ℱ is said to be initial if r(F_m)=m for all indices m.

  * The flag ℱ is said to be descending if min(F_1)>min(F_2)>⋯>min(F_k)>0.

We write D_k(M) for the set of initial descending k-step flags of nonempty proper flats of M.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Set V := V ∖{v_n}. A G-parking function c = ∑_i = 1^n-1 c_i v_i with respect to v_n is an element of ℤV such that for every non-empty subset , there exists v_i ∈ U with 0 ≤ c_i < d_U(v_i). The parking functions inherit a partial order from ℤV. A parking function c' is maximal if c' ≤ c for any parking function c implies c = c'.

sentence: The connected partition lattice L_G is the set of connected partitions of G partially ordered by refinement: π < π' if π refines π'. We use L^*_G to denote the lattice that is the order dual of L_G. We use 0̂ and 1̂ to denote the minimal and maximal elements of a lattice, respectively. So we have 0̂ = {{v_1},…,{v_n}} and 1̂ = {V} for L_G, and vice-versa for L^*_G.

sentence:
For a cut {U,W}, we define its cut-set to be

Given an atomic datum =(U_0,(U_a)_a∈(L)), there exists a unique chain complex

U_a↪ U_0,

    V_x=_≺ x,

where _≺ x:=_i-1_V_≺ x,
and _x is the inclusion V_x↪ V_≺ x.

We call V the minimal complex
of the atomic datum , and denote it by ()=(,L).

sentence: A chord diagram of order n is a circle with n pairs of pairwise distinct points, considered up to a diffeomorphism (not necessarily orientation-preserving), called chords . Framing is a map from the set of chords into the set _2={0,1}; the chords mapped into 0 and 1 are called orientable and disoriented , respectively.

sentence: Let G be a ribbon graph, α one of its ribbons. Take S to be the union of borders of vertices (that are discs, and hence S is a union of circles), and consider the symmetric difference S':=SΔ∂α: we remove from S two arcs along which α touches it, and add back two “side boundary” arcs from ∂α. Then, S' is still a union of circles (as closed one-dimensional manifold). Take a union of disc attached all the circles from S' (these will be the new vertices), and glue back the same ribbons as in G (see Fig. <ref>). The obtained graph is called partial dual (or Morse petestroika ) of G by the edge (or ribbon) α.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Assume the quasiparabolic W-set (X,)  is bounded below and admits a bar operator. 
For each x ∈ X there are  unique elements M_x ∈(X,) and N_x ∈(X,) with 

    M_x = M_x∈ M_x + ∑_w<x v^-1[v^-1] · M_w
    N_x = N_x∈ N_x + ∑_w<x v^-1[v^-1] · N_w

 where both sums are over w ∈ X.
The elements {M_x}_x ∈ X and {N_x}_x∈ X form  -bases for (X,)  (X,), which we refer to as the canonical bases of these modules.

A scaled W-set is a W-set X with a height function : X → satisfying

    |(x) - (sx)| ∈{0,1}    for all s ∈ S and x ∈ X.

sentence:
A scaled W-set (X,) is quasiparabolic if both of 
the following properties hold:

   (QP1) If (rx) = (x) for some (r,x) ∈ R× X then rx =x.


   (QP2) If  (rx) > (x) and (srx) < (sx) for some (r,x,s) ∈ R× X × S then rx=sx.

 X is  the weakest partial order ≤  with

A degree sequence (d_1,d_2,…,d_n) is called typical if the following three properties hold:


  * 1/2∑_i=1^nd_i ≥cn/3,

  * ln^3/4n ≤max_1≤ i≤ nd_i ≤ln n,

  * i : d_i≥ b_0≤ nln nexp-ln^1/4n.

sentence:
For f ≥ 3, an f-fan at some vertex a>0 in a triangular ladder _π is
a sequence of vertices that has one of the following two forms:


  * π(a-2)≠ and vertices a+1, a+2, …, a+f+1 are all adjacent to the vertex a.


  * π(a-2)= and vertices a-1,a+1, …, a+f are all adjacent to the vertex a.


Equivalently, _π has an f-fan at a>0 with π(a-2)≠ if π(a+1) =1
and π(a+i)=0 for 2≤ i ≤ f.
Similarly, _π has an f-fan at a>0 with π(a-2)= if π(a+1) =1
and π(a+i)=0 for 2≤ i ≤ f-1.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let _π be an M-bounded triangular ladder for some M≥ 3 and let yz ∈ E(_π)
be such that 0<y<z and π(y) ≠. Let

    π' = π_z-1∘ 0     if  y < z-1 
    π_z-1∘ 1     if  y =z-1 ,

where π_ℓ denotes
the ℓ-prefix of π and ∘ denotes string concatenation.
We say yz is a boundary edge of _π w.r.t. _M iff π' ∉_M.  In other
words, an edge is a boundary edge if the ladder obtained by removing all vertices larger than z and
then attaching a new vertex adjacent to y,z no longer belongs to the family _M.
We classify a boundary edge yz into one of two categories:

  
  * outer boundary edges: z=|π|+1 (last vertex in _π) and in addition
  |π| is maximal w.r.t. its number of copies of  (i.e., |π is 3M-1, 2M or M+1 if it
  has 0, 1 or 2 such copies resp.).


  * side boundary edges: all other boundary edges. Necessarily y<z-1, there is at most 1 copy of  in π,
the ladder _π has an (M-1)-fan at y whilst _π' has an M-fan at y.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let _π be a triangular ladder that contains some outer boundary edge yz.
The backward extension from yz to _π,
denoted by B_π,yz, is defined as the graph obtained by deleting from _ π
all edges within the distinguished vertex set I = {0,1,y,z}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let _π be an M-bounded triangular ladder and let yz ∈ E( _π) with y<z be an edge that
is not an outer boundary edge.  The forward extension from yz to _π, denoted by F_π,yz, is the graph
obtained by deleting from _ π all edges between vertices in the following set I of distinguished vertices:
[∙]

  * If yz is an initial edge then I = {0,1, …, y}∪{ z}.

  * If yz is a side boundary edge then I = {0,1, …, y}∪{ z} in case π(y-2)≠
and otherwise I = {0,1, …, y-2}∪{ y,z}.

  * If yz is an interior edge then I = {0,1, …, z}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
* (Bounded towers) For any two realizations C_1 and C_2 of the (d-1)-cube, there exists a cubical d-polytope C made of m (m≤ 4d) d-cubes stacked one on top of the other, such that C_1 and C_2 are projectively equivalent to its bottom and top facets, resp. Call C a d-tower of m cubes .
		
		
  * (Cubical connected sum) For any two cubical d-polytopes P_1 and P_2, and facets F_i of P_i, i=1,2, there exists a projective transformation ϕ and a d-tower T of at most 4d cubes, such that P:=P_1∪ T∪ϕ(P_2) is convex , P_1∩ T=F_1 and ϕ(P_2)∩ T=ϕ(F_2) are the top and bottom facets of T respectively.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For s≥ 2 and n_s_i≥ 2 for i=1,…,s, we define a graph KP(n_1,n_2,…,n_s), called a clique-path , to be a graph constructed by vertex sums using distinct summing vertices and cliques K_n_1, K_n_2,…,K_n_s in order.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For s≥ 2 and n_s_i≥ 2 for i=1,…,s, we define a graph KS(n_1,n_2,…,n_s), called a clique-star , to be a graph constructed by vertex sums using only one summing vertex and cliques K_n_1, K_n_2,…,K_n_s.
The vertex that is in every clique is called the center and every other vertex is called noncentral.

sentence:
Let  be a finite set of combinatorial objects, and let  be
  a descent set map on  such that (T) ⊆ [n-1] for
  all T ∈. A dual equivalence for (,) is a
  family of involutions {φ_i}_1<i<n on  satisfying the
  following conditions:

  
  
    -0.7
  
  * ( fixed points ) The fixed points of φ_i are
    given by
    
      ^φ_i  =  { T ∈ |  i-1 ∈(T)
        ⇔i ∈(T) }.
    
    

  
  * ( descent set ) For T∈∖^φ_i, we have
    
    {j}∩(T) ≠{j}∩(φ_i(T))     j = i-1  j = i, 
       {j}∩(T)   =  {j}∩(φ_i(T))     j<i-2  i+1<j.

    
    
  
  * ( equality ) For T∈∖^φ_i, we have
    
    {i-2}∩(T) ≠{i-2}∩(φ_i(T))
             ⇔   φ_i(T) = φ_i-1(T), 
    {i+1}∩(T) ≠{i+1}∩(φ_i(T))
             ⇔   φ_i(T) = φ_i+1(T).

    
    
  
  * ( commutativity ) For T ∈ and |i-j| ≥ 3, we
    have
    
      φ_j∘φ_i(T) = φ_i∘φ_j(T).
    
    

  
  * ( minimality ) For any 2 ≤ h ≤ i<n, if S =
    φ_i_ℓ∘⋯∘φ_i_1 (T) for indices
    h ≤ i_1,…,i_ℓ≤ i, then there exist indices h
    ≤ j_1,…,j_m ≤ i with at most one j_k = i such that
    S = φ_j_m∘⋯∘φ_j_1 (T).

sentence:
Let  be a finite set of combinatorial objects of fixed degree
  n, and let w : → be a reading word on
  . A D equivalence for (,w) is a family of involutions
  {φ_i}_1<i<n on  satisfying the following conditions:

  
  
  (a) ( restriction ) For T ∈ and J = {i-1,i,i+1},
    we have
    
      [               w(φ_i(T))_J                         = d_i(w(T))_J    _i(w(T))_J;           w(φ_i(T))_[n]∖J                         =                w(T)_[n]∖J ]
    

  
  (b) ( equality ) For T ∈, if φ_i-1(T)
    ∈^φ_i+1 and φ_i+1(T) ∈^φ_i-1, then either φ_i-1(T) = T =
    φ_i+1(T) or φ_i(T) = φ_i-1(T) or
    φ_i(T) = φ_i+1(T).
    
  
  (c) ( commutativity ) For T ∈ and |i-j| ≥ 3, we
    have
    
      φ_j∘φ_i(T) = φ_i∘φ_j(T).
    

  
  (d) ( local Schur positivity ) For J = {i-1,i} or
    {i-1,i,i+1} and  an equivalence class under
    {φ_j}_j ∈ J, the restricted generating function
    
      ∑_T ∈ Q_(st(w(T)_J))(X),
    
    where st is the standardization map defined above, is
    Schur positive.

sentence:
A D graph is a locally Schur positive graph satisfying dual
  equivalence graph axioms 1, 2, 3 and 5 such that for every
  connected component of Φ_i-1∪Φ_i+1 with exactly two
  edges, say with vertices Φ_i-1(w),w,Φ_i+1(w), either
  Φ_i(w) = Φ_i-1(w) or  Φ_i(w) = Φ_i+1(w).

  is an X-orbit, then we say C is X-completely
    transitive , or simply completely transitive .

sentence:
By a Hessenberg pair on V, we mean an
ordered pair (A, A^*) of linear transformations on V that
satisfy (i)–(iii) below.   



  * Each of A, A^* is diagonalizable on V.

  * There exists an ordering { V_i }_i=0^d of the eigenspaces of A such that

    A^* V_i ⊆ V_0 + V_1 + … +
    V_i+1         (0 ≤ i ≤ d),

where V_-1 = 0, V_d+1= 0.

  * There exists an ordering { V^*_i }_i=0^δ of the
eigenspaces of A^* such that

    A V^*_i ⊆ V^*_0 + V^*_1 + …
    +V^*_i+1         (0 ≤ i ≤δ),

where V^*_-1 = 0, V^*_δ+1= 0.

sentence:
<cit.>

By a tridiagonal pair on V, we mean an ordered pair (A, A^*) of linear transformations on V that satisfy (i)–(iv) below.



  * Each of A, A^* is diagonalizable on V.

  * There exists an ordering { V_i
}_i=0^d of the
eigenspaces of A such that

    A^* V_i ⊆ V_i-1 + V_i+ V_i+1         (0 ≤ i ≤ d),

where V_-1 = 0, V_d+1= 0.

  * There exists an ordering { V^*_i
}_i=0^δ of
the
eigenspaces of A^* such that

    A V^*_i ⊆ V^*_i-1 + V^*_i+ V^*_i+1         (0 ≤ i ≤δ),

where V^*_-1 = 0, V^*_δ+1= 0.

  * The pair (A, A^*) is irreducible in the sense of Definition <ref>.

sentence:
Assume λ ={k_1,k_2,…,k_q} is a multi-set of positive integers.
	A λ-painting game on G
	is a k-painting game on G for which the following holds: There are integers k'_1, k'_2, …, k'_q
	such that in the first k'_1 rounds, each vertex v of G is selected by Lister in k_1 rounds;
	in the next k'_2 rounds, each vertex v of G is selected by Lister in k_2 rounds; and so on.
	We say G is λ-paintable if painter has a winning strategy in the λ-painting game on G.

sentence:
Let S ∈STab(n) be a standard tableau.
A decent of S is an integer i, 1 ≤ i ≤ n-1, 
  for which the row of the cell filled by i+1 is strictly below that of i.
A major index of S is defined to be the sum of its descents.

sentence:
A partial matching in a poset P is a partial matching in the underlying graph of the Hasse diagram of P, i.e. it is a subset μ⊆ P × P such that


  * (a,b)∈μ implies b covers a (sometimes denoted as a ⋖ b), i.e. a<b and no c satisfies a<c<b, and

  * each a ∈ P belongs to at most one element in μ.

When (a,b)∈μ, we write a=d(b) and b=u(a).  
A partial matching on P is called acyclic if there does not exist a cycle 

    b_1>d(b_1)<b_2>d(b_2)<⋯<b_n>d(b_n)<b_1
 
with n≥ 2 and all b_i∈ P being distinct.

sentence: Let π a permutation on [n]. The block transposition distance of π is d(π) if π is the product of d(π) block transpositions, but it cannot be obtained as the product of less than d(π) block transpositions.

sentence:
(see <cit.>)Let π be a permutation on [n]. The circular permutation class π^∘ is obtained from π by inserting an extra element 0 that is considered a predecessor of π_1 and a successor of π_n and taking the equivalence class under cyclic index shift. So π^∘ is circular in positions being represented by [0 π_1⋯π_n-1 π_n], [π_n  0 π_1
⋯π_n-1], and so on. The linearization of a circular permutation π^∘ is a permutation π obtained by removing the element 0 and letting its successor be the first element of π. It is customary to denote by π^∘ any representative of the circular class of π and ≡^∘ the equivalence relation.

sentence: (see <cit.>)Let π be a permutation on [n], and let m be an integer with 1≤ m≤ n. The m-step cyclic value shift of the circular permutation π^∘ is the circular permutation m+π^∘ =[m m + π_1⋯ m+ π_n], where the integers are taken mod n+1. The toric class π_∘^∘ is obtained from π^∘ by taking the m-step cyclic value shifts of the circular permutations in π^∘. So, π_∘^∘ is circular in values, as well as in positions.

sentence:
Let f: X_n → X_n+1 be a function, ∼ be an equivalence
relation on X_n, with classes Y_n, and compatible with f, and
let f̃ be the function which leads to the commuting diagram


X_n
@> f >>
X_n+1


@VV·/∼V @VV·/∼V

Y_n
@> f̃ >>
Y_n+1



Call Y(x) the function which associates to each x ∈ X_n its
class in Y_n.  We say that f is a pullback function if, for
all x' ∈ X_n+1, and for all y ∈ Y_n such that
f̃(y)=Y(x), there exists a x ∈ X_n such that Y(x)=y and
f(x)=x'.

sentence:
[Monoid and group operators]

We say that A is a monoid operator on set X_n, if, for the
datum of a finite set Y_n, a map a: X_n → Y_n, and a map

å: Y_n →_n, it consists of the map on X_n defined by

A(x) = å_a(x) x
,

where the action å x is in the sense of the symmetric-group
action over X_n.  We say that A is a group operator if,
furthermore, a(A(x))=a(x).

sentence:
[monoid and group dynamics]
We call a monoid dynamics the datum of a family of spaces
{X_n}_n ∈ as above, and a finite collection ={A_i} of
monoid operators.
We call a group dynamics the analogous structure, in which all
A_i's are group operators.

For a monoid dynamics on the datum S_n = (X_n, ), we say that 

x, x' ∈ X_n are strongly connected , x ∼ x', if there
exist words w, w' ∈^* such that w x = x' and w' x' = x.

For a group dynamics on the datum S_n = (X_n, ), we say that x,
x' ∈ X_n are connected , x ∼ x', if there exists a word
w ∈^* such that w x = x'.

starting with j_1=n is called

sentence:
A permutation  is of type H(r_1,r_2) if it is of type
H, and the portions of the rank path before and after the -1 mark
have path-length 2r_1 and 2r_2, respectively (so the rank length
is r=r_1+r_2-1). It is

of type X(r,i) if it is of type X, has rank r, and the
principal cycle has path-length 2i+1 (i.e., it contributes a i entry to
the cycle structure λ).

s() := Sign(()) ∈{0,±1}
.

sentence:
Call V_± the two vertex-sets of _n,n.  For  a
permutation with edge set E, and E' ⊆ E of cardinality
m, call V”_± the subset of V_± not containing the
endpoints of E'. A pair of partitions P_+=(P_+,1,…,P_+,h)
∈(V”_+) and P_-=(P_-,1,…,P_-,k) ∈(V”_-) are
said to be compatible with E' if each block contains indices
which are consecutive in [n].

Define the m × (hk) matrix valued in _2

Q_e,ij :=
{
[                                                                   1 edge e ∈ E' does not cross the segment connecting
  P_-,i to P_+,j,;                                                                   0                                                          otherwise. ]
.

For v ∈_2^d, let |v| be the number of entries equal to
1. Similarly, identify v with the corresponding subset of [d].
Given such a construction, introduce the following functions on
(_2)^hk

    A_,E',P(v)
       :=
    ∑_u ∈ (_2)^E'
    (-1)^χ_u + (u,Qv);
       _,E',P(v)
       :=
    ∑_u ∈ (_2)^E'
    (-1)^|u|+χ_u + (u,Qv).

sentence:
[Pullback function]
Let f: X_n → X_n+1 be a function, ∼ be an equivalence
relation on X_n, with classes Y_n, and compatible with f, and
let f̃ be the function which leads to the commuting diagram


X_n
@> f >>
X_n+1


@VV·/∼V @VV·/∼V

Y_n
@> f̃ >>
Y_n+1



Call Y(x) the function which associates to each x ∈ X_n its
class in Y_n.  We say that f is a pullback function if, for
all x' ∈ X_n+1, and for all y ∈ Y_n such that
f̃(y)=Y(x), there exists a x ∈ X_n such that Y(x)=y and
f(x)=x'.

S_C is
K-factorizable if there exist maps (not necessarily linear)

    A:(C)→ K          B:(C^∘)→ K^*

such
that S_C(x,y)=<A(x),B(y)> for all (x,y) ∈(C)
×(C^∘).

sentence: The box diagonal diagram  is the skew shape consisting of R rows, S columns and N = R+S-1 cells constructed as follows. Draw a grid R cells high and S cells wide, and a line L given by y= R/S x from the bottom left corner to the top right corner. Then  consists of the cells whose interior or top left corner point is intercepted by L.

sentence:
Let α=α_1⋯α_R be a composition, 2≤ i≤ R, and ν be a partition. Then we define C'_α,i,ν to be the set of LR tableaux T such that

  * sh(T)=α, c(T)=ν, and

  * if T_i,i_1=1, then i≤ R-1 and T_i,i_1+1≥ T_i+1,i_1,

 where the first cell in the i-th row of T is in column i_1. We refer to such T as row-i-restricted LR tableaux , or when the context is clear, simply as restricted LR tableaux . Also set 
    c'_α,i,ν=|C'_α,i,ν| and c'_α,i,j,ν=|C'_α,i,ν∩ C'_α,j,ν|.

sentence:
For two partitions λ=λ_1λ_2⋯λ_ℓ(λ) and μ=μ_1μ_2⋯μ_ℓ(μ) where ℓ(λ)≥ℓ(μ) without loss of generality, define the union of λ and μ to be the partition 
    λ∨μ=max(λ_1,μ_1)max(λ_2,μ_2)⋯max(λ_ℓ(λ),μ_ℓ(λ))
 and the intersection of λ and μ to be the partition 
    λ∧μ=min(λ_1,μ_1)min(λ_2,μ_2)⋯min(λ_ℓ(μ),μ_ℓ(μ)).
 These operations are indeed the set-theoretic union and intersection of the corresponding diagrams. For two skew shapes λ/μ and ν/ρ, define the union and intersection to be the skew shapes 
    (λ/μ)∨(ν/ρ)=(λ∨ν)/(μ∨ρ) and (λ/μ)∧(ν/ρ)=(λ∧ν)/(μ∧ρ).

  We warn that these are the skew shapes arising from the set-theoretic union and intersection of the outer and inner shapes separately, and may not be the set-theoretic union and intersection of the overall diagram.

sentence: An LR tableau T of equitable ribbon shape is comfortable if every long row has a 1 and every long intermediate row has two 1's. Otherwise, T is uncomfortable .

sentence:
Let us write a composition α∈ℛ((a+1)^na^m) as 
    α=a^p_1(a+1)a^p_2(a+1)⋯(a+1)a^p_n+1,
 where p_i≥ 0 for 1≤ i≤ n+1. Then we define the profile of α to be the tuple 
    p(α)=p_1p_2⋯ p_n+1
 and we define the quasi-profile of α to be the tuple q(α)=q_0q_1⋯, where 
    q_j=|{i:p_i=j}|;
 that is, q_j is the number of j's in p(α).

sentence: <cit.> Let α be a composition. Recall that a composition β is a coarsening of α if it can be obtained by adding together adjacent parts of α. We define ℳ(α) to be the multiset of partitions determined by all coarsenings of α and we call it the multiset of coarsenings of α . For a partition λ we denote by m_α(λ) its multiplicity in ℳ(α).
